questions.text: The superior portion of the hyoid bone is derived from which branchial arch?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II

 

  • The superior portion of the hyoid bone is derived from the second branchial arch (hyoid arch). Specifically:
    • The lesser horn and the upper part of the body of the hyoid bone arise from the second branchial arch, which gives rise to structures innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII).
    • The third branchial arch contributes to the lower part of the hyoid bone, including the greater horn and the inferior portion of the body.
  • The second arch is also responsible for structures like the stapes, styloid process, and stylohyoid ligament, highlighting its role in head and neck development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. III: The third branchial arch contributes to the greater horn and the inferior body of the hyoid bone, not the superior portion.

 

Option B. I: The first branchial arch gives rise to the maxilla, mandible, malleus, incus, and associated muscles but does not contribute to the hyoid bone.

 

Option C. IV: The fourth branchial arch gives rise to laryngeal cartilages (e.g., thyroid cartilage) and does not contribute to the hyoid bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The superior portion of the hyoid bone (lesser horn and upper body) is derived from the second branchial arch, which also gives rise to structures innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is diagnosed with FIGO stage IIIB cervical cancer, indicating locally advanced disease. Which of the following represents the most appropriate treatment approach for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy plus chemotherapy

 

  • The treatment of choice for locally advanced cervical cancer (FIGO stages II–IVA) is concurrent chemoradiotherapy. 
  • This approach combines external beam radiation therapy (EBRT), brachytherapy, and concurrent cisplatin-based chemotherapy to maximize tumor control and survival. 
  • Chemotherapy acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of radiotherapy. 
  • Surgery is not typically recommended for FIGO stage IIIB or higher due to the extent of disease spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy alone: While radiotherapy can control localized tumors, concurrent chemotherapy significantly improves survival outcomes by enhancing the radiosensitivity of the tumor. Therefore, radiotherapy alone is not the optimal treatment.

 

Option B. Radiotherapy plus HPV vaccine: HPV vaccines are preventive measures used to reduce the risk of HPV-related cancers. They do not play a role in treating established cervical cancer. Combining radiotherapy with vaccination is not a standard treatment approach.

 

Option D. Surgery alone: Surgery is typically reserved for early-stage cervical cancer (FIGO stages I–IIA). In stage IIIB and higher, the disease extent makes surgical management inappropriate. Concurrent chemoradiotherapy is the preferred treatment for locally advanced disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard treatment for locally advanced cervical cancer (FIGO stages II–IVA) is concurrent chemoradiotherapy, which combines radiotherapy with cisplatin-based chemotherapy to improve tumor control and overall survival.

choices.text: Distribution of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) and indoor residual spraying (IRS)
Provision of oral antimalarial medications in schools
Setting up mobile health units for mass screening and treatment
Expansion of drinking water chlorination programs in tribal regions

questions.text: Which of the following health interventions has demonstrated the most success in reducing the incidence of malaria in tribal populations of India, considering the unique ecological and socioeconomic conditions of these communities?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distribution of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) and indoor residual spraying (IRS)

 

  • Malaria is highly endemic in many tribal regions of India, especially in forested and rural areas. 
  • The use of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) and indoor residual spraying (IRS) have been proven to be the most effective vector control interventions for reducing malaria transmission. 
  • These methods address the vector (Anopheles mosquito) directly, which is the primary cause of malaria in these populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Provision of oral antimalarial medications in schools: While treatment is crucial, mass drug administration in schools has limited impact in malaria control, as it does not prevent further mosquito bites or control mosquito breeding.

 

Option C. Setting up mobile health units for mass screening and treatment: These units are essential for addressing immediate healthcare needs but are less effective for malaria prevention in the long term when compared to vector control strategies like ITNs and IRS.

 

Option D. Expansion of drinking water chlorination programs in tribal regions: While essential for overall health, chlorination is not specifically effective in controlling malaria transmission, as malaria is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes rather than water contamination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The use of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs) and indoor residual spraying (IRS) are the most effective interventions for malaria prevention in tribal regions of India, where mosquito control is essential for reducing transmission.

questions.text: A public health initiative, the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK), is aimed at screening and providing early intervention for children aged 0-18 years in India, particularly targeting conditions related to health deficiencies. Which of the following is not included as a deficiency condition under the RBSK?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asthma

 

  • The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) targets deficiency conditions in children as part of its screening and early intervention strategy.
  •  The program focuses on health issues like Vitamin D deficiency (Rickets), severe acute malnutrition, and goitre, which are directly related to nutritional deficiencies and developmental concerns. 
  • However, asthma is a chronic respiratory condition and not primarily a nutritional deficiency, and thus, it is not included as one of the deficiency conditions targeted by the RBSK program. 
  • RBSK primarily focuses on conditions that can be identified early and are treatable with interventions aimed at addressing nutritional gaps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency (Rickets): This is a deficiency condition included under the RBSK program. Vitamin D deficiency leads to conditions like rickets, which result in bone deformities in children. This is specifically addressed as part of the RBSK’s goal to combat deficiency-related diseases.

 

Option B. Severe acute malnutrition: Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is a major target of the RBSK initiative, which screens children for signs of malnutrition and provides interventions to improve nutritional status. SAM is a deficiency condition caused by inadequate caloric and nutritional intake.

 

Option C. Goitre: Goitre, a condition characterized by the enlargement of the thyroid gland, is often caused by a deficiency of iodine in the diet. It is a common target of the RBSK program as part of efforts to address deficiency diseases in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) primarily targets deficiency conditions such as Vitamin D deficiency (rickets), severe acute malnutrition, and goitre. 
  • Asthma, being a chronic respiratory condition and not a deficiency disease, is not included in the list of targeted conditions under RBSK.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with generalized swelling and frothy urine was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome three months ago but remains unresponsive to corticosteroids. Renal biopsy reveals podocyte foot process effacement and no immune deposits. Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NPHS1 gene mutation

 

  • Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) refers to nephrotic syndrome that does not respond to standard corticosteroid therapy. In this case, the biopsy findings of:
    1. Effacement of podocyte foot processes (on electron microscopy)
    2. No immune deposits
  • They are classic for minimal change disease or focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). 
  • When nephrotic syndrome is steroid-resistant, it is often associated with genetic mutations affecting the glomerular filtration barrier, particularly podocyte structure and function.
  • NPHS1 (nephrin) gene mutation affects nephrin, a key protein in the slit diaphragm of podocytes.
  • Mutations in NPHS1 disrupt podocyte integrity, leading to massive proteinuria and congenital or childhood-onset nephrotic syndrome that is steroid-resistant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. WT1 (Wilms tumor suppressor gene) mutation: WT1 mutations are associated with syndromic nephrotic syndrome, such as Denys-Drash or Frasier syndrome, often presenting with additional genitourinary anomalies.

 

Option C. PAX2 gene mutation: Associated with renal-coloboma syndrome, characterized by renal hypoplasia and colobomas, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. LAMB2 (laminin beta-2) gene mutation: LAMB2 mutations cause Pierson syndrome, characterized by congenital nephrotic syndrome and ocular abnormalities, not isolated SRNS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NPHS1 (nephrin) mutations cause steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome by disrupting the slit diaphragm in podocytes, leading to massive proteinuria unresponsive to corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is scheduled for a brief outpatient endoscopic procedure under monitored anesthesia care in a day-care setting. She requires adequate intraoperative analgesia but must recover quickly after the procedure to be discharged home the same day. The anesthesiologist must choose an opioid that provides effective pain control while allowing rapid postoperative recovery with minimal residual sedation. Which opioid is most suitable for intraoperative analgesia in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remifentanil

 

  • Remifentanil has a rapid onset and extremely short duration of action due to its rapid metabolism by plasma esterases. 
  • This makes it ideal for day-care surgeries where quick patient recovery and discharge are necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sufentanil: Incorrect. Although sufentanil is potent and has a rapid onset, it has a longer duration of action than remifentanil, which may not be ideal for day-care surgery due to prolonged sedation.

 

Option C. Morphine: Incorrect. Morphine has a longer duration of action and can lead to postoperative sedation and respiratory depression, which are not desirable in a day-care setting.

 

Option D. Butorphanol: Incorrect. Butorphanol can cause sedation and has a longer duration of action compared to remifentanil, making it less favorable for short procedures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • For day-care surgeries, remifentanil is the opioid of choice due to its ultra-short-acting properties, which allow for a rapid recovery and minimal postoperative sedation, enabling patients to be discharged sooner.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with SIADH develops normalization of serum sodium levels after persistent water retention. This improvement, known as vasopressin escape, is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

  • In SIADH, excessive Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH) causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia and dilution of serum osmolality. 
  • However, over time, the kidneys exhibit a compensatory mechanism termed "vasopressin escape", which prevents excessive water retention and further worsening of hyponatremia.
  • This phenomenon occurs due to the downregulation of aquaporin 2 (AQP2) channels in the collecting ducts of the kidneys. 
  • Aquaporin 2 is upregulated in response to ADH to facilitate water reabsorption. 
  • In vasopressin escape, prolonged exposure to high ADH levels leads to internalization and decreased production of AQP2 channels, reducing water reabsorption and allowing more water to be excreted. 
  • This helps stabilize serum sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in ADH secretion: In SIADH, ADH secretion remains persistently elevated due to the underlying cause (e.g., malignancy, CNS disorders). Vasopressin escape occurs despite continued high ADH levels.

 

Option C. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Upregulation of AQP2 production enhances water reabsorption, worsening hyponatremia. In vasopressin escape, AQP2 channels are downregulated, reducing water retention.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolarity: In vasopressin escape, urine osmolarity decreases as the kidneys excrete more free water. Increased urine osmolarity is a feature of early SIADH before vasopressin escape occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vasopressin escape in SIADH occurs due to the downregulation of aquaporin 2 channels in the renal collecting ducts. 
  • This reduces water reabsorption despite persistently elevated ADH levels, preventing further worsening of hyponatremia.

questions.text: A mother presents with a 3-week-old infant expressing excessive concern about harming her baby. She reports hearing voices telling her the baby is evil and must be killed, though she hasn't acted on these thoughts. She appears well-groomed but extremely anxious. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum psychosis

 

  • The most appropriate diagnosis is postpartum psychosis. 
  • This disorder occurs in the first few weeks to a month after childbirth and is characterized by severe psychiatric symptoms, including hallucinations and delusions.
    • In this case, the mother is experiencing auditory hallucinations (hearing voices telling her that her baby is evil and must be killed). Even though she hasn't acted on these thoughts, the presence of psychotic symptoms (auditory hallucinations) is suggestive of postpartum psychosis.
    • Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency, requiring immediate intervention and treatment to prevent harm to the mother or the baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum blues: This is a mild, self-limited condition that occurs in the first few days to weeks after childbirth. It involves mood swings, tearfulness, mild irritability, and anxiety, but it does not include hallucinations or delusions.

 

Option C. Postpartum depression: While postpartum depression involves symptoms like low mood, anxiety, fatigue, and sleep disturbances, it does not present with hallucinations or delusions. Hallucinations would point more towards a psychotic disorder.

 

Option D. Adjustment disorder: This is characterized by emotional distress related to a life stressor, such as financial issues, but it does not include psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Postpartum psychosis is usually seen within 2-3 weeks of delivery. Initial symptoms include tearfulness, insomnia, and lability. 
  • Later delusions (e.g. baby is dead, didn’t give birth to a child) and hallucinations develop. 
  • There is a risk of harm to self or the baby. In some cases, the baby has to be separated from the mother to prevent harm to the baby. 
  • Treatment includes the use of antipsychotics with lithium; antidepressants may be added if required.

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the impact of a hospital’s services and health programs on disease prevention. Among the various metrics, which one would be the most appropriate for assessing the efficacy of these services in reducing the occurrence of new cases of disease in a population?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incidence

 

  • Incidence refers to the rate of new cases of a disease in a population over a specified period of time. 
  • It is the most appropriate measure when evaluating the efficacy of health programs and hospital services because it directly reflects the effectiveness of interventions in preventing the occurrence of new cases. 
  • A reduction in incidence indicates that the hospital services or health programs are effectively preventing the disease or controlling its spread.
  • Incidence is especially important when the goal is to assess how successful a program is at reducing new infections or the emergence of disease in a community. 
  • This is often more telling than metrics like case fatality rate or prevalence, which may not directly reflect the ability of health services to prevent new cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case fatality rate: The case fatality rate (CFR) measures the proportion of individuals who die from a disease among those diagnosed with it. While it reflects the severity of disease and effectiveness of treatment, it does not directly measure the preventive aspects of hospital services or health programs.

 

Option B. Prevalence: Prevalence measures the total number of existing cases of a disease in a population at a given point in time. While important for understanding the burden of disease, it does not assess how well a health program is preventing new cases.

 

Option C. Secondary attack rate: The secondary attack rate measures the rate at which disease spreads within households or close contacts after the initial case. It is useful for studying transmission dynamics but not as directly relevant to assessing the overall efficacy of health services in reducing new cases of disease in the broader population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incidence is the best indicator of the efficacy of health programs and hospital services in preventing new cases of disease within a population.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation is scheduled for a total knee arthroplasty. He is currently managed on warfarin therapy, which has been held for the past 5 days. Preoperative labs show a platelet count of 85,000/mm^3, and he reports taking aspirin up until two days ago. He does not have a history of bleeding disorders, and no intravenous heparin has been administered. Considering his medication history and lab findings, which of the following would generally not be a contraindication to performing central neuraxial anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recent use of aspirin

 

  • While recent use of aspirin does alter platelet function, it is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial blocks. 
  • Many practitioners will proceed with the block if the aspirin was discontinued at least a few days prior and if there are no other bleeding risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thrombocytopenia: Central neuraxial blocks, including spinal and epidural anesthesia, are contraindicated in patients with significant thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Ongoing treatment with oral anticoagulants: Patients on oral anticoagulants like warfarin should have the medication held for an appropriate time before the procedure, and coagulation status should be normalized to reduce the risk of bleeding complications. This patient had his warfarin held 5 days prior, which typically allows for normalization of coagulation status.

 

Option D. Administration of intravenous heparin: Intravenous heparin is a significant contraindication for central neuraxial blocks due to the high risk of bleeding and spinal hematoma formation, unless it has been discontinued and the aPTT has normalized.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Aspirin alters platelet function but is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial anesthesia, particularly if discontinued a few days before the procedure and in the absence of other bleeding risks. Each patient must be assessed individually, taking into consideration current guidelines and clinical judgment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) since infancy, chronic diarrhea, eczema, and autoimmune thyroiditis is diagnosed with a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by immune dysregulation. The condition involves a profound deficiency in regulatory T cells (Tregs), leading to systemic autoimmunity. Which of the following genes is most likely mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FOXP3

 

  • IPEX syndrome (Immune Dysregulation, Polyendocrinopathy, Enteropathy, X-linked) is caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene. 
  • This gene encodes a transcription factor critical for the development and function of regulatory T cells (CD4+CD25+FOXP3+), which maintain immune tolerance. 
  • Mutations in FOXP3 lead to severe autoimmunity due to the absence of functional Tregs. 
  • While other genes like IL-2Rα and CD25 may also play a role in immune dysregulation, FOXP3 is the primary gene implicated in IPEX syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mutations in the FOXP3 gene are the hallmark genetic defect in IPEX syndrome, leading to immune dysregulation and widespread autoimmunity.

choices.text: 10% female carriers are mentally retarded

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, hyperactivity, and difficulty maintaining eye contact. On examination, he has a long face, large protruding ears, and macroorchidism. His family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms. Genetic testing is performed, revealing an abnormal FMR1 gene. Which of the following statements is true about Fragile X syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Males have IQ 20–40

 

  • Males with Fragile X syndrome typically have a mean IQ of around 42, with intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe. 
  • The IQ tends to be lower if there is complete silencing of the FMR1 gene. 
  • Some males with mosaicism for the mutation may retain higher IQ levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triple nucleotide CAG sequence mutation: Incorrect. Fragile X syndrome involves CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion, not CAG repeats. CAG repeats are seen in Huntington’s disease and other polyglutamine disorders.

 

Option B. 10% female carriers are mentally retarded: Incorrect. About 35% of female carriers have intellectual impairment or borderline IQ, not just 10%.

 

Option D. Gain of function mutation: Incorrect. The expanded CGG repeats in Fragile X syndrome lead to hypermethylation and silencing of the FMR1 gene, resulting in a loss of function, not a gain of function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that Fragile X syndrome is caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to hypermethylation and gene silencing. 
  • It predominantly affects males, with IQ typically in the range of 20–40, and is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. 
  • Differentiate it from other trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington’s disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent, inflammatory dermal and subcutaneous infections characterized by granulomatous nodules on her legs. She has a history of minor trauma to the area while gardening. A fungal culture grows a dermatophyte known to cause deep dermal infections when introduced via cutaneous injury. Given her clinical presentation, which dermatophyte is most commonly associated with this type of granulomatous infection, often referred to as Majocchi's granuloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichophyton rubrum

 

  • Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of Majocchi's granuloma, a deep fungal infection of the skin that can occur when dermatophytes are introduced into the dermis, often through a minor injury.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton is a genus of dermatophytes but is less commonly associated with Majocchi's granuloma.

 

 

Option C. Microsporum canis: Microsporum canis primarily causes tinea capitis and is a less common cause of Majocchi's granuloma.

 

 

Option D. Trichophyton mentagrophytes: Trichophyton mentagrophytes can cause Majocchi's granuloma, but it is not as commonly associated with it as Trichophyton rubrum.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the intestine

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with hyperlipidemia is prescribed a statin for cholesterol management. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which statins reduce LDL cholesterol levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase

 

  • Statins work primarily by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the key enzyme responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol in the liver. 
  • This inhibition leads to a decrease in the production of cholesterol. 
  • As a result, the liver compensates by increasing the synthesis of LDL receptors on its surface, which in turn enhances the clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream, thereby lowering circulating LDL levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of LDL receptor activity: This is incorrect. Statins actually increase the synthesis and activity of LDL receptors in the liver to enhance the clearance of LDL from the blood.

 

Option C. Activation of PPAR-α receptors: This is a mechanism associated with fibrates, not statins. PPAR-α activation increases the breakdown of triglycerides but does not directly reduce LDL cholesterol.

 

Option D. Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the intestine: This mechanism is associated with ezetimibe, a drug that reduces cholesterol absorption in the gut, not statins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Statins lower LDL cholesterol primarily by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, leading to a reduction in cholesterol production and an increase in LDL receptor synthesis, which enhances LDL clearance from the bloodstream.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neer classification grade 4

 

IMPORTANT CLASSIFICATIONS OF VARIOUS FRACTURES

 

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
  • One-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
    • No or minimal displacement (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
    • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures and are almost always treated conservatively.

 

 

  • Two-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
    • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • Four possible types of two-part fractures are: 
      1. Surgical neck: most common
      2. Greater tuberosity
        • Frequently seen in anterior shoulder dislocation
        • A lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm) 
      3. Anatomical neck
      4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
    • These fractures account for approximately 20% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Three-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
    • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • 2 three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
      1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface which remain together – most common pattern
      2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface which remain together
    • These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Four-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
    • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th. 
    • These fractures are uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures).
    • This pattern has poor non-operative results as the articular surface is no longer attached to any parts of the humerus. This pattern has a high incidence of osteonecrosis. These fractures require operative management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4: This system is used to classify the scapular fractures. 

 

 

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3: The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures is the most widely used. It predicts the development of osteonecrosis. 

 

 

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5: This is used to classify tibial plateau fracture. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the grade 4 of the Neer’s classification of the proximal humerus fracture where all the fractured parts of the humerus are displaced.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain during walking. An X-ray of the knee reveals a lytic lesion located at the upper end of the fibula, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Osteoclastoma, also known as giant cell tumor of bone, is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor that primarily affects young adults (20–40 years). 
  • It typically arises in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones, particularly the distal femur, proximal tibia, and the upper end of the fibula. 
  • On radiographic imaging, it appears as a lytic, eccentric lesion with a classic "soap bubble" appearance. 
  • Clinically, patients often present with pain, swelling, and restricted movement, as described here. 
  • The location at the upper end of the fibula and the lytic appearance make osteoclastoma the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor seen in adolescents and young adults. It typically involves the metaphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia) and appears as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion with periosteal reaction ("sunburst appearance"). The upper fibula involvement and purely lytic lesion make osteosarcoma less likely here.

 

Option C. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is a highly aggressive malignant bone tumor seen in children and adolescents. It typically involves the diaphysis of long bones and has a characteristic "onion skin" periosteal reaction on X-ray. This presentation does not fit the upper fibular location or the purely lytic lesion seen here.

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma: Chondroblastoma is a benign bone tumor arising in the epiphysis of long bones, commonly affecting the proximal humerus or distal femur in adolescents. Although it can be lytic, it is less common in the fibula compared to osteoclastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor) typically presents as a lytic, eccentric lesion in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones in young adults, often involving the upper fibula. 
  • It has a characteristic "soap bubble" appearance on X-ray.

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman is prescribed a medication to help manage her symptoms of menopause, such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Additionally, the drug also has effects on osteoporosis and endometrial health. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibolone

 

  • Tibolone is a synthetic steroid with estrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic properties, making it effective in treating menopausal symptoms. 
  • It helps to alleviate vasomotor symptoms like hot flashes, improve vaginal dryness, and prevent osteoporosis. 
  • In addition, tibolone has a neutral effect on the endometrium, reducing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia compared to other hormone therapies. 
  • Tibolone is unique in that it is often used for both menopausal symptom management and bone protection in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a synthetic progestin used in hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in combination with estrogens. While it helps with endometrial protection in women with an intact uterus, it does not have the androgenic properties that tibolone possesses. It is not typically used for managing osteoporosis directly.

 

Option C. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are commonly used for menopausal symptoms like hot flashes and vaginal dryness, but they do not provide the progestogenic and androgenic effects of tibolone. Progestogens are usually required for women with an intact uterus to prevent endometrial hyperplasia when using estrogen alone.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to prevent and treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. It is not effective in managing menopausal symptoms like hot flashes and vaginal dryness and does not have progestogenic or androgenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tibolone is a synthetic steroid with estrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic properties that is used in the management of menopausal symptoms, osteoporosis, and offers a protective effect on the endometrium.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with erythematous, shallow erosions accompanied by blisters and yellowish scales, localized to seborrheic regions such as the face, chest, and upper back. There is no involvement of the oral mucosa. A skin biopsy with immunopathology reveals IgG deposition on keratinocytes. Autoantibodies against desmoglein-1 (Dsg-1) are identified. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus foliaceus

 

  • Pemphigus foliaceus is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder caused by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein-1 (Dsg-1), a desmosomal protein responsible for cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis. 
  • Clinically, it presents with erythematous patches, shallow erosions, and scaling in seborrheic areas such as the face, scalp, chest, and back, without mucosal involvement (e.g., oral ulcers), which distinguishes it from pemphigus vulgaris. 
  • Immunopathology reveals IgG deposition on keratinocytes, consistent with the diagnosis. 
  • The disease mechanism involves the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes (acantholysis) in the superficial epidermis, leading to superficial blistering and erosion, particularly in seborrheic regions. 
  • These findings, including the absence of mucosal involvement and the presence of autoantibodies against Dsg-1, confirm pemphigus foliaceus as the most likely diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Presents with pruritic vesicles or papules on extensor surfaces. IgA deposition (not IgG) in derma papillary tips and gluten sensitivity are characteristic, unlike this case.

 

Option C. Bullous pemphigoid: Features tense, subepidermal blisters and IgG deposition at the basement membrane, not keratinocytes. Mucosal involvement is rare.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by Staphylococcus aureus toxins, seen in children or immunocompromised adults. Lacks autoimmune features or IgG involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus foliaceus is an autoimmune blistering disease caused by IgG autoantibodies targeting desmoglein-1 (Dsg-1), resulting in superficial skin erosions and scaling in seborrheic areas without mucosal involvement.

choices.text: Decrease in IgG and increase in IgM
Total lack of natural killer cells
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and lymphadenopathy. Flow cytometry shows an absence of CD40 ligand interaction in B cells. Which of the following immunological abnormalities best explains this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in IgG and increase in IgM

 

  • The absence of CD40 or its ligand (CD40L) on T cells causes a condition known as Hyper-IgM syndrome, specifically the X-linked form. 
  • CD40-CD40L interaction is essential for class switching in B cells, a process that allows immunoglobulin production to transition from IgM to IgG, IgA, or IgE.
  • In patients with this defect:
    • B cells can only produce IgM (the default antibody).
    • Class switching to other immunoglobulin types (IgG, IgA, and IgE) cannot occur, resulting in low levels of these immunoglobulins.
    • The patient is more susceptible to recurrent bacterial infections, particularly those caused by encapsulated organisms.
  • Thus, decreased IgG with increased IgM is the hallmark immunological abnormality associated with CD40 or CD40L deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Total lack of natural killer cells: Natural killer (NK) cells are part of the innate immune system and are not affected by CD40-CD40L interactions. NK cell deficiencies are associated with viral infections and conditions like Chediak-Higashi syndrome or rare congenital disorders.

 

Option C. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: Neutrophil dysfunction occurs in disorders like Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) or leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which are unrelated to CD40 signaling. These conditions lead to recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Lack of CD8-mediated cytotoxicity: CD8 T cells are responsible for killing virus-infected or malignant cells. Defects in CD8 cytotoxicity occur in conditions like MHC Class I deficiencies or T-cell-specific disorders. These processes do not involve CD40-CD40L interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The absence of CD40-CD40L interaction impairs immunoglobulin class switching, resulting in Hyper-IgM syndrome. 
  • This condition is characterized by elevated IgM levels and low IgG, IgA, and IgE, leading to recurrent bacterial infections.

choices.text: It is the most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands
Core biopsy is needed for diagnosis
It can be treated by enucleation

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of a slow-growing painless swelling on the right side of her mouth for the past 2 years. The swelling is lobular and non-tender. Investigations of the swelling reveal a pleomorphic adenoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands 

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumor, accounting for a significant percentage of all such neoplasms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It never undergoes malignant transformation: This statement is incorrect. Pleomorphic adenoma can undergo malignant transformation, although this is considered rare. The risk of transformation increases with the duration the tumor is present.

 

Option C. Core biopsy is needed for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a core biopsy can provide a diagnosis, fine needle aspiration (FNA) is often the first-line approach for the evaluation of salivary gland masses due to its simplicity and lower risk of complications. Core biopsy may lead to seeding the biopsy tract with tumor cells and is avoided.

 

Option D. It can be treated by enucleation: This statement is incorrect. Enucleation, or simple removal of the tumor without removing surrounding normal tissue, is not recommended for pleomorphic adenoma due to the risk of recurrence and potential for tumor spillage. The tumor shows extensions (pseudopodia) which may be left behind if enucleation is done.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands and should be treated with complete surgical excision (superficial parotidectomy) rather than enucleation to minimize the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient with a family history of allergies presents with a rapidly developing erythematous rash involving the flexural areas of the knees and wrists. Histopathological examination of the skin reveals the presence of spongiosis. Which of the following best describes spongiosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercellular edema

 

  • Spongiosis is characterized by intercellular edema in the epidermis, where fluid accumulates between keratinocytes, causing stretching of desmosomal connections and widening of intercellular spaces. 
  • This histopathological finding is typical of eczematous dermatitis, which aligns with the patient’s presentation of a rapidly evolving rash in flexural areas and a family history of allergies, commonly seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypergranulosis: Hypergranulosis refers to the thickening of the stratum granulosum, often seen in conditions like lichen planus. This does not describe the fluid accumulation seen in spongiosis.

 

Option C. Subepidermal blister formation: Subepidermal blistering is characteristic of conditions such as bullous pemphigoid, where blisters form below the epidermis. Spongiosis involves intercellular changes within the epidermis, not blister formation.

 

Option D. Thickening of the basement membrane: Thickened basement membranes are associated with conditions like lupus erythematosus or diabetic dermopathy. This is unrelated to the intercellular edema described in spongiosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spongiosis refers to intercellular edema of the epidermis, a hallmark feature of eczematous dermatitis, including atopic dermatitis. It represents fluid accumulation between keratinocytes due to inflammation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by parents who report that during the recent fever episode, the child experienced a convulsion. The seizure involved generalized shaking. The parents are concerned about the nature of the seizure and seek clarification from the healthcare team. How is this febrile seizure best classified based on its duration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lasting more than 15 minutes

 

  • Febrile seizures are categorized into simple and complex types based on specific clinical features. A complex febrile seizure is defined by one or more of the following criteria:
    • Duration exceeding 15 minutes
    • Focal onset, meaning the seizure affects only one part of the body
    • Recurrence within 24 hours of the initial seizure
  • In this scenario, the child experienced a seizure lasting approximately 18 minutes, which exceeds the 15-minute threshold, thereby classifying it as a complex febrile seizure. 
  • Recognizing the duration is crucial as complex febrile seizures may require more thorough evaluation to rule out underlying neurological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lasting more than 5 minutes: While seizures lasting more than 5 minutes are concerning and warrant medical attention, this duration alone does not specifically classify a febrile seizure as complex. Simple febrile seizures typically last less than 15 minutes.

 

Option B. Lasting more than 10 minutes: Similar to option A, a seizure lasting more than 10 minutes is prolonged but does not meet the threshold for a complex classification. The 15-minute mark is the established cutoff for differentiating complex febrile seizures.

 

Option D. Lasting more than 20 minutes: Seizures lasting more than 20 minutes are considered prolonged and may fall under the category of status epilepticus, a medical emergency. However, for the classification of complex febrile seizures, the critical duration is over 15 minutes, making this option less precise in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the classification of febrile seizures is essential for appropriate clinical management. 
  • Recognizing that seizures lasting more than 15 minutes, having a focal onset, or recurring within 24 hours are classified as complex febrile seizures helps healthcare providers determine the need for further evaluation and intervention to ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past two days. Her blood pressure is 200/160 mmHg, and laboratory findings reveal a serum creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL. A renal biopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following underlying diseases is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffuse scleroderma

 

  • The renal biopsy demonstrates onion-skinning or hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, which is a hallmark of malignant hypertension. 
  • This vascular lesion results from severe and sustained hypertension causing concentric lamellar thickening of arteriolar walls, leading to narrowing of the lumen.

 

In this patient, the combination of:

  • Severe hypertension (BP of 210/160 mm Hg),
  • Acute kidney injury (serum creatinine 3.8 mg/dL), and
  • A vascular lesion typical of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis

 

It strongly suggests scleroderma renal crisis as the underlying cause. 

 

Diffuse scleroderma (systemic sclerosis) is associated with this life-threatening complication, characterized by:

 

  • Malignant hypertension,
  • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, and
  • Acute renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries. It can cause renal involvement but typically presents with renal infarctions and ischemic damage, not onion-skinning lesions. PAN is also not associated with malignant hypertension.

 

Option C. Malignant pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that causes episodic hypertension, headache, sweating, and tachycardia. While pheochromocytoma can cause severe hypertension, it does not produce onion-skinning of renal arterioles, as seen in scleroderma renal crisis.

 

Option D. Takayasu arteritis: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis affecting the aorta and its major branches. It causes pulseless disease and renovascular hypertension due to renal artery stenosis, but it does not cause the hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis seen in this biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scleroderma renal crisis, associated with diffuse scleroderma, leads to malignant hypertension and hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (onion-skinning of renal arterioles). 
  • This results in acute kidney injury, headache, and hypertensive emergencies.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath (SOB) on exertion. On examination, crackles are heard at the lung bases, and a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur is detected, loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Water hammer pulse

 

  • The clinical presentation and the early diastolic murmur suggest aortic regurgitation (AR). 
  • A water hammer pulse (Corrigan pulse) is a hallmark physical finding in AR, characterized by a rapid and forceful upstroke of the pulse followed by a quick collapse. 
  • This occurs due to the regurgitant flow of blood back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus parvus et tardus: This is seen in aortic stenosis, characterized by a slow-rising and weak pulse, which does not fit the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Pulsus paradoxus: This is associated with conditions like cardiac tamponade or severe obstructive lung disease, not aortic regurgitation.

 

Option C. Fixed splitting of S2: This is a feature of atrial septal defect (ASD) and does not correlate with the murmur and symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortic regurgitation is characterized by an early diastolic murmur and findings such as a water hammer pulse due to rapid systolic ejection and diastolic regurgitation of blood.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Curve-bladed Mayo scissors

 

  • The instrument shown is curve-bladed Mayo scissors, which are designed for cutting thick, dense tissues such as the uterus, rectus sheath, and fascia during surgical procedures. 
  • Their curved design allows for precise cutting in deep and confined areas, making them ideal for surgeries requiring access to deeper tissue layers. 
  • They are commonly used in abdominal surgeries and cesarean sections where sturdy, controlled cutting is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mosquito forceps: Mosquito forceps are small hemostatic clamps used to clamp small blood vessels. They do not have cutting blades and are not designed for tissue dissection or cutting.

 

Option B. Curved artery forceps: Curved artery forceps are used for clamping vessels and tissues to control bleeding. They are not cutting instruments and lack the blades seen in Mayo scissors.

 

Option D. Episiotomy scissors: Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed for cutting perineal tissue during childbirth. While they have angled blades, they are not sturdy enough for cutting thicker structures like the uterus or fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Curve-bladed Mayo scissors are surgical instruments designed for cutting thick tissues, such as the uterus, rectus sheath, and fascia, making them indispensable in general surgery, abdominal operations, and cesarean sections. 
  • Their robust build and curved design allow for precise and efficient cutting in deeper tissue planes.

questions.text: A patient had history of burns on the site shown in the image below, one year ago. He recently noticed a growth at the scar site. What is the like diagnosis of pathology shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Given image shows a growth in a burns scar tissue, suggestive of Marjolin’s ulcer.
  • Risk factors: Chronic wounds, burns scar
  • Biopsy: Squamous cell carcinoma

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Cock’s peculiar tumor: Ruptured sebaceous cyst on scalp

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: will present with discharging sinus usually on the neck.

 

Option D. Chronic osteomyelitis: Discharging sinus with bony spicules

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Marjolin ulcer is a type of squamous cell CA seen in long standing wounds and burn scar.

choices.text: Retrograde blood flow in the vertebral artery due to subclavian artery stenosis
Aneurysmal dilation of the subclavian artery compressing the vertebral artery
Congenital hypoplasia of the subclavian artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with dizziness and occasional episodes of syncope when performing activities involving his left arm, such as lifting heavy objects. He also reports intermittent claudication of the left arm. On examination, his left radial pulse is diminished, and his left brachial systolic blood pressure is 20 mm Hg lower than the right. A bruit is heard over the left subclavian artery. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retrograde blood flow in the vertebral artery due to subclavian artery stenosis

 

  • Subclavian steal syndrome occurs due to significant stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery. 
  • When the affected arm is used, blood flow is "stolen" from the vertebral artery via retrograde flow to supply the arm, leading to symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency such as dizziness or syncope and arm claudication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aneurysmal dilation of the subclavian artery compressing the vertebral artery: This is not a mechanism of subclavian steal syndrome. Aneurysms may cause other symptoms, such as compressive effects or embolism.

 

Option C. Congenital hypoplasia of the subclavian artery: While rare, congenital hypoplasia typically does not cause subclavian steal syndrome symptoms.

 

Option D. Vasculitis involving the subclavian artery: Though vasculitis (e.g., Takayasu arteritis) can cause stenosis, the hallmark feature of subclavian steal syndrome is retrograde flow in the vertebral artery, irrespective of the underlying cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by retrograde blood flow in the vertebral artery due to proximal subclavian artery stenosis, leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency and arm ischemia during exertion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is scheduled for elective surgery and requires a blood transfusion. To ensure the availability of compatible blood, the blood bank staff selects a preservative solution that can maintain red blood cell viability for up to 35 days. Which of the following preservative solutions is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine-1 (CPDA-1)

 

  • Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine-1 (CPDA-1) is the most appropriate preservative solution for storing red blood cells for up to 35 days. 
  • CPDA-1 contains:
    1. Citrate: Prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    2. Phosphate: Maintains the pH and supports energy production.
    3. Dextrose: Provides glucose as an energy source for red blood cells.
    4. Adenine: Increases ATP production, which helps preserve red cell viability and improves oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • This solution extends the shelf life of stored blood, making it ideal for maintaining cellular metabolism and viability for transfusion purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium Citrate: Sodium citrate acts as an anticoagulant by chelating calcium and is commonly used in short-term blood samples or for coagulation testing. It does not contain components like adenine or dextrose needed to maintain red blood cell metabolism and viability.

 

Option C. Lithium Heparin: Lithium heparin is used as an anticoagulant in laboratory blood samples for biochemical analysis. It is not used for blood storage, as it does not preserve red blood cell metabolism or viability.

 

Option D. Citrate Phosphate Double Dextrose (CP2D): CP2D allows for blood storage for approximately 21-28 days. While it includes citrate and dextrose, it lacks adenine, which limits the shelf life compared to CPDA-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine-1 (CPDA-1) is the preservative solution of choice for storing red blood cells for up to 35 days. 
  • It contains adenine, which enhances ATP production, prolonging red cell survival and oxygen-carrying capacity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and is started on chemotherapy, including cisplatin. During her treatment, she develops severe mucositis and xerostomia. Which of the following agents would most effectively prevent or reduce these side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amifostine

 

  • Amifostine is a radioprotective agent and chemoprotectant used to reduce the incidence of xerostomia (dry mouth) and protect against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and radiation-induced toxicity. 
  • It works by scavenging free radicals and preventing damage to normal tissues. 
  • It is particularly beneficial for patients undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin, which is known for its nephrotoxicity and potential for causing mucositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palifermin: Palifermin is a keratinocyte growth factor used to reduce mucositis after chemotherapy, especially in patients receiving high-dose chemotherapy for hematologic malignancies. It is not effective for cisplatin-induced xerostomia or nephrotoxicity.

 

Option C. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is used to rescue normal cells from the toxic effects of methotrexate (high-dose), not for protecting against the effects of cisplatin or xerostomia.

 

Option D. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 antagonist used for the prevention of nausea and vomiting due to chemotherapy, but it does not help with mucositis or xerostomia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amifostine is used to prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and mucositis, as well as xerostomia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with end-stage renal disease has been on long-term hemodialysis for the past 10 years. He presents with joint pain, carpal tunnel syndrome, and symptoms of chronic musculoskeletal discomfort. Imaging and biopsy show evidence of amyloid deposition. Which of the following types of amyloidosis is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

 

  • In patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis, β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) amyloidosis is the most likely type to develop. 
  • β2 microglobulin is a component of MHC class I molecules and is normally cleared by the kidneys.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, β2 microglobulin accumulates in the blood because it cannot be adequately filtered.
  • Over time, the high circulating levels of β2 microglobulin lead to amyloid fibril deposition in tissues, particularly in:
    • Joints and tendons (causing carpal tunnel syndrome, joint pain, and stiffness)
    • Bones and soft tissues
  • This condition is called dialysis-related amyloidosis and is a common complication of chronic hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amyloid light chain (AL): AL amyloidosis is caused by the deposition of immunoglobulin light chains (usually lambda) and is associated with plasma cell dyscrasias (e.g., multiple myeloma). It is not related to hemodialysis or chronic renal failure.

 

Option C. Amyloid associated protein (AA): AA amyloidosis results from chronic inflammatory states, such as rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, or inflammatory bowel disease. The precursor protein is serum amyloid A (SAA), and deposition typically occurs in the kidneys, liver, and spleen.

 

Option D. Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR): ATTR amyloidosis is due to the misfolding of transthyretin, a protein involved in transporting thyroxine and retinol. It can be hereditary (mutant TTR) or age-related (wild-type TTR) and primarily affects the heart and peripheral nerves, not patients undergoing dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dialysis-related amyloidosis occurs due to the accumulation and deposition of β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) in tissues in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis. 
  • It commonly presents with carpal tunnel syndrome and joint involvement.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length Pair Technique

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most appropriate for quantitative analysis of the viral RNA genome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR

 

  • For quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, the gold standard method is RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR, which combines:
    1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Converts viral RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase.
    2. Real-time PCR: Amplifies the cDNA and measures the viral load in real time using fluorescence, enabling precise quantification of the RNA genome.
  • This combination is sensitive, specific, and widely used in clinical settings for RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2, HCV, and HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nested PCR: Nested PCR is a two-step DNA amplification process used to improve specificity and sensitivity for DNA targets. It is not suitable for RNA quantification, as it does not include a reverse transcription step.

 

Option C. Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length Pair Technique: This technique amplifies DNA and analyzes restriction sites, but it is not quantitative and cannot detect RNA directly.

 

Option D. Quantitative PCR (qPCR): While qPCR can quantify DNA, it cannot analyze RNA genomes directly without a preceding reverse transcription step to convert RNA into cDNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes is RT-PCR followed by Real-time PCR, which combines reverse transcription to convert RNA into cDNA and real-time fluorescence-based quantification during amplification.

choices.text: Nomadic sites like brick kilns and construction sites
Villages with a population size of <500
High-risk areas such as forested regions and hilly areas

questions.text: The Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) aims to address immunization gaps in specific populations. Which of the following areas was specifically not identified as a priority for immunization under IMI?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Villages with a population size of <500

 

  • The Intensified Mission Indradhanush focuses on areas with low immunization coverage due to factors like migration, high-risk populations, and hard-to-reach communities. 
  • While urban slums, nomadic sites, and forested or hilly areas are targeted due to difficult access or high vulnerability, villages with a population size of <500 are generally not singled out unless other factors like poor immunization coverage or outbreaks are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urban slums with migratory populations: Migrant populations in urban slums are one of the primary targets, as these populations are often missed due to mobility and social factors.

 

Option B. Nomadic sites like brick kilns and construction sites: Nomadic populations, especially in areas like brick kilns and construction sites, are another high-risk group targeted under IMI due to their constant mobility.

 

Option D. High-risk areas such as forested and hilly regions: These hard-to-reach areas are targeted under IMI because they often have low immunization coverage due to geographical barriers and logistical challenges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) prioritizes areas with low immunization coverage, including migrant populations, nomadic sites, and high-risk areas, while areas like small villages are not prioritized unless specific gaps in coverage exist.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents to the clinic with a pruritic rash that started as maculopapular lesions and progressed to vesicles. She reports recent exposure to a child with chickenpox. Laboratory tests confirm varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection. The patient is concerned about the risk of transmission to the fetus. At which period of gestation is the highest risk of transmission of varicella to the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14–18 weeks

 

  • The highest risk of congenital varicella syndrome (CVS) occurs between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation, with an estimated risk of transmission of ~2%. 
  • This is due to the active development of fetal organ systems during this period. 
  • CVS includes limb hypoplasia, cutaneous scarring, chorioretinitis, and neurological abnormalities. 
  • The risk before 13 weeks is lower (~0.4%), and cases after 20 weeks are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 8–12 weeks: Incorrect. The risk of CVS is lower during the first trimester (~0.4%).

 

Option C. 34–37 weeks: Incorrect. Varicella infection during late pregnancy rarely causes CVS but may lead to neonatal varicella if the mother develops the rash shortly before delivery.

 

Option D. 28–32 weeks: Incorrect. The risk of CVS during this period is minimal, as it primarily occurs between 13 and 20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital varicella syndrome is most likely to occur when maternal varicella infection happens between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation, with the highest risk during this window. 
  • Understanding the timing of fetal susceptibility helps guide counseling and management for pregnant women with varicella.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes a posterolateral thoracotomy for surgical management of a lung mass. During the procedure, specific muscles are incised to gain access to the thoracic cavity. The surgeon avoids cutting one of the following muscles during the approach. Which of the following muscles is not cut in a posterolateral thoracotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pectoralis major

 

  • In a posterolateral thoracotomy, an incision is made along the posterior and lateral chest wall to provide access to the thoracic cavity. During this procedure:
    1. The latissimus dorsi is often incised or retracted as part of the approach.
    2. The serratus anterior may be divided along its fibers to allow the surgeon to expose the ribs.
    3. The intercostal muscles (between the ribs) are also incised to enter the thoracic cavity.
  • However, the pectoralis major muscle is located anteriorly on the chest wall and does not lie within the incision line of a posterolateral thoracotomy. Therefore, it is not cut during the procedure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latissimus dorsi: The latissimus dorsi is a broad, superficial muscle of the back that must be incised or retracted during a posterolateral thoracotomy to gain access to the thoracic cavity.

 

Option B. Intercostals: The intercostal muscles, which lie between adjacent ribs, are always incised to allow entry into the thoracic cavity.

 

Option C. Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle, located on the lateral chest wall, is often divided or retracted during a posterolateral thoracotomy to provide exposure to the ribs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During a posterolateral thoracotomy, the pectoralis major is not cut because it is located anteriorly on the chest wall and is not involved in the surgical approach. 
  • The muscles typically incised include the latissimus dorsi, serratus anterior, and intercostal muscles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a history of fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He recently travelled to Bangladesh and consumed undercooked pork. On examination, he has periorbital edema and muscle pain. A biopsy reveals larvae encysted in the muscle tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichinellosis

 

  • Trichinellosis, also known as Trichinella spiralis infection, is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. 
  • The clinical presentation of fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, periorbital edema, and muscle pain, along with the muscle biopsy showing encysted larvae, is characteristic of Trichinella infection.
  • Trichinellosis is transmitted by consuming undercooked pork or wild game (e.g., wild boar), which is common in Southeast Asia. 
  • The larvae of Trichinella spiralis are ingested from contaminated meat and then migrate to the muscle, where they encyst. The periorbital edema is a classic sign seen in muscle involvement, which is common in this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cysticercosis: Incorrect. Cysticercosis, caused by the larval form of Taenia solium, can also cause muscle involvement, but it is typically associated with neurological symptoms (seizures, intracranial cysts) rather than the abdominal and muscular symptoms seen here. The history of undercooked pork consumption fits with the potential for Trichinellosis rather than cysticercosis.

 

Option C. Toxocariasis: Incorrect. Toxocariasis is caused by the larvae of Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati, typically affecting children and causing ocular or visceral larva migrans. The clinical presentation in this patient, including muscle pain and periorbital edema, is not typical for toxocariasis.

 

Option D. Echinococcosis: Incorrect. Echinococcosis, caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus, typically presents with cystic lesions in the liver or lungs, often leading to hydatid cysts. This patient's presentation of muscle pain and encysted larvae does not align with Echinococcosis, which is primarily a liver and lung infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichinellosis is caused by Trichinella spiralis, which is transmitted through undercooked pork or wild game. 
  • The classic presentation includes abdominal pain, diarrhea, muscle pain, periorbital edema, and encysted larvae in muscle tissue.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female comes with low back pain, following is seen on CT scan. Serum Calcium is 7mg/dL, ALP is elevated. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteomalacia

 

  • Osteomalacia is a disorder of bone mineralization due to vitamin D deficiency or impaired calcium and phosphate metabolism. This leads to softening of the bones, which causes bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures.
  • In osteomalacia, despite adequate bone matrix production, the bones do not mineralize properly due to a deficiency of calcium or phosphate, often linked to insufficient vitamin D.
  • Low serum calcium and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) are common in osteomalacia because the body increases bone turnover in response to low calcium levels. There is typically a compensatory increase in ALP as osteoblast activity rises.
  • CT may show bone thinning or fractures, particularly in the spine, pelvis, or legs. The softening of bone can lead to deformities and fractures even with minimal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteoporosis:

 

  • Osteoporosis is characterized by low bone density, which increases the risk of fractures. It is typically a silent condition without symptoms until fractures occur.
  • Osteoporosis usually does not cause changes in serum calcium levels or ALP unless there is a secondary cause. The hallmark of osteoporosis is low bone mineral density (BMD), which might be assessed using DEXA scans, not CT scans.
  • While osteoporosis is associated with bone fractures and back pain, osteomalacia is more likely in this case given the combination of low calcium and elevated ALP.

 

Option C. Potts spine (Tuberculosis of the Spine):

 

  • Pott’s spine refers to spinal tuberculosis caused by infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It typically presents with chronic back pain and neurological deficits due to destruction of the vertebral bodies.
  • In spinal tuberculosis, the serum calcium is typically normal or slightly low, and alkaline phosphatase may not be as elevated as in osteomalacia. The main diagnostic clue would be the presence of granulomas or destructive lesions in the spine on imaging.
  • While Pott’s spine can present with back pain and spinal abnormalities, it does not typically lead to elevated ALP or a low calcium unless there is concurrent secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. PIVD (Prolapsed Intervertebral Disc):

 

  • PIVD refers to a herniated disc, which can cause low back pain, particularly radiating pain in the legs (sciatica). It is usually a mechanical issue due to disc degeneration or trauma.
  • In PIVD, laboratory markers such as serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase would typically be normal. The main diagnostic approach would be MRI or CT to visualize the disc herniation and nerve root compression.
  • PIVD does not cause changes in serum calcium or ALP levels, so it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomalacia is the diagnosis based on low serum calcium, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and the clinical presentation of bone pain.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male fell from a significant height and landed with a sudden jerk to the neck. Post-injury, he developed a characteristic Policeman Tip Deformity.  Examination reveals weakness and abnormal positioning of the upper limb. Which of the following is not seen in the deformity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supination

 

  • Policeman Tip Deformity is characteristic of an upper brachial plexus injury, most commonly involving the C5 and C6 nerve roots. 
  • This injury results in paralysis of muscles supplied by the axillary, musculocutaneous, and suprascapular nerves, leading to the following characteristic features:
    1. Adduction of the shoulder: Due to paralysis of the deltoid (axillary nerve) and supraspinatus (suprascapular nerve), the arm hangs in adduction as the opposing pectoralis major pulls the arm medially.
    2. Extension of the elbow: The biceps brachii and brachialis (musculocutaneous nerve) are paralyzed, leaving the triceps (radial nerve) unopposed.
    3. Medial rotation of the shoulder: The infraspinatus and teres minor (suprascapular and axillary nerves) are paralyzed, leaving the subscapularis unopposed.
    4. Pronation of the forearm: Paralysis of the biceps brachii (musculocutaneous nerve) results in the inability to supinate the forearm, leading to unopposed pronation by the pronator muscles.
  • Supination, however, is not seen in this deformity due to paralysis of the biceps brachii, which is responsible for forearm supination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Policeman Tip Deformity (Erb-Duchenne palsy) results from an upper brachial plexus injury (C5-C6), leading to weakness in abductors, flexors, lateral rotators, and supinators of the upper limb. 
  • The deformity is characterized by adduction, extension, medial rotation, and pronation, with supination absent due to biceps brachii paralysis.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are known to decrease atrioventricular (AV) conduction, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lignocaine

 

  • Lignocaine (also known as lidocaine) is a Class 1b antiarrhythmic that works by blocking sodium channels. 
  • It is primarily used for ventricular arrhythmias and does not significantly affect AV conduction in the same manner as other drugs in this question. 
  • Instead, lignocaine has a local anesthetic effect and decreases depolarization in ventricular tissues.
  • It does not typically decrease AV conduction to the same extent as the other listed drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esmolol: Esmolol is a beta-blocker that decreases AV conduction by blocking β-adrenergic receptors in the heart, particularly in the atrioventricular node. This results in slower heart rate and reduced AV nodal conduction, which is useful in controlling ventricular rate in conditions like atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Option B. Digitalis: Digitalis (or digoxin) decreases AV conduction by increasing vagal tone. It works on the vagus nerve to enhance parasympathetic activity, leading to a reduction in AV node conduction. Digitalis is often used in atrial fibrillation to slow down the ventricular response by decreasing AV nodal conduction.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that decreases AV conduction by blocking the L-type calcium channels in the AV node. This slows down the atrial impulses from reaching the ventricles and is useful in controlling heart rate in conditions like atrial fibrillation and supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drugs that decrease AV conduction include beta-blockers (e.g., esmolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil), and digitalis. 
  • However, lignocaine (lidocaine) primarily affects ventricular conduction and does not significantly reduce AV conduction.

choices.text: Size of the ventricular septal defect (VSD)

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric cardiology clinic with noticeable bluish discoloration of the lips and fingertips, especially during feeding and crying. On examination, the child has a harsh systolic murmur best heard in the left upper sternal border. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of Tetralogy of Fallot. The pediatric cardiologist aims to assess the severity of the infant's cyanosis to guide further management. Which of the following factors is the best determinant of the severity of cyanosis in Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Degree of pulmonary stenosis

 

  • In Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the severity of cyanosis is primarily determined by the degree of pulmonary stenosis. 
  • Pulmonary stenosis refers to the obstruction of blood flow from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery. 
  • A higher degree of obstruction increases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the ventricular septal defect (VSD), leading to more deoxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation and thus more pronounced cyanosis. 
  • Therefore, the degree of pulmonary stenosis is the most significant factor in determining the severity of cyanosis in TOF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size of the ventricular septal defect (VSD): While the size of the VSD affects the amount of shunting, its impact on cyanosis is modulated by the degree of pulmonary stenosis. A large VSD with mild pulmonary stenosis may result in less cyanosis compared to a smaller VSD with severe pulmonary stenosis.

 

Option B. Overriding of the aorta: Overriding of the aorta means that the aorta is positioned directly above the VSD, receiving blood from both the right and left ventricles. While this contributes to the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, it is not the primary determinant of cyanosis severity.

 

Option C. Degree of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH): RVH is a compensatory response to the increased workload from pumping against the obstruction caused by pulmonary stenosis. Although it is an important feature of TOF, it does not directly determine the level of cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the pathophysiological factors that influence cyanosis severity in Tetralogy of Fallot is crucial for accurate assessment and management. 
  • Recognizing that the degree of pulmonary stenosis is the primary determinant of cyanosis helps clinicians prioritize interventions aimed at relieving right ventricular outflow tract obstruction to improve oxygenation in affected infants and children.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with excruciating, recurrent headaches that have occurred nightly for the past 3 weeks. The headaches last 30–90 minutes, are severe, and are located behind his left eye. He describes associated symptoms of left-sided nasal congestion, lacrimation, and ptosis. MRI of the brain is unremarkable. He is diagnosed with episodic cluster headaches. The patient was started on verapamil for preventive therapy but reports no reduction in the frequency of his headaches. Oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan have been effective for aborting acute attacks, but he seeks an alternative preventive therapy. Which of the following treatments would be most appropriate for prevention in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galcanezumab

 

  • Galcanezumab is a CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) monoclonal antibody approved by the FDA for the prevention of episodic cluster headaches. 
  • It is administered as a monthly subcutaneous injection and has been shown to significantly reduce the frequency of cluster headache attacks, especially in patients unresponsive to traditional therapies like verapamil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Typically used for chronic cluster headache prevention, lithium is less effective for episodic cluster headaches.

 

Option C. Topiramate: Commonly used for migraine prophylaxis, it is not specifically approved or effective for cluster headache prevention.

 

Option D. Propranolol: While effective for migraine prevention, propranolol is not indicated for cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with episodic cluster headaches who do not respond to verapamil, galcanezumab is a safe and effective alternative for preventive therapy. 
  • It represents a modern approach targeting the underlying CGRP pathway in cluster headache pathophysiology.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal mass measuring 2.5 cm x 3 cm. Biopsy of the lesion reveals colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hamartoma

 

  • A hamartoma is a benign, disorganized overgrowth of tissues that are normally found at the site where the lesion occurs. In this case:
    1. The biopsy findings of colonic mucosa with dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells are classic for a hamartomatous polyp.
