    2. These features are commonly seen in juvenile polyps, which occur in young children and are the most frequent type of rectal polyp in this age group.
    3. Juvenile polyps are non-neoplastic and are often found in children under 5 years of age presenting with rectal bleeding or a palpable mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperplastic polyp: Hyperplastic polyps are benign proliferations of the colonic epithelium that occur in adults, not children. They are characterized by serrated glands without significant mucin accumulation or inflammatory cells and do not present as large masses.

 

Option C. Inflammatory polyp: Inflammatory polyps are associated with chronic inflammation, such as in ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease. Although inflammatory cells may be present, they typically lack the dilated glands and mucin-filled spaces seen in juvenile polyps.

 

Option D. Choristoma: A choristoma is a benign mass of normal tissue in an abnormal location (e.g., gastric tissue in the colon). In this case, the biopsy findings describe colonic mucosa located in the rectum, which is a normal location, so this is not a choristoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A hamartoma is a benign lesion composed of disorganized but normal tissue components found at their usual location. 
  • In children, juvenile polyps are the most common type of hamartoma and present with dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with suspected protein abnormalities undergoes a biochemical workup. The laboratory technician performs a test using Millon’s reagent to detect the presence of a specific amino acid in the protein. Which of the following amino acids is identified by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tyrosine

 

  • Millon’s test is a specific test used to detect tyrosine in proteins. 
  • Tyrosine contains a phenolic hydroxyl group, which reacts with mercuric nitrate in Millon’s reagent under acidic conditions to form a characteristic red-colored complex. 
  • This reaction is unique to tyrosine because of its phenolic group and is used to differentiate tyrosine-containing proteins from other amino acids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is detected using tests like the Aldehyde test or Hopkins-Cole test, which identify its indole ring structure. It does not react with Millon’s reagent.

 

Option C. Proline: Proline, being an imino acid, does not react with Millon’s reagent. It is often identified through its unique structural properties in other biochemical tests.

 

Option D. Glycine: Glycine lacks the phenolic group required for Millon’s test. It can be detected by the Ninhydrin test, which identifies free amino groups.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Millon’s test is a specific biochemical test that identifies tyrosine in proteins. 
  • The test relies on the reaction of tyrosine’s phenolic hydroxyl group with Millon’s reagent to produce a red-colored complex.

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer presents with a 3-month history of recurrent upper abdominal pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting. He also reports feeling fatigued and has unintentionally lost 10 pounds over the past month. He lives on a farm where he raises livestock and owns several dogs. A CT scan reveals multiple cystic masses in his liver. Laboratory tests show mild eosinophilia. Considering his occupational exposure and the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the adult parasite that causes his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dog’s intestine

 

  • The patient's history of farming, contact with dogs, and the presence of multiple cystic lesions in the liver, along with eosinophilia, is strongly suggestive of hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus granulosus. 
  • Echinococcus has a definitive host (the dog) and intermediate hosts (which include humans, sheep, and other herbivores). 
  • The adult tapeworms reside in the dog’s intestine, where they release eggs into the environment through the dog's feces. 
  • Humans acquire the infection by ingesting these eggs, which hatch in the intestines and release larvae that migrate to organs such as the liver, where they form cystic structures. 
  • The CT scan findings of cystic masses in the liver and the eosinophilia support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human's intestine: Humans are intermediate hosts for Echinococcus, not definitive hosts. The adult tapeworm does not reside in the human intestine. Instead, larvae form cysts in the liver, lungs, or other organs.

 

Option C. Human's liver: While humans can develop liver cysts due to Echinococcus larvae, the adult worms do not reside in the liver. The larvae develop into cysts in the liver, but the adult tapeworms live in the dog’s intestine.

 

Option D. Dog’s liver: The adult worms of Echinococcus are found in the dog’s intestine, not in the liver. Dogs become infected by consuming infected tissues containing the larvae, which then mature into adult tapeworms in their intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Echinococcus granulosus, the causative agent of hydatid disease, has adult tapeworms that reside in the dog’s intestine, where they release eggs that contaminate the environment. 
  • Humans, as intermediate hosts, ingest these eggs, leading to the formation of hydatid cysts, most commonly in the liver.

choices.text: Decreased activation of voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by a rescue team after being found nearly unconscious on a hill station. He had access to water but no food for 5 days. On presentation, the patient is severely shaking and disoriented, recognizing only familiar persons. His serum glucose concentration is 55 mg/dL. Which of the following is most likely occurring in this patient’s pancreatic islet β cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased activation of voltage-gated calcium channels

 

  • In the pancreatic islet β cells, insulin secretion is regulated by glucose metabolism. During fasting or hypoglycemia, low glucose levels result in:
    1. Decreased glucose uptake via GLUT2 transporters.
    2. Reduced ATP production from glycolysis and the Krebs cycle.
    3. Failure to close ATP-sensitive potassium K+ channels, leading to membrane hyperpolarization.
    4. Reduced activation of voltage-gated calcium channels, preventing calcium influx and subsequent insulin secretion.
  • This mechanism is a protective response during hypoglycemia to prevent further drops in blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased protein synthesis: Protein synthesis is decreased during fasting due to energy conservation, especially in a hypoglycemic state.

 

Option C. Voltage-gated calcium channels activation: This occurs during hyperglycemia when increased ATP closes K+ channels, depolarizing the membrane and activating calcium channels, leading to insulin release.

 

Option D. Downregulation of GLUT2 transporters: GLUT2 transporters are constitutively expressed in β cells and are not regulated in response to fasting or hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hypoglycemia, decreased activation of voltage-gated calcium channels in β cells prevents insulin release, conserving glucose levels to support vital organs like the brain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with urinary retention and difficulty voiding. Imaging and examination reveal no structural abnormalities, and neurological assessment identifies dysfunction in the sympathetic supply to the urinary bladder and the issue originates from the lumbar plexus. Which branches of the lumbar plexus supplying the urinary bladder cause this dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1 and L2

 

  • The urinary bladder receives sympathetic innervation from the lumbar splanchnic nerves, which originate from spinal segments L1 and L2 of the lumbar plexus. 
  • These sympathetic fibers act on the bladder by relaxing the detrusor muscle and contracting the internal urethral sphincter, allowing the bladder to fill and maintain continence. 
  • Dysfunction in these nerves can result in urinary retention or difficulty voiding, as described in this case.
  • While the parasympathetic innervation (which causes bladder contraction during voiding) originates from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), the lumbar plexus is specifically responsible for the sympathetic contribution through L1-L2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L3 and L4: L3 and L4 contribute to the femoral and obturator nerves, which provide motor and sensory innervation to the lower limb and thigh. They do not supply the urinary bladder.

 

Option B. L2 and L3: L2 may contribute partially to the sympathetic pathway, but L3 is not involved in bladder innervation.

 

Option D. L2, L3, and L4: While L2 is correct, L3 and L4 primarily innervate the lower limbs and do not provide sympathetic innervation to the urinary bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The urinary bladder receives sympathetic innervation from the lumbar splanchnic nerves arising from L1 and L2. 
  • These nerves relax the detrusor muscle and contract the internal urethral sphincter, facilitating bladder filling. 
  • Parasympathetic innervation comes from S2-S4 but is unrelated to the lumbar plexus.

choices.text: Gastric and esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with hepatitis C with a previous history of variceal bleeding is admitted to the hospital with hematemesis. His blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, physical examination reveals splenomegaly and ascites, and initial hematocrit is 25%. Prior to endoscopy, which of the following is the best initial management of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administration of intravenous octreotide

 

  • The patient has acute variceal bleeding, likely secondary to portal hypertension from chronic liver disease.
  • Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is used for the initial management of acute variceal bleeding. It acts by:
    1. Reducing splanchnic blood flow
    2. Lowering portal venous pressure, thereby decreasing bleeding from esophageal varices.
  • Octreotide is administered intravenously as soon as variceal bleeding is suspected, prior to endoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administration of propranolol:

 

  • Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker used for the prevention of variceal bleeding, not for acute management.
  • Beta-blockers are contraindicated in ongoing variceal hemorrhage as they may exacerbate hypotension.

 

Option C. Perform a hepatoportal venous Doppler:

 

  • While a Doppler ultrasound is useful for evaluating portal venous flow, it is not part of the acute management.
  • The priority in this case is to stabilize the patient and control bleeding.

 

Option D. Gastric and esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube):

 

  • Balloon tamponade is a temporary measure for refractory variceal bleeding when other interventions fail.
  • It is not the first-line treatment due to the risk of complications, such as esophageal rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with suspected acute variceal bleeding, immediate management includes:

 

  1. Stabilizing the patient with fluid resuscitation while avoiding hypervolemia.
  2. Initiating intravenous octreotide to reduce portal hypertension and control bleeding.
  3. Administering prophylactic antibiotics to reduce the risk of infections.
  4. Preparing for emergency endoscopy to perform band ligation or sclerotherapy.
     
  • Intravenous octreotide is the best initial step in managing acute variceal bleeding due to its splanchnic vasoconstrictive properties, which reduce portal pressure and bleeding risk.

questions.text: What is the most likely mode of inheritance in the below pedigree?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

  • In the given pedigree:
    1. The condition appears in every generation, which is characteristic of dominant inheritance.
    2. Both males and females are affected equally, indicating the condition is autosomal (not sex-linked).
    3. An affected individual typically transmits the condition to approximately 50% of their offspring, further supporting autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Autosomal dominant disorders are caused by a single mutant allele, and vertical transmission (across multiple generations) is a defining feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance typically skips generations, as affected individuals must inherit two copies of the mutant allele. In this pedigree, the condition is seen in every generation, making autosomal recessive inheritance unlikely.

 

Option C. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance refers to individuals carrying a dominant allele who do not express the disease phenotype. While incomplete penetrance can complicate autosomal dominant patterns, this pedigree shows clear expression in every generation, suggesting complete penetrance.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant: In X-linked dominant inheritance, affected mothers transmit the condition to 50% of their sons and daughters, while affected fathers pass the condition only to their daughters. This pedigree shows no such gender-based transmission, ruling out X-linked dominant inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by vertical transmission (occurs in every generation) and affects males and females equally. 
  • Each affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the condition to their offspring.

choices.text: Pericardial effusion with tamponade confirmed by echocardiography
Uniform QRS complex amplitude on ECG

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over the past week. On examination, his heart sounds are muffled, jugular venous pressure is elevated, and pulsus paradoxus is noted. An ECG shown Below. Which of the following is the most specific finding for diagnosing the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardial effusion with tamponade confirmed by echocardiography

 

  • Electrical alternans, characterized by beat-to-beat variability in the QRS complex amplitude and axis, is highly specific for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade. 
  • It occurs due to the swinging motion of the heart within a fluid-filled pericardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left ventricular hypertrophy on echocardiography: LV hypertrophy is not related to electrical alternans or pericardial effusion.

 

Option C. Normal-sized heart on chest X-ray: In tamponade or significant pericardial effusion, the heart typically appears enlarged on chest X-ray (water-bottle sign).

 

Option D. Uniform QRS complex amplitude on ECG: Electrical alternans specifically refers to variable QRS amplitude, and uniformity would contradict the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Electrical alternans is a hallmark ECG finding in large pericardial effusions with tamponade. 
  • Immediate echocardiography is essential to confirm the diagnosis and guide pericardiocentesis.

choices.text: Destruction of upper and lower motor neurons
Dilation of the central spinal canal

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents with dysphagia, hoarseness of voice, and progressive weakness in both arms over the past year. Examination reveals tongue atrophy, pooled oral secretions, diffuse muscle atrophy, and occasional fasciculations. Laboratory investigations are as follows:

 

 

What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Destruction of upper and lower motor neurons

 

  • The patient's symptoms of progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, and bulbar involvement (dysphagia, hoarseness, tongue atrophy) are characteristic of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). 
  • ALS involves the simultaneous destruction of upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN), leading to combined signs of spasticity (UMN) and atrophy/fasciculations (LMN). 
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) may reflect muscle breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of the central spinal canal: This would suggest syringomyelia, which causes cape-like sensory loss and LMN signs, not generalized UMN/LMN involvement.

 

Option C. Demyelination of peripheral nerves: This suggests Guillain-Barré syndrome or chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, which would not explain UMN signs or tongue atrophy.

 

Option D. Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors: This describes myasthenia gravis, which presents with fluctuating weakness but without muscle atrophy or fasciculations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by progressive UMN and LMN degeneration, leading to muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and bulbar symptoms. Elevated CK can be seen due to muscle wasting.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with chronic renal failure is admitted to the ICU. Due to prolonged hospitalization and malnutrition, he develops symptoms consistent with thiamine deficiency. Which of the following is the most accurate functional test to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC transketolase

 

  • Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a coenzyme for several critical enzymes, including transketolase, a key enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway. 
  • The most accurate functional assessment of thiamine deficiency involves measuring RBC transketolase activity before and after adding thiamine:
    • A significant increase in transketolase activity (>25%) after thiamine addition confirms B1 deficiency.
    • This functional test evaluates the physiological impact of thiamine deficiency on enzyme activity, making it more reliable than direct measurement of serum thiamine levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum lactate levels: Elevated lactate levels can indicate metabolic disturbances such as lactic acidosis due to pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency in severe thiamine deficiency. However, it is not a direct or specific test for thiamine status.

 

Option C. RBC glutathione reductase: This test assesses riboflavin (vitamin B2) status, not thiamine. Glutathione reductase activity depends on FAD, a riboflavin derivative.

 

Option D. Serum pyruvate levels: Pyruvate accumulation is seen in thiamine deficiency due to impaired pyruvate dehydrogenase activity. However, serum pyruvate measurement is nonspecific and does not directly assess thiamine status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • RBC transketolase activity is the most reliable functional test for diagnosing thiamine (B1) deficiency, as it directly measures the activity of a key thiamine-dependent enzyme.

choices.text: It is an amylin analog useful in diabetes mellitus.
It can be taken orally for convenience.
It is indicated for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist administered via subcutaneous injection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is started on liraglutide for better glucose control. Which of the following statements about liraglutide is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist administered via subcutaneous injection.

 

  • Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that mimics the natural hormone GLP-1, which stimulates insulin release in response to food intake. 
  • This action helps prevent postprandial hyperglycemia in type 2 diabetes mellitus. 
  • It is administered via subcutaneous injection once daily. 
  • It is not effective orally, and it is not approved for use in type 1 diabetes mellitus. 
  • Moreover, it is not an amylin analog, which has a different mechanism of action.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an amylin analog useful in diabetes mellitus: This is incorrect. Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, not an amylin analog. Amylin analogs, such as pramlintide, have a different mechanism.

 

Option B. It can be taken orally for convenience: This is incorrect. Liraglutide is not effective orally and must be administered via subcutaneous injection.

 

Option C. It is indicated for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. This is incorrect. Liraglutide is only approved for type 2 diabetes mellitus and is not recommended for type 1 diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, administered subcutaneously, and is indicated for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. 
  • It is not effective orally and is not approved for type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound is performed to assess her endometrial thickness. At what minimum endometrial thickness on ultrasound should an endometrial biopsy be considered to rule out malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 mm

 

  • In women with postmenopausal bleeding, an endometrial biopsy is indicated if the endometrial thickness exceeds 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound. 
  • A threshold of 4 mm has high sensitivity for detecting endometrial carcinoma or hyperplasia, which are key concerns in postmenopausal bleeding. 
  • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, the risk of malignancy is low, and other causes of bleeding may be explored.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In women with postmenopausal bleeding, an endometrial thickness >4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound is an indication for endometrial biopsy to evaluate for malignancy or hyperplasia. 
  • A thickness ≤4 mm is associated with a low risk of endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: A researcher is studying an infectious disease and attempts to estimate the incubation period based on various time intervals. Which of the following is not typically used as a proxy for the incubation period?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Period of communicability

 

  • The period of communicability refers to the time during which an infected individual is capable of transmitting the disease to others. 
  • While this is important for understanding disease spread, it is not a direct proxy for the incubation period, which is the time from exposure to the onset of symptoms. 
  • The incubation period typically describes the time between exposure to the infectious agent and the first appearance of symptoms, whereas the period of communicability focuses on transmissibility, which is a separate concept.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latent period: The latent period is often used as a proxy for the incubation period, especially in diseases where the person may not yet be infectious but symptoms have not yet appeared. The latent period begins at exposure and ends when the individual becomes infectious. Since this period overlaps with the incubation period, it is commonly used as a proxy.

 

Option C. Serial interval: The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in the primary case and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case. This interval is used as a proxy for the incubation period in diseases that spread from person to person, particularly in studies of transmission dynamics.

 

Option D. Generation time: The generation time refers to the time from the infection of a primary case to the infection of a secondary case. While it is not identical to the incubation period, the generation time can provide an estimate of how long it takes for the disease to spread from one person to another, making it a useful proxy in the study of infectious diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The period of communicability is not used as a proxy for the incubation period. Common proxy measures include the latent period, serial interval, and generation time.

questions.text: Which of the following mental health conditions is not specifically targeted in the mhGAP intervention guidelines for non-specialized health care providers in low- and middle-income countries?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autism Spectrum Disorders

 

  • The WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) aims to scale up care for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders in low- and middle-income countries. 
  • The focus is on conditions with a high burden of disease and those that can be effectively managed by non-specialized health care providers. These include:
    1. Depression
    2. Psychosis (including schizophrenia)
    3. Bipolar disorder
    4. Epilepsy
    5. Suicide prevention
    6. Dementia
    7. Alcohol and drug use disorders

  • While autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are important and recognized mental health concerns, they are not specifically included as a priority in the mhGAP guidelines due to limited interventions that can be feasibly implemented in resource-limited settings by non-specialized providers.

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia and Psychotic Disorders: Schizophrenia is a major focus of the mhGAP guidelines, as it represents a significant burden of disease and can be managed with antipsychotic medications and psychosocial support, even in low-resource settings.

 

Option C. Bipolar Disorder: Bipolar disorder is included in the mhGAP guidelines, with recommendations for mood stabilizers and psychoeducation for effective management.

 

Option D. Major Depressive Disorder: Depression is one of the most common conditions targeted by mhGAP, given its global prevalence and the availability of effective treatments like antidepressants and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mhGAP guidelines prioritize mental health conditions with high disease burden and feasible treatment options for non-specialized providers in resource-limited settings. 
  • Autism spectrum disorders are not included in the mhGAP priorities, highlighting the need for further research and tailored interventions for ASD in these regions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male reports to the trauma centre after a road traffic accident. Examination reveals pelvic trauma and a suspected injury to the membranous urethra. Where is urine most likely to collect in this scenario
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deep perineal pouch

 

  • The membranous urethra is the portion of the male urethra that passes through the deep perineal pouch, located between the perineal membrane and the pelvic diaphragm. 
  • It is susceptible to injury during trauma, especially in pelvic fractures.

When the membranous urethra is ruptured:

  • Urine and blood collect in the deep perineal pouch because this is the anatomic location of the injury.
  • The extravasated urine remains confined to this space unless the injury also involves surrounding structures.

The deep perineal pouch contains muscles like the external urethral sphincter and the deep transverse perineal muscle, and these boundaries restrict the initial spread of extravasation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peritoneal cavity: Urine does not collect in the peritoneal cavity because the membranous urethra is located extraperitoneally. The peritoneal cavity is only involved if there is a concomitant rupture of the bladder or other intraperitoneal organs.

 

Option C. Scrotum: Rupture of the spongy (penile) urethra can lead to urine extravasation into the scrotum. However, injuries to the membranous urethra do not involve the scrotum unless the trauma extends distally.

 

Option D. Anterior abdominal wall: Extravasation into the anterior abdominal wall occurs with injuries to the spongy urethra combined with disruption of Buck’s fascia, allowing urine to spread into the superficial perineal pouch and anterior abdominal wall. This does not happen with isolated membranous urethra injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Injury to the membranous urethra leads to extravasation of urine into the deep perineal pouch, as this portion of the urethra lies within this anatomical space. 
  • It does not involve the scrotum, anterior abdominal wall, or peritoneal cavity unless there are additional injuries.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with complaints of flank pain and hematuria. Pathology of a renal mass reveals polygonal cells with small nuclei, clear cytoplasm, and branching vasculature. This mass is associated with a genetic syndrome that is primarily linked to which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemangioblastoma

 

  • The described renal mass is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which is associated with Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition. 
  • VHL syndrome is linked to several tumors, including hemangioblastomas (commonly in the brain and retina), pheochromocytomas, and RCC. 
  • The presence of hemangioblastomas is a hallmark feature of VHL syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinomas are associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), not VHL syndrome.

 

Option C. Insulinoma: Insulinomas are also associated with MEN1, not VHL syndrome.

 

Option D. Medullary thyroid cancer: This cancer is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), not VHL syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is associated with clear cell RCC and hemangioblastomas, among other tumors. 
  • Recognizing the characteristic pathology and genetic links is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation at a crime scene, a detective is trying to detect traces of bodily fluids, including semen, that are not visible under standard lighting. Which type of light source is most effective in revealing these traces?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UV light

 

  • Ultraviolet (UV) light is widely used in forensic science to identify bodily fluids, such as semen, that remain invisible under normal visible light. 
  • Seminal stains fluoresce when exposed to UV light, allowing forensic experts to detect and document such evidence that might otherwise be overlooked. 
  • This is an essential tool for crime scene investigators in identifying and collecting hidden forensic evidence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infrared light: Infrared light is typically used for imaging heat signatures and is not effective in detecting fluids like semen, which fluoresce under UV light.

 

Option C. Blue light: While blue light can be useful for certain types of evidence, UV light is specifically more effective in visualizing semen stains due to their fluorescence.

 

Option D. Yellow light: Yellow light is ineffective for revealing bodily fluids or stains at a crime scene, as it does not induce fluorescence in substances like semen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ultraviolet (UV) light is the most effective tool used by forensic experts to detect invisible seminal stains at crime scenes.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mirrizzi syndrome

 

  • Mirizzi syndrome occurs when a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck compresses or obstructs the common bile duct (CBD) or common hepatic duct (CHD), leading to:
    1. Obstructive jaundice
    2. Right upper quadrant pain
    3. Nausea or vomiting
  • This condition is identified on imaging, where the CBD/CHD appears narrowed due to external compression by the impacted stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gallstone ileus:

 

  • This occurs when a large gallstone erodes through the gallbladder wall, creating a cholecysto-enteric fistula (commonly to the duodenum).
  • The stone enters the bowel and causes mechanical bowel obstruction, often at the ileocecal junction.
  • Clinical features include abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and evidence of bowel obstruction on imaging.

 

Option C. Choledocholithiasis:

 

  • Refers to gallstones in the common bile duct (CBD), leading to biliary obstruction, jaundice, and sometimes ascending cholangitis.
  • Imaging shows stones within the CBD, not external compression as seen in Mirizzi syndrome.

 

Option D. Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis

 

  • This is a rare, chronic inflammatory disease of the gallbladder, characterized by thickened gallbladder walls with xanthogranulomatous changes.
  • It mimics gallbladder carcinoma clinically and radiologically but lacks evidence of CBD compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirizzi syndrome occurs when an impacted gallstone in the gallbladder neck or cystic duct causes external compression or obstruction of the common bile duct, leading to jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. 
  • It is differentiated from choledocholithiasis (stones within the CBD) and gallstone ileus (intestinal obstruction due to cholecysto-enteric fistula).

choices.text: Weak tone of the lower esophageal sphincter
Formation of a tissue cavity containing necrotic debris

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with fever, progressive weakness, and cough for the past five days. He experienced a similar episode two months ago. Over the last five days, his cough has become more frequent and productive of yellowish-green sputum. Auscultation of the lungs reveals right basal crackles, and dullness to percussion is noted at the right lung base. A chest X-ray shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outpouching of the hypopharynx

 

  • The clinical presentation of recurrent aspiration pneumonia, productive cough, and evidence of a right lower lobe infiltrate suggests Zenker’s diverticulum, an outpouching of the hypopharynx. 
  • This condition can lead to aspiration of food particles or secretions into the lungs, causing recurrent lower respiratory tract infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weak tone of the lower esophageal sphincter: This is associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which does not typically present with recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Formation of a tissue cavity containing necrotic debris: This suggests a lung abscess, which is a possible complication but not the primary explanation for the recurrent episodes of pneumonia.

 

Option C. Uncoordinated contractions of the esophagus: This is seen in esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia, which does not lead to recurrent aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recurrent aspiration pneumonia in older patients with productive cough and radiologic findings of infiltrates may be due to Zenker’s diverticulum, an outpouching of the hypopharynx that predisposes to aspiration.

questions.text: A neonatologist working in a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) in a large hospital observes an increase in cases of oral thrush among newborns. The infections appear to be spreading primarily through hand transmission by healthcare workers. Based on the epidemiology of the infection, which of the following fungal species is most likely responsible for this outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Candida parapsilosis

 

  • Candida parapsilosis is a well-known fungal pathogen in neonatal infections, especially in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs). 
  • It is commonly transmitted via healthcare workers' hands and has a higher tendency to colonize the skin and the hands of caregivers. 
  • This can lead to nosocomial outbreaks, where infants become infected with oral thrush as a result of cross-contamination from hands that have come into contact with contaminated surfaces or patients.
  • The latter is more likely to cause outbreaks due to its ability to persist on the hands of caregivers, making hand hygiene a critical factor in preventing its spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: While C. albicans is the most common cause of oral thrush in neonates, it does not typically spread as effectively via healthcare workers' hands compared to C. parapsilosis. Therefore, it is less likely to be the cause of a nosocomial outbreak in this setting.

 

Option C. Candida tropicalis: C. tropicalis can cause infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, but it is not particularly known for causing outbreaks through hand transmission in the NICU setting, making it an unlikely cause in this scenario.

 

Option D. Candida glabrata: While C. glabrata is an emerging pathogen in healthcare-associated infections, it is less commonly associated with oral thrush in neonates and is not typically transmitted through hands in the same way as C. parapsilosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Candida parapsilosis is an important cause of nosocomial infections, particularly in neonatal intensive care units, where it is often transmitted via healthcare workers' hands.
  • It is more likely to cause outbreaks of oral thrush in neonates due to its ability to colonize and persist on the skin and hands of caregivers. 
  • Proper hand hygiene is crucial in preventing the spread of this pathogen.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents with a persistent, non-itchy erythematous rash in the groin area that has been present for several weeks. There is no history of usage of over the counter topical medications. On examination, the rash has a well-demarcated border. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) test reveals the presence of fungal elements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea cruris

 

  • Tinea cruris, commonly known as "jock itch," is a superficial dermatophyte infection that affects the groin, inner thighs, and occasionally the buttocks. It is characterized by:
    1. Clinical Features: Erythematous plaques with a well-demarcated, raised border. The lesions may or may not be pruritic, and they often persist for weeks or longer.
    2. Location: The involvement of the groin in this patient is classic for tinea cruris.
    3. KOH Examination: The positive potassium hydroxide (KOH) test confirms the presence of fungal elements, consistent with a dermatophyte infection.
  • The described presentation – persistent erythema in the groin with a well-defined border and fungal confirmation on KOH – makes tinea cruris the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tinea corporis: Tinea corporis refers to dermatophyte infections of the trunk, arms, or legs. It presents as annular plaques with central clearing, but it does not typically involve the groin.

 

Option C. Tinea incognito: Tinea incognito occurs when a fungal infection is modified by inappropriate topical steroid use, resulting in an atypical, less demarcated appearance. The well-defined border seen here is not consistent with tinea incognito.

 

Option D. Tinea faciei: Tinea faciei affects the face and presents as annular lesions with scaling and erythema. The groin involvement in this case rules out tinea faciei.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tinea cruris is a dermatophyte infection that typically presents as an erythematous rash with a well-demarcated border in the groin region. 
  • A positive KOH test confirms the diagnosis by identifying fungal elements.

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in the kidneys
Activation of CFTR channels leading to increased chloride secretion into the intestinal lumen
Blocking the absorption of bile salts in the ileum
Inhibition of serotonin reuptake in the gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with chronic constipation is prescribed Plecanatide for her condition. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activation of CFTR channels leading to increased chloride secretion into the intestinal lumen

 

  • Plecanatide is a guanylate cyclase C (GC-C) agonist used primarily to treat chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC). 
  • It works by binding to GC-C receptors on the apical surface of enterocytes in the small intestine. 
  • This activates guanylate cyclase, which increases cAMP and cGMP production within the enterocytes, leading to the activation of CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) channels. 
  • Activation of the CFTR channel increases the secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen. 
  • This results in an increase in intestinal fluid secretion, which softens the stool and relieves constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in the kidneys: This mechanism is more consistent with the action of drugs like amiloride or triamterene (potassium-sparing diuretics) that inhibit sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules, not plecanatide.

 

Option C. Blocking the absorption of bile salts in the ileum: This is the mechanism of drugs like colesevelam or cholestyramine, which are bile acid sequestrants. They bind to bile acids and prevent their reabsorption, affecting cholesterol metabolism and not the chloride secretion in the intestines.

 

Option D. Inhibition of serotonin reuptake in the gastrointestinal tract: This mechanism is characteristic of SSRIs or 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like alosetron, but it does not align with the action of plecanatide, which specifically targets GC-C receptors in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plecanatide is a GC-C receptor agonist that increases chloride secretion by activating the CFTR channel, thereby promoting fluid secretion and softening stool in patients with chronic constipation.

questions.text: A PG resident is conducting a study on the effectiveness of a new drug by comparing the blood pressure of patients before and after taking the drug. The data is paired (each patient has a before and after measurement), but the distribution of differences between the two measurements is not normal. Which statistical test should the resident use to determine if there is a significant difference in blood pressure before and after the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilcoxon signed rank test

 

  • The Wilcoxon signed rank test is the appropriate choice when comparing two related samples or repeated measurements on a single group, especially when the data is not normally distributed. 
  • It is a non-parametric test that evaluates the differences between paired observations, taking into account the direction of the differences (positive or negative) and their magnitude. 
  • Since the data in this scenario is paired (before and after treatment), and the distribution of differences is not normal, the Wilcoxon signed rank test is the most suitable.
    • The paired t-test would require the differences between paired values to follow a normal distribution, which is not met in this case.
    • The unpaired t-test compares two independent groups and is not applicable to paired data.
    • The Chi-square test is used for categorical data and is not appropriate for continuous measurements like blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t-test: The paired t-test compares the means of two related groups but assumes that the differences between the paired observations are normally distributed, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Unpaired t-test: The unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups, not for paired data.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: The Chi-square test is used for categorical data, not for continuous variables like blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Wilcoxon signed rank test is a non-parametric test used to compare two related samples when the data does not follow a normal distribution.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of diarrhea and reduced fluid intake. On examination, the child has dry mucous membranes, slightly sunken eyes, a heart rate of 120 beats/minute, and a capillary refill time of 2 seconds. The urine output is reduced to 0.4 mL/kg/hour. The pediatrician assesses the degree of dehydration based on clinical findings. Which of the following is true regarding the presentation of dehydration in a child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dry mucous membrane—moderate dehydration

 

  • Dry mucous membranes are a key feature of moderate dehydration in children. 
  • Moderate dehydration corresponds to a 3–9% loss of body weight and is associated with thirst, slight tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, and reduced urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced skin turgor—mild dehydration: Incorrect. Reduced skin turgor with recoil taking more than 2 seconds is a sign of severe dehydration, not mild dehydration.

 

Option C. Urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour—moderate dehydration: Incorrect. While reduced urine output is a feature of dehydration, <0.5 mL/kg/hour is a more advanced sign seen in severe dehydration.

 

Option D. Fluid deficit of 150 mL/kg—severe dehydration: Incorrect. Severe dehydration is associated with fluid deficits greater than 100 mL/kg, but 150 mL/kg corresponds to a very severe degree of dehydration that can lead to hypovolemic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Differentiate between mild, moderate, and severe dehydration based on clinical findings such as mucous membrane dryness, skin turgor, urine output, and capillary refill time. 
  • Recognizing these signs early can guide appropriate fluid resuscitation and management in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with increasing joint pain and a recent history of hemolytic anemia. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of C3 and C5. Which of the following functions of complement is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Target cell lysis

 

  • The primary role of complement in target cell lysis is carried out by the membrane attack complex (MAC), which is formed during the activation of the complement system. 
  • This involves the cleavage of C5 and the subsequent formation of the MAC, which causes the formation of pores in the target cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. 
  • In this patient with low levels of C3 and C5, the formation of the MAC and subsequent target cell lysis is likely impaired.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Opsonization: Incorrect. While C3b and C4b are important opsonins, opsonization involves the tagging of pathogens for phagocytosis by immune cells, which is not specifically affected by low levels of C3 and C5 in this context.

 

Option C. Immune adherence: Incorrect. CR2 acts as a receptor for the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and is involved in immune adherence, which is also not directly related to the MAC function or the classical pathway deficiencies described here.

 

Option D. Inflammatory response: Incorrect. Inflammatory mediators such as C3a, C4a, and C5a are involved in chemotaxis and triggering inflammation. Although C3 and C5 levels are low, their anaphylatoxic function is not directly linked to the defect in the MAC pathway that leads to cell lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The membrane attack complex (MAC) is responsible for target cell lysis, and it is formed during the activation of the complement system, specifically involving C3 and C5.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes has persistent postprandial hyperglycemia despite treatment. Laboratory findings indicate a dysfunction in an incretin hormone that stimulates insulin secretion in a glucose-dependent manner and is produced by K-cells of the duodenum. Which hormone is responsible for this function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric Inhibitory Peptide

 

  • Gastric Inhibitory Peptide (GIP), also known as glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide, is secreted by K-cells of the duodenum and jejunum in response to food intake, especially glucose. 
  • It stimulates insulin secretion in a glucose-dependent manner, contributing to the regulation of postprandial blood glucose levels.
  • GIP is part of the incretin system, alongside Glucagon-like Peptide-1 (GLP-1). 
  • Both hormones enhance insulin secretion after meals, but GIP is specifically referred to as glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin: This is a hormone produced in the pancreas and gastrointestinal tract that inhibits the release of insulin, glucagon, and other hormones. It is not an incretin and does not originate from K-cells.

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon, secreted by pancreatic alpha cells, increases blood glucose levels through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not stimulate insulin secretion.

 

Option C. Amylin: Amylin is co-secreted with insulin by pancreatic beta cells and regulates postprandial glucose by slowing gastric emptying and suppressing glucagon release. It is not an incretin hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gastric Inhibitory Peptide (GIP), secreted by K-cells of the duodenum, is an incretin hormone that stimulates insulin secretion in a glucose-dependent manner to regulate postprandial blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a history of cough, breathlessness, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal a WBC count of 78,000/mm³. A peripheral blood smear shows >80% neutrophils, including band forms and immature and mature neutrophil precursors. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hyperplasia with proliferation of all myeloid elements and increased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) activity. A chest X-ray shows a nodule adjacent to the right lung hilum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leukemoid reaction

 

  • The patient’s findings, including elevated WBC count with a predominance of neutrophils and increased LAP activity, are consistent with a leukemoid reaction, which is a reactive process often secondary to infection, inflammation, or malignancy. 
  • The presence of a lung nodule suggests an infectious or neoplastic process, likely driving the reaction. 
  • Increased LAP activity differentiates it from chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), where LAP is typically low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: This primarily affects lymphoid precursors and is more common in younger patients. It does not present with a predominance of mature and immature neutrophils.

 

Option B. Chronic myeloid leukemia: Although CML also shows elevated WBCs with immature and mature myeloid cells, it is typically associated with decreased LAP activity and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL1 fusion).

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: While TB could cause systemic symptoms like weight loss and night sweats, it typically does not result in such a high WBC count dominated by neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A leukemoid reaction is a marked increase in WBC count in response to infection, inflammation, or malignancy, and is characterized by high LAP activity and neutrophilia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with schizophrenia reports intense restlessness and inability to sit still after starting haloperidol. Physical examination shows constant leg movements. Which medication is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propranolol

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of intense restlessness and inability to sit still after starting haloperidol are consistent with akathisia, a movement disorder caused by dopamine antagonism, often as a side effect of antipsychotics like haloperidol. 
  • Akathisia presents as motor restlessness, typically manifesting as constant leg movements, pacing, or a feeling of inner restlessness. 
  • Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is the most appropriate treatment for akathisia, as it has been shown to be effective in alleviating the symptoms of motor restlessness and anxiety associated with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trihexyphenidyl: Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms like parkinsonism. However, it is not typically the first-line treatment for akathisia, as beta-blockers like propranolol are more effective for this condition.

 

Option C. Lorazepam: Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, might help with the anxiety component of akathisia but is not the first-line treatment for the motor symptoms. It can be used in combination with other treatments but is less effective than propranolol for akathisia.

 

Option D. Amantadine: Amantadine is useful for treating parkinsonism and drug-induced movement disorders, but it is not as effective for akathisia as propranolol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute akathisia is the commonest side effect of antipsychotic medications. It is characterized by an inner sense of restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. 
  • Drug of choice is β-blockers such as propranolol. Other treatment options include anticholinergics and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes mammography for a routine breast screening. The imaging reveals microcalcifications in a clustered pattern. A biopsy shows areas of central necrosis within the ducts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Comedo subtype of DCIS

 

  • The comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is characterized by central necrosis and calcifications within the ducts. 
  • These findings are often seen as linear or clustered microcalcifications on mammography, which are highly suspicious for malignancy.

 

In this subtype:

  • Tumor cells grow within the ducts but do not invade the basement membrane.
  • Necrotic debris accumulates centrally in the ducts, and dystrophic calcification occurs over time.
  • On histology, the presence of central necrosis surrounded by tumor cells is a hallmark feature of the comedo subtype.

These features make the comedo subtype of DCIS distinct and easily identifiable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS): LCIS arises from lobular epithelial cells and is often an incidental finding on biopsy. It does not show necrosis or calcifications and typically lacks characteristic findings on mammography.

 

Option C. Cribriform subtype of DCIS: This subtype shows a "Swiss cheese" appearance with uniform spaces created by tumor cells within the ducts. It lacks the central necrosis seen in the comedo subtype and has fewer or no calcifications.

 

Option D. Colloid carcinoma: Colloid (mucinous) carcinoma is a type of invasive breast cancer characterized by extracellular mucin pools. It does not show central necrosis or microcalcifications and is not a form of DCIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comedo subtype of DCIS is characterized by central necrosis and microcalcifications, which can be detected on mammography. 
  • This pattern is an important feature for diagnosing DCIS and differentiating it from other breast lesions.

choices.text: Subnormal intelligence is a consistent feature

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Asperger syndrome in a child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repetitive activity patterns

 

  • Repetitive activity patterns are a hallmark of Asperger syndrome, which is part of the autism spectrum disorders (ASD). 
  • Individuals with Asperger syndrome often engage in repetitive behaviors and have highly focused interests. 
  • In this scenario, the child's tendency to line up toys in a specific order and his distress when routines are disrupted exemplify these repetitive behaviors. 
  • These patterns interfere with social adaptation and can dominate the individual's activities, aligning with the diagnostic criteria for Asperger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in girls: Asperger syndrome, like other autism spectrum disorders, is more commonly diagnosed in boys than in girls. The male-to-female ratio is approximately 4:1, making this statement incorrect.

 

Option C. Subnormal intelligence is a consistent feature: Individuals with Asperger syndrome typically have normal to above-average intelligence. Unlike some other forms of autism, intellectual disability is not a consistent feature of Asperger syndrome, rendering this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Severe language impairment is characteristic: Severe language impairment is not characteristic of Asperger syndrome. Children with Asperger syndrome generally exhibit normal early language development, particularly in syntax and semantics. However, they may experience difficulties with pragmatic aspects of language, such as understanding social cues and engaging in reciprocal conversation. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the core characteristics of Asperger syndrome is essential for accurate diagnosis and management. 
  • Recognizing that repetitive activity patterns are a key feature helps clinicians differentiate Asperger syndrome from other autism spectrum disorders and related conditions. 
  • This knowledge facilitates targeted interventions aimed at improving social interactions and reducing restrictive behaviors in affected children.

questions.text: A patient with metastatic cancer is being treated with 5-Fluoro-Uracil (5-FU), a chemotherapeutic agent known for its role in inhibiting DNA synthesis. The clinician explains that 5-FU exerts its effects by being converted to a specific active metabolite that inhibits a crucial enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidine. Which enzyme is inhibited by the metabolite of 5-Fluoro-Uracil, leading to thymineless cell death?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymidylate synthase

 

  • 5-Fluoro-Uracil (5-FU) is metabolized in the body to 5-fluoro-deoxyuridine monophosphate (FdUMP), which then binds to and inhibits thymidylate synthase. 
  • Thymidylate synthase is a critical enzyme in the synthesis of thymidine, a necessary nucleotide for DNA replication and repair. 
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-FU effectively reduces the availability of thymidine, leading to thymineless cell death, especially in rapidly dividing cancer cells that require sufficient thymidine for DNA synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase is involved in the purine salvage pathway but is not directly affected by 5-FU.

 

Option C. PRPP synthase: PRPP synthase is involved in the synthesis of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides, but it does not play a direct role in thymidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Adenosine deaminase: Adenosine deaminase is involved in the metabolism of adenosine, but it is unrelated to the action of 5-FU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 5-Fluoro-Uracil (5-FU) is a chemotherapeutic agent that inhibits thymidylate synthase via its active metabolite, 5-FdUMP.
  • This inhibition blocks the synthesis of thymidine, causing "thymineless death" in rapidly dividing cancer cells. 
  • It is a key treatment for various malignancies, including colorectal and gastric cancers.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of pain in the right calf for six months. The pain was mild, dull aching, worsened on prolonged standing and was relieved on rest. She also complained of multiple swellings on medial aspect of the right lower limb which had started initially in the foot and later progressed upwards till the calf. What is the mostly likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varicose veins

 

  • Symptoms align with the patient's description: dull aching pain that worsens with prolonged standing and improves with leg elevation.
  • The progression from the foot upwards is also characteristic of varicose veins due to gravity's effect on venous pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): DVT is characterized by acute and severe pain and swelling in one leg, usually associated with warmth and redness. The pain in DVT tends to be more acute and severe than described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Peripheral arterial disease (PAD): PAD typically presents with claudication, which is muscle pain on exertion that resolves with rest, and is due to arterial insufficiency. The pain is often described as crampy or fatiguing and occurs with predictable levels of exercise. 

 

Option D. Neurogenic claudication: Neurogenic claudication results from compression of the spinal nerves, often due to lumbar spinal stenosis. It causes pain in the lower back and legs that is worsened by standing and walking and relieved by bending forward or sitting down. Unlike varicose veins, it is not associated with visible swelling of the veins.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In this case, varicose veins are most consistent with the patient's presentation. 
    • Symptoms- include dull aching pain especially in the calf that increases throughout the day or with prolonged standing, and is relieved by elevation or compression stockings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker presents to the clinic with a request for assistance with smoking cessation. He has tried nicotine replacement therapy in the past without success. He denies any history of psychiatric disorders or seizures but expresses concerns about potential weight gain after quitting smoking. Which of the following pharmacologic agents would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bupropion

 

  • Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) and is commonly used for smoking cessation. 
  • Unlike nicotine replacement therapy (e.g., nicotine patch), bupropion has the additional benefit of being weight-neutral or even slightly weight-reducing, making it particularly useful for patients who are concerned about weight gain after quitting smoking. 
  • It works by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, which can reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms associated with nicotine cessation.
  • Bupropion also has the added benefit of being safe in patients without a history of seizures or psychiatric disorders. 
  • However, it should be used cautiously in patients with a history of seizures due to an increased risk of seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nicotine patch: The nicotine patch is a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) that delivers a steady, controlled dose of nicotine through the skin to reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. While it is effective in some individuals, it does not prevent weight gain, and its success rate is lower compared to bupropion or varenicline, with a 20% success rate. Additionally, nicotine replacement therapy can have a lower efficacy when compared to agents like bupropion in terms of long-term smoking cessation.

 

Option B. Varenicline: Varenicline is a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, which reduces the pleasurable effects of smoking and alleviates withdrawal symptoms. While it is effective, varenicline is associated with a higher risk of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation. For this reason, it may not be the best option for patients who do not have a history of psychiatric disorders but may have concerns about such side effects. Moreover, weight gain is not typically a concern with varenicline.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that is primarily used for managing nicotine withdrawal symptoms, especially in patients with cardiovascular comorbidities. However, clonidine is less effective in promoting long-term cessation compared to bupropion or varenicline, and it can be associated with side effects such as hypotension and sedation. It is not as commonly used as a first-line agent for smoking cessation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bupropion is an effective pharmacologic option for smoking cessation, especially in patients who are concerned about weight gain after quitting smoking. 
  • It is weight-neutral or slightly weight-reducing and works by inhibiting dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake. It is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures.

questions.text: A 3-minute-old newborn presents to the neonatal intensive care unit with signs of respiratory distress. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). To accurately assess the infant's pre-ductal oxygen saturation, the clinical team decides to use pulse oximetry. Where should the clinical team place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right upper limb

 

  • The right upper limb is supplied by the right brachial artery, which originates from the right subclavian artery. 
  • The right subclavian artery arises directly from the brachiocephalic trunk, the first branch of the aortic arch. 
  • This anatomical pathway ensures that oxygen saturation measured at the right upper limb reflects pre-ductal values, meaning it is assessed before any shunting occurs through the PDA. 
  • This makes it the most accurate site for monitoring pre-ductal oxygen saturation in infants with PDA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left upper limb: The left upper limb is supplied by the left subclavian artery, which branches off the aortic arch after the origin of the PDA. Therefore, oxygen saturation measured here would be post-ductal, potentially influenced by the shunt, making it unsuitable for assessing pre-ductal levels.

 

Option B. Left lower limb: Similar to the left upper limb, the left lower limb receives blood from arteries that are downstream of the PDA. Measurements here would reflect post-ductal saturation and could be affected by the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood due to the PDA.

 

Option D. Right lower limb: The right lower limb also receives post-ductal blood. Oxygen saturation measurements in the lower limbs would not accurately represent pre-ductal levels as they are influenced by the shunting through the PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Accurately distinguishing between pre-ductal and post-ductal oxygen saturation sites is essential for the effective monitoring and management of infants with congenital heart defects like patent ductus arteriosus. 
  • Understanding the arterial supply anatomy ensures appropriate placement of pulse oximeters to obtain reliable pre-ductal oxygen saturation readings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been informed by his doctor that the probability of developing acute myocardial infarction (MI) over the course of his lifetime is 0.75. Given this probability, what are the odds that he will experience an acute MI during his lifetime?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The odds of an event occurring are calculated using the following formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • P(event) is the probability of the event occurring.

 

In this case, the probability of the man developing acute MI is 0.75, and the probability of not developing acute MI is:

 

1−0.75=0.25

 

Now, applying the formula:

 

Odds = 0.75/ 0.25 = 3:1

 

Therefore, the odds of this man developing acute MI in his lifetime are 3:1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Odds: Odds are the chance of frequency of occurrence of a characteristic relative to its non-occurrence (expressed as a ratio of occurrence to non-occurrence)
  • Odds = Probability / (1 – Probability)
  • Probability = Odds / (1 + Odds)

choices.text: Non-selective beta-blocker with a half-life of 9 minutes
β1-selective blocker with an elimination half-life of approximately 4 minutes
β2-selective blocker with a half-life of 10 minutes
Non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the pharmacokinetic properties of landiolol?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) β1-selective blocker with an elimination half-life of approximately 4 minutes

 

  • Landiolol is a highly selective β1-adrenergic receptor antagonist with an ultra-short elimination half-life of about 4 minutes, allowing for rapid onset and offset of action. 
  • This pharmacokinetic profile enables precise titration and control in clinical scenarios requiring quick heart rate management. 
  • Its high β1 selectivity reduces the likelihood of bronchoconstriction, making it advantageous in patients with conditions like asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-selective beta-blocker with a half-life of 9 minutes: Describes non-selective beta-blockers with longer half-lives, which are not characteristic of landiolol.

 

Option C. β2-selective blocker with a half-life of 10 minutes: Refers to β2-selective blockers with a longer half-life, not applicable to landiolol.

 

Option D. Non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: Pertains to non-selective beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, which landiolol does not possess.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Landiolol's ultra-short half-life and high β1 selectivity make it ideal for rapid and controlled heart rate reduction in acute clinical settings, with minimal impact on β2 receptors, thereby reducing the risk of bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 24 weeks of gestation undergoes an ultrasound evaluation and the following image is provided below. What measurement is being assessed in this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amniotic fluid index

 

  • The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is being measured in the image. AFI is calculated by dividing the uterus into four quadrants and measuring the deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid in each quadrant. 
  • The sum of these measurements represents the AFI, which is used to assess amniotic fluid volume.
  • This approach is helpful in diagnosing conditions such as oligohydramnios (AFI <5 cm) or polyhydramnios (AFI >24 cm).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical length: Cervical length is measured transvaginally and is used to assess the risk of preterm labor. It measures the distance from the internal to the external cervical os and is unrelated to the measurement depicted in this image.

 

Option C. Deepest vertical pocket of liquor: The deepest vertical pocket (DVP) measures the largest pocket of amniotic fluid in a single quadrant. While DVP is part of the AFI calculation, the AFI represents the combined measurements of all four quadrants, making this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. Femur length: Femur length is a fetal biometry parameter used to estimate fetal growth and gestational age. It involves measuring the diaphysis of the fetal femur, which is unrelated to the amniotic fluid assessment shown in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is calculated by summing the deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid measurements from each of the four quadrants of the uterus. 
  • It is an important tool to assess amniotic fluid volume and diagnose oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with congestive heart failure presents with worsening peripheral edema and pulmonary congestion. On evaluation, the movement of water molecules across the endothelial cells of capillaries into the interstitium is identified as the primary cause of edema. Which process primarily governs this movement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Filtration

 

  • The movement of water molecules across the capillary endothelium into the interstitial space, resulting in edema, is primarily governed by the process of filtration. Filtration is driven by Starling forces, which include:
    • Capillary hydrostatic pressure (pushes fluid out of the capillaries).
    • Plasma oncotic pressure (pulls fluid into the capillaries).

 

In congestive heart failure (CHF):

 

  1. Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure: Elevated venous pressure due to heart failure raises capillary pressure, forcing fluid into the interstitium.
  2. This imbalance in Starling forces leads to fluid accumulation and edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: This process involves energy (ATP) to move substances against their concentration gradient, such as sodium-potassium pump activity. It does not explain the passive movement of water across capillaries during edema formation.

 

Option B. Secondary Active Transport: Secondary active transport uses energy from ion gradients (e.g., sodium) to move substances against their concentration gradient. This process does not regulate water movement in capillaries.

 

Option D. Facilitated Diffusion: Facilitated diffusion involves transport proteins and applies to substances like glucose and ions. Water movement in capillaries is passive and pressure-driven, not dependent on transporters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Edema in congestive heart failure results from filtration, driven by increased capillary hydrostatic pressure and altered Starling forces. 
  • Filtration is the primary process governing the movement of water into the interstitial space.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of cirrhosis of liver presents with sudden hepatomegaly. Imaging reveals solitary 3 x 4 cm nodule with rapid washout of contrast in venous phase. Which clinical criteria would decide suitability for treatment by liver transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Milan criteria

 

  • The Milan criteria, introduced by Mazzaferro in 1996, are the standard for determining eligibility for liver transplantation in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
  • Criteria for liver transplant under the Milan criteria:
    1. A single tumor ≤5 cm in size OR
    2. Up to 3 nodules, each ≤3 cm in size
    3. No angioinvasion or extrahepatic involvement
  • Patients who meet the Milan criteria have excellent outcomes, with a 4-year survival rate of 75% and a recurrence-free survival rate of 83%.
  • In this case, the solitary 3 x 4 cm lesion meets the Milan criteria for liver transplantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child’s score: The Child-Pugh score assesses the severity of chronic liver disease based on parameters like bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy. It is used to determine prognosis and prioritize treatment, but it does not specifically decide transplant eligibility for HCC.

 

Option B. LIRADS score: The Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS) is a standardized method to evaluate liver lesions in patients at risk for HCC. It is useful for diagnosing HCC but does not determine transplant eligibility.

 

Option D. King’s college criteria: The King’s College criteria are used to assess the need for liver transplantation in patients with acute liver failure, not in cases of HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Milan criteria are used to determine eligibility for liver transplantation in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). A solitary lesion ≤5 cm or up to 3 nodules ≤3 cm, with no angioinvasion or extrahepatic spread, ensures excellent survival and low recurrence rates post-transplant.

choices.text: After 2 weeks with normal WBC counts

questions.text: A patient treated with clozapine develops severe agranulocytosis. When can clozapine be restarted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never

 

  • If a patient develops severe agranulocytosis (an absolute neutrophil count [ANC] < 500 cells/μL) while on clozapine, the medication should be permanently discontinued. 
  • Agranulocytosis is a life-threatening complication, and while clozapine can be restarted after resolving neutropenia, it should never be restarted once agranulocytosis has occurred. 
  • This is because the recurrence of agranulocytosis would present an extreme risk of fatal infections.
  • In clinical practice, permanent discontinuation of clozapine is advised for patients who develop agranulocytosis, and they should be closely monitored for other options, including other antipsychotics or treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. After 2 weeks with normal WBC counts: This is true for cases of severe neutropenia but not agranulocytosis. For agranulocytosis, clozapine should never be restarted.

 

Option C. After 4 weeks with prophylactic G-CSF: Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) may be used for treating neutropenia, but it is not recommended to restart clozapine after agranulocytosis, even with G-CSF.

 

Option D. Immediately with close monitoring: Restarting clozapine immediately is unsafe if agranulocytosis has occurred. It should be permanently discontinued.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agranulocytosis (ANC < 500 cells/μL) is a severe and life-threatening complication of clozapine therapy. 
  • Once agranulocytosis occurs, clozapine should be permanently discontinued, and it should never be restarted due to the risk of recurrence.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervix posterior in position

 

  • Preterm labor is defined as regular uterine contractions associated with cervical changes (dilatation or effacement) occurring between 20 and 37 weeks of gestation. 
  • Cervical position (anterior vs. posterior) is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor, although an anterior position may indicate cervical readiness for labor. 
  • Diagnostic criteria focus on uterine contractions and cervical effacement or dilatation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Cervical dilatation > 2 cm is a critical finding in preterm labor, indicating the cervix is opening in response to uterine contractions.

 

Option B. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: This is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor, as frequent contractions combined with cervical changes indicate active labor progression.

 

Option D. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Cervical effacement > 80% is a diagnostic criterion, as it indicates significant thinning of the cervix, a key marker of labor progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of preterm labor requires regular uterine contractions associated with cervical changes, such as dilatation or effacement. 
  • Cervical position is not part of the diagnostic criteria but may provide additional context during clinical examination.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with jaundice, progressive fatigue, and weight loss. Seven months ago, he underwent orthotopic liver transplantation for alcoholic cirrhosis. On examination, scleral icterus is noted. Laboratory studies reveal elevated ALT, AST, and bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy shows perivenular fibrosis, intimal inflammation, and loss of bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic transplant rejection

 

  • Chronic transplant rejection in liver transplant patients is characterized by progressive bile duct loss (vanishing bile duct syndrome), perivenular fibrosis, and intimal inflammation. 
  • These histological findings, coupled with the timeline (several months post-transplant), elevated liver enzymes, and bilirubin, strongly point toward chronic rejection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft-versus-host disease: This typically occurs in bone marrow or hematopoietic stem cell transplants rather than liver transplants. It is associated with skin, gut, and liver involvement but not bile duct loss.

 

Option C. Acute transplant rejection: Acute rejection usually occurs within the first 3 months post-transplant. It is characterized by mixed inflammatory infiltrate in the portal tracts and endothelial inflammation but not bile duct loss or fibrosis.
