Option D. Recurrence of primary disease: Recurrence of alcoholic cirrhosis is unlikely within this short timeframe and does not typically result in the histological findings of bile duct loss or perivenular fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic transplant rejection in liver transplant patients leads to progressive bile duct loss and fibrosis, distinguishing it from other causes of post-transplant liver dysfunction.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with a history of endometriosis presents with infertility and is eager to conceive. She seeks advice on the most effective treatment option to improve her fertility outcomes while managing endometriosis. What is the most appropriate treatment for her condition and fertility goals?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

 

  • For a patient with endometriosis who is actively trying to conceive, laparoscopic ablation of lesions is the most effective treatment. 
  • Surgical management, including ablation or excision of endometriotic lesions, improves fertility by restoring normal pelvic anatomy and removing implants that may interfere with ovulation, fertilization, or implantation. 
  • Laparoscopy also allows the surgeon to address endometriomas and adhesions, further enhancing fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin therapy: Progestins are used to manage pain associated with endometriosis by suppressing estrogen production and endometrial proliferation. However, they are not first-line treatments for infertility related to endometriosis, as they suppress ovulation and prevent conception.

 

Option B. Combined oral contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) are commonly used to manage endometriosis symptoms, but they suppress ovulation and are inappropriate for women actively attempting to conceive.

 

Option C. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists: GnRH agonists suppress ovarian function and reduce the severity of endometriosis, but their use is associated with hypoestrogenic side effects and suppression of ovulation. They are not suitable for women actively trying to conceive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For women with infertility related to endometriosis, laparoscopic ablation or excision of lesions is the treatment of choice to improve fertility outcomes. 
  • This surgical approach restores pelvic anatomy, removes endometriotic implants, and enhances the likelihood of conception.

questions.text: The following muscles cause inversion of foot except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroneus Longus

 

MUSCLES OF FOOT INVERSION

 

  • Inversion is taking great toe inwards.
  • Peroneus longus muscle makes up the lateral compartment of the lower leg along with peroneus brevis muscle. 
  • It originates from the lateral condyle of tibia, head & proximal 2/3rd of lateral surface of fibula, and inserts on the lateral base of first metatarsal and medial cuneiform bone. 
  • It is supplied by the peroneal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • It functions as the evertor of the foot and ankle, and also assists in ankle plantar flexion. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis Anterior, Option B. Tibialis Posterior, and Option D. Extensor Hallucis Longus: All functions as foot invertors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The foot inversion is caused by tibialis anterior, tibialis posterior and extensor hallucis longus muscles. 
  • Peroneus longus muscle causes eversion of the foot along with ankle plantarflexion

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, a farmer, presents with symptoms of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain after ingesting contaminated crabs while working in an endemic area. Which of the following parasites, which has a complex life cycle requiring two intermediate hosts, is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paragonimus spp.

 

  • Paragonimus spp., known as the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails as the first intermediate host and crabs or fish as the second intermediate host. 
  • Humans can become infected by ingesting contaminated crab or fish, leading to lung infection with symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. 
  • This matches the patient’s history and symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fasciola hepatica: Fasciola hepatica primarily causes liver infections, and its second intermediate host is aquatic plants, not crabs or fish, making this option less likely.

 

Option B. Clonorchis spp.: Clonorchis spp. (Chinese liver fluke) also involves snails and fish as intermediate hosts but typically leads to liver rather than pulmonary symptoms.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium spp.: Diphyllobothrium spp. (broad fish tapeworm) affects the intestines and is transmitted through raw fish. It does not cause the pulmonary symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Parasites with an indirect/complex life cycle that require one definitive host and two intermediate hosts

questions.text: Which of these open inguinal hernia repairs involves double breasting of conjoint tendon with inguinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shouldice’s repair

 

  • Shouldice's repair is an open inguinal hernia repair involving the following steps:
    1. The conjoint tendon is sutured to the inguinal ligament in multiple overlapping (double-breasting) layers.
    2. This technique strengthens the posterior wall of the inguinal canal using continuous sutures.
    3. It is considered a pure tissue repair, meaning no prosthetic mesh is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bassini’s repair:

 

  • In Bassini’s repair, the conjoint tendon is approximated to the inguinal ligament in a single layer.
  • This technique does not involve double-breasting and is simpler compared to Shouldice repair.

 

Option B. Maloney’s repair

 

  • Maloney’s repair is a variation of hernia repair, but it does not involve the double-breasting of tissue layers.
  • It is not as commonly practiced as other techniques.

 

Option D. Desarda’s repair:

 

  • Desarda’s repair uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis, which is sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament to reinforce the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • It functions dynamically by tightening during abdominal muscle contraction, but it does not involve double-breasting of the conjoint tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shouldice repair is a tissue-based open inguinal hernia repair involving double-breasting of the conjoint tendon with the inguinal ligament. 
  • This technique is recognized for its superior outcomes and low recurrence rates compared to other tissue repairs.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of severe headaches and transient weakness in his right arm and leg. He has a history of early-onset strokes and migraines with aura, and his father had a similar history before dying of a stroke at the age of 55. Neurological examination reveals mild right-sided weakness. Brain MRI shown below. 

 

 

Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the NOTCH3 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CADASIL 

 

  • CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy)  is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.  
  • It is characterized by recurrent ischemic strokes, migraines with aura, and progressive cognitive decline. 
  • Brain MRI typically shows subcortical white matter hyperintensities, with a predilection for the anterior temporal lobes and external capsules. 
  • A family history of early-onset strokes is a key feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MELAS: Presents with stroke-like episodes, lactic acidosis, and mitochondrial myopathy, often involving mitochondrial DNA mutations.

 

Option C. Fabry Disease: Can cause stroke and white matter changes but is associated with angiokeratomas, corneal opacities, and alpha-galactosidase deficiency.

 

Option D. Multiple Sclerosis: Typically involves demyelination with lesions scattered across the central nervous system, often with relapsing-remitting symptoms, but not the familial stroke pattern seen in CADASIL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CADASIL should be suspected in patients with a family history of early-onset strokes, migraines with aura, and characteristic anterior temporal lobe white matter changes on MRI. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing for NOTCH3 mutations.

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for anchoring actin filaments to the Z-line in muscle fibers?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) α-actinin

 

  • α-actinin is a structural protein that plays a crucial role in anchoring actin filaments to the Z-line within sarcomeres, the functional units of skeletal and cardiac muscle. 
  • This anchoring is essential for maintaining the alignment of actin filaments during muscle contraction and relaxation cycles. 
  • Without α-actinin, the structural integrity of the Z-line would be compromised, affecting muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulin: This protein is involved in regulating the length of actin filaments in skeletal muscle but does not play a direct role in anchoring them to the Z-line.

 

Option B. Myomesin: Myomesin is located in the M-line of the sarcomere and helps stabilize myosin filaments, not actin filaments.

 

Option C. Myosin: Myosin is the motor protein responsible for generating contractile force by interacting with actin filaments. It is not involved in anchoring actin to the Z-line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • α-actinin is a Z-line protein that anchors actin filaments to maintain sarcomere alignment and ensure efficient muscle contraction.

choices.text: Heat stroke with severe central nervous system dysfunction
Heat exhaustion with dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
Acute myocardial infarction due to exertion

questions.text: A 38-year-old male landscaper presents to the emergency department after experiencing fatigue, dizziness, and muscle weakness during a long day of outdoor work in high temperatures. He reports having been exposed to direct sunlight for several hours and sweating heavily throughout the day. On examination, his temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), heart rate is 108 beats per minute, blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. He appears pale and slightly sweaty. Laboratory results reveal a serum sodium level of 128 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heat exhaustion with dehydration and electrolyte imbalance

 

  • This patient's symptoms (fatigue, dizziness, and weakness) combined with his history of prolonged exposure to high temperatures, profuse sweating, and mild hyponatremia suggest heat exhaustion. 
  • Heat exhaustion occurs due to prolonged heat exposure and dehydration, resulting in electrolyte imbalances, including low sodium levels. 
  • Unlike heat stroke, heat exhaustion does not involve significant central nervous system dysfunction (such as confusion or seizures), which is a hallmark of heat stroke. 
  • The patient's relatively stable vital signs and the absence of severe neurological symptoms support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stroke with severe central nervous system dysfunction: Heat stroke is a life-threatening emergency characterized by high body temperature (often >40°C or 104°F) and central nervous system dysfunction (such as confusion, delirium, or seizures). This patient does not have the characteristic symptoms of heat stroke, such as confusion or altered mental status.

 

Option C. Acute myocardial infarction due to exertion: Although chest pain and exertion may be associated with a myocardial infarction, this patient's presentation (lack of chest pain, high temperature, and low sodium) points more towards heat exhaustion. Additionally, there is no evidence of ischemia or elevated cardiac markers to support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Acute renal failure from dehydration: While dehydration can lead to acute renal failure, this patient's primary symptoms are related to systemic heat exhaustion, and there is no clear evidence of kidney dysfunction (e.g., elevated creatinine, oliguria) to suggest acute renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heat exhaustion is caused by prolonged exposure to high temperatures, leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, often presenting with symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, weakness, and mild hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, a professional singer, presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and occasional vocal strain for the past four months. He denies smoking or significant upper respiratory infections. Laryngoscopy reveals a unilateral, smooth, pedunculated lesion arising from the free edge of the vocal cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal cord polyp

 

  • The image shows a unilateral swelling at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is characteristic of a vocal cord polyp.
  • Vocal cord polyps are typically unilateral, large, and sessile or pedunculated lesions that arise due to phonotrauma (e.g., excessive vocal strain).
  • They are associated with hoarseness of voice due to impaired vibration of the affected vocal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord nodule: Vocal cord nodules are typically bilateral and symmetric, located at the same junction as polyps. They are smaller and appear more like callous-like formations.

 

Option C. Reinke's edema: Reinke's edema involves bilateral, diffuse swelling of the vocal cords with a polypoidal appearance. It is commonly associated with smoking and low-pitched hoarseness, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Vocal cord cyst: A vocal cord cyst appears as a submucosal lesion within the vocal cord, typically white or translucent, with a smooth surface. It does not appear as the unilateral protrusion seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A vocal cord polyp is a unilateral lesion at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, commonly caused by phonotrauma and presenting with hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: Bacterial endocarditis due to Streptococcus viridans
Bacterial endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis
Bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus epidermidis
Bacterial endocarditis due to Escherichia coli

questions.text: A 45-year-old male IV drug abuser presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and murmur on auscultation. Blood cultures grow gram-positive cocci in pairs that are non-hemolytic on blood agar. The organisms are bile aesculin positive, PYR-positive, and able to grow in 6.5% NaCl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacterial endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis

 

  • Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of infective endocarditis, especially in patients with risk factors like IV drug abuse. 
  • The laboratory findings (gram-positive cocci in pairs, non-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, PYR-positive, bile aesculin positive, and growth in 6.5% NaCl) are typical of Enterococcus faecalis. 
  • This pathogen can cause mitral valve endocarditis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or those with prolonged catheter use, making it highly relevant in this clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial endocarditis due to Streptococcus viridans: Incorrect. S. viridans is part of the normal oral flora and is a common cause of endocarditis, but it typically produces alpha-hemolysis on blood agar and does not grow in 6.5% NaCl.

 

Option C. Bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus epidermidis: Incorrect. S. epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus, typically associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis, but it would be catalase-positive (unlike Enterococcus) and would not show PYR-positive results.

 

Option D. Bacterial endocarditis due to Escherichia coli: Incorrect. E. coli is gram-negative, and while it can cause endocarditis, it would not have the typical gram-positive cocci in pairs morphology or show the other biochemical features characteristic of Enterococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enterococcus faecalis is a key pathogen in infective endocarditis, especially in high-risk populations like IV drug users, and can be identified by its PYR-positive, bile aesculin-positive, and 6.5% NaCl growth characteristics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a gradual decrease in vision in his right eye for the past 2 months. On examination, there is a grayish-white opacity in the cornea. His visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left. The patient denies any history of trauma or systemic diseases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy

 

  • Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, progressive corneal endothelial disease that primarily affects the aging population. 
  • It causes gradual corneal edema due to the loss of endothelial cells, leading to a decrease in the corneal pump function. 
  • This results in fluid accumulation in the stroma, causing grayish-white or cloudy areas in the cornea. 
  • Typically, vision starts to deteriorate early in the morning due to edema, which improves throughout the day with blinking and tear production.
  • In this case, the patient’s symptoms and gradual progression of vision loss without trauma or systemic disease point to Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy. 
  • The key feature of this condition is the development of corneal opacities due to fluid buildup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: Keratoconus typically presents with a progressive thinning and conical shape of the cornea, which leads to astigmatism and visual distortion. However, unlike Fuchs' dystrophy, keratoconus usually manifests in younger patients and presents with irregular astigmatism rather than central corneal opacity.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex keratitis: Herpes simplex keratitis is usually associated with a history of herpetic infection and often presents with dendritic ulcers visible on fluorescein staining. It is not typically characterized by a gradual, non-painful clouding of the cornea like in Fuchs' dystrophy.

 

Option D. Corneal scar: Corneal scars are generally caused by trauma or infections, leading to localized opacity. The absence of any history of trauma or infection, along with the gradual progression of symptoms, makes a corneal scar an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy should be recognized as a progressive corneal endothelial disease that causes gradual vision loss due to the loss of endothelial cells and resulting corneal edema. 
  • It typically presents with grayish-white opacity and is more common in older patients.

questions.text:
Regarding suicide risk, which statements are correct?

 

  1. Most common psychiatric cause is depression
  2. Previous attempt is the strongest predictor
  3. Completed suicide is more common in females
  4. Risk is high immediately after hospital discharge

 

Select the correct combination:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4 are correct

 

1. Most common psychiatric cause is depression: True. Depression is the most common psychiatric condition associated with suicide. People with major depressive disorder have significantly higher suicide rates compared to the general population.

 

2. Previous attempt is the strongest predictor: True. Previous suicide attempts are considered the strongest predictor of future suicide risk. Individuals who have previously attempted suicide are at a higher risk of completing suicide.

 

4. Risk is high immediately after hospital discharge: True. The risk of suicide is high in the period immediately following hospital discharge, particularly after discharge from psychiatric hospitalization. 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Completed suicide is more common in females: False. While females have a higher rate of suicide attempts, completed suicide is more common in males. Men often use more lethal means (e.g., firearms) than women, which contributes to their higher rates of completed suicides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Depression is the most common psychiatric cause of suicide, and previous suicide attempts are the strongest predictor of future risk. 
  • The immediate post-discharge period is critical, as it marks a time of heightened vulnerability for suicide, while completed suicides are more common in males despite females having a higher rate of attempts.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) 32 mL/min

Substituting the correct values:

Thus, the correct urine flow rate is indeed 32 mL/min.

  • To calculate the urine flow rate (V) when renal clearance, plasma concentration, and urine concentration are known, use the formula:

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 4, in active labor at 37 weeks of gestation undergoes an amniotomy to augment labor when the cervix is dilated to 5 cm. The amniotic fluid appears golden in color upon rupture of membranes. What is the most likely cause of this golden discoloration of the amniotic fluid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rh isoimmunization

 

  • Golden-colored amniotic fluid is most often associated with Rh isoimmunization. 
  • This condition occurs when maternal antibodies attack fetal red blood cells in Rh-incompatible pregnancies, causing hemolysis and significant bilirubin release. 
  • Bilirubin imparts the characteristic golden or amber coloration to the amniotic fluid. 
  • This finding often indicates severe hemolysis in the fetus, which can lead to hydrops fetalis if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intra-amniotic infection: Intra-amniotic infections, such as chorioamnionitis, are usually associated with cloudy, foul-smelling amniotic fluid due to the presence of pus and bacterial overgrowth. Golden-colored fluid is not typical in cases of infection.

 

Option C. Chorioamnionitis: Chorioamnionitis, a bacterial infection of the amniotic sac, results in similar findings to intra-amniotic infections. Amniotic fluid in these cases often appears cloudy and odorous, not golden.

 

Option D. Post maturity: Post maturity syndrome is associated with meconium-stained or thickened amniotic fluid due to prolonged exposure to stress hormones. Golden amniotic fluid is not a common finding in post maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Golden-colored amniotic fluid observed during labor is a hallmark of Rh isoimmunization, caused by hemolysis of fetal red blood cells and the release of bilirubin. 
  • This finding indicates severe hemolytic disease of the fetus, requiring immediate assessment and possible intervention to prevent fetal complications.

questions.text: A 17-year-old presents with primary amenorrhea. Physical examination shows normal genitalia and breast development. Laboratory results reveal a 5-alpha reductase deficiency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • Male pseudohermaphroditism occurs when an individual has a 46,XY karyotype but has ambiguous or female-like external genitalia due to impaired androgen action or conversion. 
  • In 5-alpha reductase deficiency, testosterone is not efficiently converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is essential for the development of male external genitalia. 
  • These individuals typically present as phenotypically female or ambiguous genitalia at birth, despite having internal male structures (e.g., testes). 
  • Puberty often triggers virilization due to increased testosterone levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Female pseudohermaphrodite: Female pseudohermaphroditism occurs in individuals with a 46,XX karyotype who have masculinized external genitalia due to excess androgen exposure in utero. This condition is unrelated to 5-alpha reductase deficiency.

 

Option B. Concealed sex: This is a vague term and not a recognized diagnostic category in medical practice. It does not apply to this case.

 

Option D. True hermaphroditism: True hermaphroditism, or ovotesticular disorder, is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual. This condition is not associated with 5-alpha reductase deficiency or a 46,XY karyotype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 5-alpha reductase deficiency causes male pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by a 46,XY karyotype with ambiguous or female-like genitalia due to impaired DHT production. 
  • At puberty, testosterone-driven virilization may occur, revealing the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure is being treated for his condition. He is concerned about the possibility of hyperkalemia due to his medications. Which of the following drugs is least likely to contribute to an increase in potassium levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Furosemide

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic commonly used in patients with chronic renal failure. 
  • It works by inhibiting sodium and chloride reabsorption in the loop of Henle, promoting diuresis. 
  • This action increases the excretion of potassium, sodium, and chloride, reducing the risk of hyperkalemia. 
  • In contrast, furosemide tends to cause hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia, especially when used in patients with renal dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beta-blockers: Beta-blockers can contribute to hyperkalemia in patients with chronic renal failure. They inhibit beta-adrenergic activity, which can lead to reduced potassium uptake by cells and result in elevated potassium levels in the blood. Beta-blockers are also known to impair renal potassium excretion, which further increases the risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. ACE inhibitors: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors can raise potassium levels in patients with chronic renal failure. They block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, leading to decreased aldosterone secretion. Since aldosterone promotes potassium excretion, its inhibition can result in potassium retention, leading to hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs): Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs also block the effects of angiotensin II, leading to decreased aldosterone secretion and a similar risk of hyperkalemia. ARBs are commonly used in patients with chronic kidney disease, but they can also impair potassium excretion, increasing the risk of elevated potassium levels in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces potassium levels by increasing its excretion, whereas beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs can increase potassium levels due to their effects on renal function and electrolyte balance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with something coming out per anus (SCOPA) and splash in the pan type of blood in stools. On examination, the mass remains outside and has crossed the anal verge but can be manually reduced. Which is the grade of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

  • Hemorrhoids are symptomatic enlargements of the internal haemorrhoidal venous plexus (Greek: haima = blood, rhoos = flowing; synonym: piles, Latin: pila = a ball). Internal hemorrhoids characteristically lie in the 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions (with the patient in the lithotomy position)
  • The internal haemorrhoidal plexus constitutes the submucosal component of the anal cushions that are important in sealing the anal canal. 
  • Man’s upright posture, the absence of valves in the portal venous system and raised abdominal pressure due to pregnancy or particularly through straining during defecation contribute to venous plexus engorgement and development of varicosities. Shearing forces lead to mucosal trauma (bleeding) and caudal displacement of the anal cushions (prolapse).

 

Four degrees of hemorrhoids:

 

  • First degree - Bleed only, no prolapse
  • Second degree - Prolapse but reduce spontaneously
  • Third degree - Prolapse but have to be manually reduced
  • Fourth degree - Permanently prolapsed

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Grade III internal hemorrhoids are characterized by prolapse during straining or defecation that can be manually reduced, distinguishing them from Grade IV, which are irreducible.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent infections involving the lungs, liver, and bones that have required multiple hospitalizations. His history is significant for excessive inflammation, granuloma formation, gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis. Laboratory testing shows defective respiratory burst activity in neutrophils. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH oxidase

 

  • The patient’s recurrent infections, granuloma formation, and defective neutrophil respiratory burst activity are classic findings of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD). 
  • CGD is caused by a deficiency of NADPH oxidase, an enzyme essential for the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) during the oxidative burst in phagocytes (neutrophils and macrophages).
  • NADPH oxidase generates superoxide radicals by transferring electrons from NADPH to molecular oxygen. 
  • These radicals are critical for microbial killing within phagolysosomes. 
  • Without NADPH oxidase, pathogens (especially catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus and Aspergillus) persist, leading to chronic infections and granuloma formation. 
  • Associated symptoms like gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD): G6PD deficiency leads to impaired NADPH production in red blood cells, making them vulnerable to oxidative stress. This causes hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to oxidant stressors (e.g., fava beans, infections, or drugs). However, it does not cause defective respiratory burst activity, granuloma formation, or recurrent infections seen in CGD.

 

Option C. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): LDH is involved in the conversion of pyruvate to lactate during anaerobic glycolysis. LDH deficiency may cause muscle weakness and exercise intolerance, but it is not associated with impaired neutrophil function, respiratory burst defects, or recurrent infections.

 

Option D. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is involved in purine metabolism, converting hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. Deficiency causes xanthinuria, leading to reduced uric acid levels and potential kidney stones. It has no role in neutrophil oxidative burst or granuloma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) results from a deficiency of NADPH oxidase, which impairs the respiratory burst in phagocytes, leading to defective microbial killing, recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms, and granuloma formation.

questions.text: Following the consumption of a heavy meal with an alcoholic binge, a patient presents with severe chest pain and retching. Serum lipase is 200U/L, chest X-ray shows left pleural effusion. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CECT thorax + abdomen

 

  • The clinical picture strongly suggests Boerhaave’s syndrome (spontaneous esophageal perforation) due to:
    1. Alcohol binge and heavy meal
    2. Severe chest pain and retching
    3. Left pleural effusion on chest X-ray
  • Boerhaave’s syndrome occurs due to sudden increased intra-esophageal pressure against a closed glottis, resulting in esophageal rupture.
  • CECT Thorax + Abdomen with water-soluble contrast is the definitive investigation to confirm the diagnosis. It can:
    • Identify the site of perforation
    • Detect fluid collections, pleural effusions, and other complications
    • Assess for mediastinitis and pneumomediastinum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Laparoscopy is unnecessary at this stage as Boerhaave’s syndrome is primarily diagnosed through imaging. It is invasive and not the first-line step for esophageal perforation.

 

Option B. USG thorax: Ultrasound is useful to confirm a pleural effusion but does not detect esophageal perforation. It lacks the sensitivity to identify mediastinal or esophageal pathology.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy: Endoscopy may worsen the perforation by increasing intraluminal pressure. It is contraindicated when esophageal perforation is suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Boerhaave’s syndrome presents with a triad of vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema, often after forceful retching following heavy meals or alcohol binge. 
  • CECT thorax + abdomen with contrast is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis, identify the perforation site, and detect complications like pleural effusion or mediastinitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss over the past several months. On examination, she is pale with a distended abdomen. Laboratory findings show iron-deficiency anemia. A duodenal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Celiac sprue

 

  • The biopsy findings of villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes are classic for celiac disease. 
  • Celiac disease (celiac sprue) is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion in susceptible individuals, leading to malabsorption.

 

Key features include:

 

  • Clinical symptoms: Chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and iron-deficiency anemia due to impaired iron absorption in the proximal small intestine.
  • Histology: Flattening of villi, crypt hyperplasia, and lymphocytic infiltration in the small intestine.
  • Symptoms improve with a gluten-free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease involves the entire gastrointestinal tract and presents with skip lesions, transmural inflammation, and non-caseating granulomas. Villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia are not characteristic.

 

Option C. Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and rectum, causing bloody diarrhea and mucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses, not villous atrophy.

 

Option D. Tropical sprue: Tropical sprue also causes villous atrophy and malabsorption, similar to celiac disease, but it occurs in individuals living in or visiting tropical regions. It is thought to be infectious and responds to antibiotic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Celiac disease presents with villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis on duodenal biopsy. 
  • It causes chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and iron-deficiency anemia, which improve with a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who delivered 18 months ago and is breastfeeding presents with irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding. She seeks advice on the most appropriate contraceptive method. What is the best contraceptive option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS)

 

  • The levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is the most appropriate contraceptive method for this patient. 
  • It provides long-term, reversible contraception and is highly effective in reducing menstrual bleeding, making it ideal for patients with heavy and irregular periods. 
  • The local release of levonorgestrel suppresses endometrial growth, leading to lighter and more regular menstrual cycles. 
  • It is safe for breastfeeding women as it does not significantly affect lactation or systemic hormonal levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin-only pill: While safe for breastfeeding mothers and effective as contraception, progestin-only pills require strict adherence to daily intake at the same time. They may also cause irregular bleeding patterns, which might not be suitable for a woman already experiencing irregular and heavy periods.

 

Option B. CuT 380 A: The copper intrauterine device provides non-hormonal, long-term contraception but can worsen menstrual bleeding and cramping, making it unsuitable for a patient with heavy and irregular periods.

 

Option C. Mala-N: This combined oral contraceptive pill contains estrogen, which is contraindicated for breastfeeding mothers as it can suppress lactation. It is also not the best choice for managing heavy menstrual bleeding compared to the LNG-IUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is the best contraceptive option for breastfeeding women with heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding. 
  • It provides effective contraception, reduces menstrual blood loss, and is safe for lactating mothers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old retired shipyard worker presents with progressive shortness of breath and chest pain. Imaging reveals pleural thickening and pulmonary fibrosis. A biopsy of the lung shown below. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asbestosis

 

  • The histopathological image shows ferruginous bodies, which are asbestos fibers coated with iron and protein. 
  • These structures are characteristic of asbestosis, a pneumoconiosis caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos. Key features include:
    • Pulmonary fibrosis: Typically involves the lower lobes.
    • Pleural thickening and plaques: A hallmark of asbestos exposure.
    • Ferruginous bodies: Asbestos fibers surrounded by hemosiderin-laden macrophages, visible under light microscopy.
  • Patients often have a history of occupational exposure to asbestos, particularly in shipyards, construction, or insulation work.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesothelioma: Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura strongly linked to asbestos exposure. While asbestosis increases the risk of mesothelioma, the diagnosis of mesothelioma requires identifying atypical mesothelial cells and evidence of invasive growth, not just fibrosis and ferruginous bodies.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Anthracosis results from coal dust accumulation in the lungs, leading to black pigmentation of lung tissue. It is common in coal miners and urban dwellers but does not cause pleural thickening, fibrosis, or ferruginous bodies.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis results from inhalation of silica dust and primarily causes upper lobe nodular fibrosis. Histology often shows birefringent silica particles under polarized light, not ferruginous bodies. Pleural thickening is uncommon in silicosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asbestosis is characterized by pulmonary fibrosis, pleural thickening, and the presence of ferruginous bodies (asbestos fibers coated with iron). 
  • Occupational exposure to asbestos is the primary risk factor

choices.text: The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients.
Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles.
Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).
The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with generalized muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She also reports diplopia and ptosis. Initial testing reveals a negative serum anti-AChR antibody test. Further investigations reveal the presence of anti-MuSK antibodies. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-MuSK antibodies are present in approximately 40% of anti-AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (MG).

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). 
  • Anti-MuSK (muscle-specific tyrosine kinase) antibodies are present in approximately 40% of patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR (acetylcholine receptor) antibodies. 
  • These antibodies interfere with the clustering of acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ, contributing to the pathogenesis of MG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of anti-MuSK antibodies excludes the possibility of anti-AChR antibodies in other patients: While anti-MuSK antibodies are rarely found in anti-AChR-positive patients, their presence does not categorically exclude anti-AChR antibodies in other individuals.

 

Option B. Anti-MuSK antibodies are commonly found in patients with weakness confined to ocular muscles: Anti-MuSK antibodies are typically associated with generalized MG, not with MG limited to ocular muscles.

 

Option D. The severity of myasthenia gravis correlates directly with the measured level of anti-AChR antibodies: The severity of MG does not correlate well with anti-AChR antibody levels across different patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with generalized MG who are negative for anti-AChR antibodies may have anti-MuSK antibodies. 
  • These antibodies play a significant role in the clustering of acetylcholine receptors and are critical for diagnosing antibody-negative MG.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage (D&C) in the correct sequence:

 

  1. Serial dilation
  2. Curettage
  3. Uterine sound
  4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-3-1-2

 

The correct sequence for performing dilation and curettage (D&C) is as follows:

 

Assessment of uterine size and direction (Step 4): This is the first step, performed by bimanual examination to determine the size, position, and orientation of the uterus. This ensures the procedure is performed safely and minimizes the risk of uterine perforation.

 

Uterine sound (Step 3): A uterine sound is then inserted to measure the length of the uterine cavity and confirm its direction. This helps guide subsequent steps of the procedure.

 

Serial dilation (Step 1): The cervix is gradually dilated using graduated dilators to allow the introduction of the curette.

 

Curettage (Step 2): Finally, the curette is used to scrape the endometrial lining for tissue removal or sampling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of steps for dilation and curettage (D&C) is assessment of uterine size and direction → uterine sounding → serial dilation → curettage.
  • This sequence ensures safe and effective removal of uterine contents.

choices.text: Deposition of immune complexes in the glomeruli
Direct bacterial invasion of renal tubules
Ischemic damage due to systemic vasculitis
Acute tubular necrosis due to toxic metabolites

questions.text:
A 29-year-old veterinarian presents with fever, headache, myalgia, and nausea for the past 7 days. He reports contact with animal urine while working on a farm. On examination, he has conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory findings are as follows:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL
  • Platelet count: 70,000/mm³
  • Creatinine: 3.2 mg/dL
  • Total bilirubin: 8.0 mg/dL (direct: 2.5 mg/dL)
  • AST/ALT: Mildly elevated (AST: 120 U/L, ALT: 105 U/L)
  • Prothrombin time: Prolonged
  • Urinalysis: Proteinuria and microscopic hematuria

 

What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying this patient’s kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ischemic damage due to systemic vasculitis

 

  • The clinical presentation of fever, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, along with a history of contact with animal urine, is highly suggestive of Weil's disease, the severe form of leptospirosis. 
  • Kidney injury in Weil’s disease is caused by ischemic damage from systemic vasculitis, which results in interstitial nephritis and tubular damage. 
  • The presence of proteinuria and hematuria further supports this mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deposition of immune complexes in the glomeruli: This is characteristic of conditions like lupus nephritis, not leptospirosis.

 

Option B. Direct bacterial invasion of renal tubules: While Leptospira interrogans can localize in the kidney, kidney injury in Weil's disease is primarily due to ischemic damage and interstitial inflammation.

 

Option D. Acute tubular necrosis due to toxic metabolites: Although tubular necrosis can occur, it is secondary to ischemia and inflammation, not toxic metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Weil's disease, kidney injury results from ischemic damage and interstitial nephritis due to systemic vasculitis, which distinguishes it from other causes of acute kidney injury.

questions.text: Salt pepper skull is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary hyperparathyroidism

 

SALT PEPPER SKULL

 

  • Salt and pepper skull refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism. 
  • There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull and a ground-glass appearance as well as spotty deossification.

 

 

  • Skull appearance in other conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by excessive and abnormal bone remodeling. It is characterized by cotton wool skull appearance.

 

 

Option B. Eosinophilic granuloma. Eosinophilic granuloma is a localized form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a disorder involving the proliferation of certain white blood cells. It is characterized by Geographical lesion (Bevelled margins) in the skull.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells in the bone marrow. The skull gives a punched out appearance in this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Salt and pepper skull is a radiographic feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 6 weeks' gestation undergoes a transvaginal ultrasound to confirm viability of the pregnancy. The ultrasound reveals a double-bleb sign. What does this ultrasound finding represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amniotic sac and yolk sac

 

  • The double-bleb sign on ultrasound is a hallmark of a very early intrauterine pregnancy. 
  • It refers to the visualization of the amniotic sac and yolk sac within the gestational sac. 
  • This finding is an early sign of a viable pregnancy before the fetal pole is visible. 
  • The amniotic sac and yolk sac are seen as two adjacent circular structures, confirming intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heterotopic pregnancy: Heterotopic pregnancy involves simultaneous intrauterine and ectopic pregnancies. The double-bleb sign is not a feature of this condition, as it specifically represents structures within a single intrauterine gestational sac.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: An ectopic pregnancy occurs when the gestational sac implants outside the uterus, typically in the fallopian tube. The double-bleb sign cannot occur in an ectopic pregnancy, as it signifies a developing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Option D. Intrauterine two gestational sacs: The presence of two gestational sacs indicates a twin pregnancy. This is distinct from the double-bleb sign, which refers to the amniotic sac and yolk sac within a single gestational sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The double-bleb sign on ultrasound refers to the presence of the amniotic sac and yolk sac within the gestational sac, an early indicator of a viable intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe agitation, fever of 103°F (39.4°C), tachycardia, and tremors. Her medical history is significant for untreated hyperthyroidism. Laboratory studies reveal suppressed TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 levels. A diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

  • Aspirin is contraindicated in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing T3 and T4 from their binding proteins (thyroxine-binding globulin, transthyretin, and albumin). 
  • This can worsen the hypermetabolic state characteristic of thyroid storm. 
  • Therefore, alternative antipyretics, such as acetaminophen, are preferred to manage fever in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to control the adrenergic symptoms of thyroid storm, such as tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, which helps lower active thyroid hormone levels.

 

Option B. Lugol's iodine: Lugol's iodine is a saturated iodine solution used to inhibit thyroid hormone release and reduce iodine organification (Wolff-Chaikoff effect). It is an effective agent in the treatment of thyroid storm when given after thionamides to prevent iodine from being used for further hormone synthesis.

 

Option D. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen is used to control fever in thyroid storm and is safe to use. Unlike aspirin, it does not displace thyroid hormones from their binding proteins and does not exacerbate hyperthyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspirin is contraindicated in thyroid storm because it displaces thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition. 
  • Acetaminophen is preferred for managing fever in this situation.

choices.text: Antigenic variation in the hepatitis B virus surface antigen
Immune complex formation with hepatitis B surface antigen
Inefficient B-cell response to the hepatitis B virus
Non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, a healthcare worker, presents for a routine check-up. She reports no major symptoms but is concerned about a recent needle-stick injury during a patient procedure. Laboratory tests reveal normal liver enzymes, but she tests positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) with elevated levels of anti-HBc IgG antibodies. Despite these findings, her viral load remains detectable. What is the most likely reason for her persistent viremia despite the presence of these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen

 

  • In the case of chronic hepatitis B infection, the presence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies (indicating prior exposure to the virus) and HBsAg (indicating active infection) does not necessarily correlate with the resolution of viremia. 
  • The most likely explanation for persistent viremia in this patient is the presence of non-neutralizing antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg). 
  • These antibodies are unable to effectively neutralize the virus, allowing continued viral replication despite the immune response.
  • In contrast to neutralizing antibodies, non-neutralizing antibodies can bind to the virus but fail to prevent it from infecting liver cells, which results in the persistence of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antigenic variation in the hepatitis B virus surface antigen: While antigenic variation can occur with hepatitis C and other viruses, hepatitis B does not exhibit significant antigenic drift or shift that would explain the persistence of viremia in this case. The primary mechanism for persistence in hepatitis B is the failure of immune response rather than continuous antigenic variation.

 

Option B. Immune complex formation with hepatitis B surface antigen: Immune complex formation could lead to some degree of tissue damage, such as in immune-complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, but it is not the primary reason for viremia in hepatitis B. The presence of antibodies against HBsAg does not generally result in significant immune complex formation in this context.

 

Option C. Inefficient B-cell response to the hepatitis B virus: Although an ineffective immune response can play a role in chronic infection, the B-cell response in hepatitis B infection is typically adequate for producing antibodies. The issue here is not the quantity of antibodies, but rather their quality—specifically, the non-neutralizing nature of the antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In chronic hepatitis B infection, non-neutralizing antibodies against hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) can be present and fail to clear the virus, leading to persistent viremia despite the presence of specific antibodies. This highlights the importance of the neutralizing capacity of antibodies in controlling viral infections.

choices.text: Introduction of clean water and sanitation in urban areas through the Public Health Act of 1848
The establishment of the National Health Service (NHS) in the UK in 1948
The creation of the first national vaccination program in the UK
The foundation of the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1948

questions.text: Edwin Chadwick is best known for his contributions to public health reform during the 19th century. Which of the following initiatives was directly influenced by Chadwick's work?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Introduction of clean water and sanitation in urban areas through the Public Health Act of 1848

 

  • Edwin Chadwick was a pioneer in public health reform and played a central role in advocating for the improvement of sanitation and living conditions in industrialized cities. 
  • His report on the sanitary conditions of the laboring population led to the Public Health Act of 1848, which was the first legislative attempt to address the issues of sanitation, clean water, and waste management in urban areas. 
  • This act was a foundational step in the development of modern public health policy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The establishment of the National Health Service (NHS) in the UK in 1948: While Chadwick’s work influenced public health reforms, the NHS was established much later in 1948, driven by figures like Aneurin Bevan, not by Chadwick.

 

Option C. The creation of the first national vaccination program in the UK: Chadwick’s work was focused on sanitation and public health infrastructure, not directly on vaccination programs. The first national vaccination programs were more influenced by later public health pioneers.

 

Option D. The foundation of the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1948: Chadwick's influence was national, not international. The WHO was established after World War II, and while public health reformers like Chadwick contributed to the development of global health systems, the WHO was not directly shaped by his work.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Edwin Chadwick’s work directly influenced the Public Health Act of 1848, which focused on improving sanitation and clean water in urban areas.

choices.text: Administer 100% oxygen for a few minutes before discontinuing N2O
Use halothane for maintenance instead of N2O

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoing surgery under general anesthesia is given a combination of nitrous oxide (N2O) and an inhalational anesthetic. Upon recovery, she develops rapid breathing and symptoms of hypoxia. The anaesthetist suspects diffusion hypoxia. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to prevent this condition during the recovery phase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer 100% oxygen for a few minutes before discontinuing N2O

 

  • Diffusion hypoxia occurs during the recovery phase when nitrous oxide (N2O) is rapidly discontinued, causing a large amount of N2O to leave the bloodstream and dilute the available oxygen. 
  • To prevent this, the administration of 100% oxygen for several minutes before discontinuing N2O is recommended. 
  • This helps to prevent hypoxia by maintaining oxygen saturation during the rapid diffusion of N2O out of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of N2O: Increasing the dose of N2O would not help in preventing diffusion hypoxia and could potentially worsen the hypoxia by displacing oxygen in the blood.

 

Option C. Use halothane for maintenance instead of N2O: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent, but it does not address the issue of diffusion hypoxia related to the use of N2O. N2O is still the main cause of this condition.

 

Option D. Increase the rate of ventilation: Increasing ventilation alone does not directly address the problem of diffusion hypoxia caused by the rapid diffusion of N2O from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To prevent diffusion hypoxia during recovery from anesthesia, 100% oxygen should be administered for several minutes before discontinuing nitrous oxide (N2O).

choices.text: Presence of lactose fermentation on MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following can differentiate between Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of lactose fermentation on MacConkey agar

 

Explanation:

 

Both Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis are non-lactose fermenters on MacConkey agar, so lactose fermentation cannot be used to differentiate between them.

 

Key differentiating features between the two include:

 

Motility at 22°C: Y. enterocolitica is motile at 22°C, whereas Y. pestis is non-motile at all temperatures.

 

Growth at 4°C: Y. enterocolitica can grow at refrigeration temperatures (psychrophilic), while Y. pestis cannot.

 

Urease activity: Y. enterocolitica is urease-positive, while Y. pestis is urease-negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pestis differ in motility at 22°C, growth at 4°C, and urease activity. However, both are non-lactose fermenters on MacConkey agar, making lactose fermentation an invalid differentiating factor.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of solvent abuse presents with fatigue and frequent exposure to toluene. Laboratory tests reveal elevated hippuric acid in his urine. Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzoyl glycine

 

  • Hippuric acid is a compound formed in the liver through the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine.
  • This process occurs as part of the body’s detoxification pathway, particularly for substances like toluene, which is metabolized to benzoic acid. 
  • Benzoic acid undergoes conjugation via the enzyme glycine N-acyltransferase, leading to the formation of benzoyl glycine (hippuric acid). 
  • Hippuric acid is then excreted in the urine as a detoxified product.
  • Clinically, elevated hippuric acid levels can serve as a marker for toluene exposure, commonly seen in individuals with solvent abuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benzoyl acetate: Benzoyl acetate does not participate in the metabolism of benzoic acid or in hippuric acid formation. It is not involved in the conjugation pathway with glycine.

 

Option C. Benzoyl lactate: Benzoyl lactate is not a known intermediate or product in the metabolic pathway of benzoic acid. Lactate is typically associated with anaerobic metabolism, not detoxification pathways.

 

Option D. Benzoyl glutamine: While glutamine is involved in ammonia detoxification and urea cycle processes, it does not conjugate with benzoic acid to form hippuric acid. The conjugating partner in this case is glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hippuric acid is formed by the conjugation of benzoic acid with glycine in the liver and is excreted in urine. 
  • It serves as a clinical marker for toluene exposure or benzoic acid metabolism.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy presents with a right-sided acute scrotal pain. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the most common anatomical abnormality responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High investment of tunica vaginalis

 

  • This condition is the most common anatomical abnormality associated with testicular torsion. It is often referred to as the "bell-clapper deformity".
  • In this abnormality, the tunica vaginalis is abnormally high, allowing the testis to move freely like a clapper in a bell. 
  • This excessive mobility predisposes the testis to rotate around its spermatic cord, leading to torsion and subsequent vascular compromise.
  • Testicular torsion presents with:
    • Sudden, severe scrotal pain.
    • Negative Prehn’s sign: Elevating the testis worsens the pain (Prehn’s sign differentiates torsion from epididymo-orchitis where pain decreases).
    • Swelling, erythema, and absent blood flow on Doppler ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inverted testis: Inversion refers to abnormal positioning of the testis, where it lies transversely or upside down. This positioning can predispose the testis to torsion but is not as common as the "bell-clapper" deformity.

 

Option B. Loose epididymis: A separation or looseness between the epididymis and the testis may allow torsion of the testis on its pedicle. While this can occur, it is less common than a high investment of the tunica vaginalis.

 

Option D. All of these: While all the mentioned abnormalities can contribute to testicular torsion, high investment of the tunica vaginalis remains the most common cause in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis, also called the bell-clapper deformity, is the most common anatomical abnormality leading to testicular torsion.
  • It allows excessive testicular mobility, causing rotation around the spermatic cord, vascular compromise, and acute scrotal pain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a positive family history of thalassemia presents for evaluation prior to pregnancy. Laboratory studies reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm a diagnosis of thalassemia trait?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated HbA2

 

  • The best test to confirm a diagnosis of thalassemia trait is the measurement of hemoglobin fractions via hemoglobin electrophoresis or high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). 
  • In beta-thalassemia trait, the most characteristic finding is an elevated HbA2 level (>3.5%).
    • HbA2 is a minor hemoglobin component made of 2 alpha and 2 delta chains. In beta-thalassemia trait, reduced beta-globin chain synthesis causes a compensatory increase in delta-globin chain production, leading to increased HbA2.
    • Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the gold standard for diagnosis of beta-thalassemia trait and provides a definitive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peripheral smear: A peripheral smear in thalassemia trait typically shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells, target cells, and basophilic stippling. While supportive, it is not diagnostic of thalassemia trait, as similar findings are seen in iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Reticulocytosis: Reticulocytosis (elevated reticulocyte count) occurs when there is increased red blood cell production, as seen in hemolytic anemia or blood loss. In thalassemia trait, reticulocyte counts are usually normal or slightly elevated, as it is a mild, compensated anemia.

 

Option D. NESTROFT test: The NESTROFT test (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a screening test for thalassemia. It identifies increased osmotic fragility of red blood cells. While it is useful as a screening tool in resource-limited settings, it is not confirmatory for thalassemia trait.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The best confirmatory test for beta-thalassemia trait is the measurement of hemoglobin fractions using hemoglobin electrophoresis or HPLC, which reveals elevated HbA2 levels (>3.5%).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents with acute chest pain radiating to his left arm. ECG shows ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF, and troponin levels are elevated. Which test can detect areas of reversible myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium scan

 

  • A thallium scan (myocardial perfusion imaging) is a non-invasive test that detects areas of reversible myocardial ischemia. 
  • It involves injecting a radioactive tracer, such as thallium-201 or technetium, which evaluates blood flow to the myocardium during stress and rest. 
  • Ischemic areas take up less tracer during stress (appearing as "cold spots"), but these regions show uptake during rest if the ischemia is reversible. 
  • This distinguishes viable myocardium from infarcted (non-viable) tissue, making it particularly valuable in assessing ischemic heart disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coronary angiography: Coronary angiography identifies coronary artery stenosis or occlusion, making it the gold standard for diagnosing coronary artery disease. However, it does not directly assess myocardial viability or differentiate between reversible ischemia and infarction.

 

Option C. Cardiac MRI: Cardiac MRI can identify myocardial viability using late gadolinium enhancement but is not typically used as a first-line test for detecting reversible ischemia in acute settings.

 

Option D. CT coronary angiography: CT coronary angiography visualizes coronary arteries to detect atherosclerosis and stenosis. While it is useful for evaluating coronary anatomy, it does not assess myocardial perfusion or viability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A thallium scan (myocardial perfusion imaging) detects areas of reversible myocardial ischemia by evaluating blood flow to the myocardium during stress and at rest. 
  • It helps differentiate between ischemic but viable tissue and infarcted myocardium.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is correct?


Assertion (A): Diffuse nebular opacity interferes more with vision.


Reason (R): Iris details cannot be seen through it.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false.

 

  • Assertion (A): Diffuse nebular opacity interferes more with vision.
    • True. Diffuse nebular opacity refers to a hazy or clouded cornea. Because it affects a larger portion of the cornea, it scatters incoming light and interferes significantly with vision. This is true for many corneal conditions such as corneal dystrophies, infections, and trauma.
  • Reason (R): Iris details cannot be seen through it.
    • False. While diffuse nebular opacity blurs vision, it does not completely block the visibility of the iris. The iris can still be seen, although its details may be obscured. A more dense opacity or total opacity (such as in corneal scarring or advanced cataract) could potentially block the iris from view, but diffuse nebular opacity alone usually does not do so completely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diffuse nebular opacity affects vision primarily by scattering light, and while it reduces clarity, it does not prevent the iris from being seen unless the opacity is more severe or dense. 
  • The reasoning behind the assertion should be questioned carefully to differentiate between different levels of opacity and their effects on ocular structures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of atrial fibrillation is started on two medications, nadolol and amiodarone, to manage his condition. Both drugs have a similar pharmacological effect, particularly at therapeutic doses. Which of the following is the common mechanism of action of these drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta-adrenoceptors

 

  • Both nadolol and amiodarone share a common effect on the beta-adrenoceptors.
    • Nadolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that works by blocking beta-1 and beta-2 receptors, leading to a reduction in heart rate and contractility, which helps in controlling arrhythmias.
    • Amiodarone, though primarily classified as a class III antiarrhythmic (potassium channel blocker), also has significant beta-blocking properties. This contributes to its ability to slow down the heart rate and control arrhythmias.
    • Together, these drugs help manage arrhythmias by inhibiting beta-adrenoceptor activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac Na channels: While amiodarone does have sodium channel blocking properties, nadolol does not, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Cardiac K channels: Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic that primarily blocks potassium channels to prolong repolarization, but nadolol does not affect K channels significantly.

 

Option D. Alpha-adrenoceptors: Neither nadolol nor amiodarone has a significant effect on alpha-adrenoceptors at therapeutic doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both nadolol and amiodarone block beta-adrenoceptors at therapeutic doses, which contributes to their antiarrhythmic effects.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of epilepsy and hypertension presents with progressive shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough. Pulmonary function tests show restrictive lung disease, and a chest CT scan reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following medications is least likely to be responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha-methyldopa

 

  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is a known complication of several medications, but alpha-methyldopa is least commonly associated with this side effect. 
  • This antihypertensive drug is more often linked to drug-induced lupus or hemolytic anemia rather than pulmonary toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carmustine: Carmustine is a nitrosourea chemotherapeutic agent that is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis as a long-term complication. It is associated with restrictive lung disease, especially with high cumulative doses or prolonged therapy.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone, an antiarrhythmic medication, is a well-known cause of drug-induced interstitial lung disease. It induces pulmonary fibrosis in a dose-dependent manner, particularly with doses exceeding 400 mg/day over a prolonged period.

 

Option C. Busulfan: Busulfan, an alkylating agent used in hematologic malignancies, is associated with pulmonary fibrosis, often referred to as "busulfan lung." Its mechanism involves oxidative stress and chronic inflammation in the lung parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Several medications, including carmustine, amiodarone, and busulfan, are known to cause interstitial lung disease and pulmonary fibrosis. 
  • Alpha-methyldopa, while associated with other adverse effects, is not implicated in pulmonary toxicity and is the least likely medication to cause these findings.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and spotting at 7 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound confirms a missed miscarriage. She has multiple large uterine fibroids and consents to medical management. What is the most appropriate approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mifepristone followed by misoprostol

 

  • Medical management of missed miscarriage is best achieved with mifepristone followed by misoprostol. 
  • Mifepristone (a progesterone antagonist) primes the uterus by softening the cervix and initiating decidual necrosis, while misoprostol (a prostaglandin) induces uterine contractions for expulsion. 
  • This sequence is highly effective and safer for patients with uterine fibroids compared to surgical methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction and evacuation: Riskier in patients with large fibroids due to higher chances of uterine injury.

 

Option C. Misoprostol followed by mifepristone: Less effective sequence than mifepristone first.

 

Option D. Misoprostol alone: Misoprostol alone is less effective than the combination regimen, as it lacks the preparatory effect of mifepristone on the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The optimal management of a missed miscarriage is mifepristone followed by misoprostol, particularly in patients with complicating factors like uterine fibroids.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing, a weak cry, and generalized weakness. The child’s mother reports that the infant consumed honey several days ago. On examination, the infant is floppy, with a weak cry and poor muscle tone. The diagnosis of infant botulism is made. Which of the following adenovirus serotypes is most commonly associated with diarrhea in infants and would be a potential differential diagnosis for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 40, 41

 

  • Adenovirus serotypes 40 and 41 are commonly associated with diarrhea in infants, particularly causing viral gastroenteritis. 
  • In this case, while the presentation is suggestive of infant botulism, adenovirus serotypes 40 and 41 could present with similar gastrointestinal symptoms in an infant, making them a potential differential diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8, 19, 37: These serotypes are linked to epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (Shepard's eye), which causes eye infections, not gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 5: These serotypes are typically responsible for upper respiratory tract infections, not gastrointestinal issues like diarrhea.

 

Option D. 3, 7, 14: These serotypes cause pharyngoconjunctival fever, which is characterized by conjunctivitis and pharyngitis, not diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenovirus serotypes 40 and 41 are commonly associated with diarrhea in infants.

choices.text: Increase life expectancy at birth to 75 years
Achieve TB cure rate greater than 85% with a goal for TB elimination
Reduce premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases by 25%
Increase utilization of public health facilities by 50%

questions.text: The National Health Policy 2017 of India outlines several ambitious targets to be achieved by 2025. Which of the following targets is not part of the goals for health improvements by 2025 as per the NHP 2017?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase life expectancy at birth to 75 years

 

  • The National Health Policy 2017 (NHP 2017) aims to increase life expectancy at birth to 70 years by 2025, not 75 years. 
  • This is one of the key health goals set by the policy, which also includes numerous other targets related to health outcomes and healthcare utilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Achieve TB cure rate greater than 85% with a goal for TB elimination: This is a key target under the NHP 2017. The policy sets an ambitious target of achieving a TB cure rate of >85% and eliminating TB altogether.

 

Option C. Reduce premature mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases by 25%: This is a major target of the NHP 2017. It aims to reduce premature mortality due to non-communicable diseases by 25% by 2025.

 

Option D. Increase utilization of public health facilities by 50%: The NHP 2017 aims to increase the utilization of public health facilities by 50% by 2025 to improve access to healthcare services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The target for life expectancy at birth in the National Health Policy 2017 is to increase it to 70 years by 2025, not 75 years.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with concerns about poor weight gain and swelling in the legs. On examination, the child appears underweight, with a BMI suggestive of mild malnutrition, but there is significant bilateral pedal edema. Blood investigations show hypoalbuminemia. To assess the severity of protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the pediatrician evaluates several clinical and anthropometric parameters. Which of the following findings would exclusively rule out severe protein-energy malnutrition (PEM)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal lean body mass

 

  • Lean body mass is a direct reflection of protein stores in the body. 
  • In severe protein-energy malnutrition, lean body mass is invariably reduced due to catabolism of body protein to provide energy and amino acids. 
  • If lean body mass is normal, it strongly indicates the absence of severe PEM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BMI > 17: BMI can be falsely elevated in conditions like edema or fluid retention, making it unreliable for ruling out PEM in such cases.

 

Option C. Normal skin fold thickness: Skin fold thickness may also be falsely elevated in the presence of edema, even in malnourished individuals.

 

Option D. Normal extracellular fluid (ECF) volume: ECF volume may remain preserved or normal in cases of malnutrition, especially in edematous states like kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that lean body mass is a reliable marker of nutritional status and its preservation rules out severe protein-energy malnutrition. 
  • BMI, skin fold thickness, and ECF volume may be affected by edema and are less specific for ruling out PEM.

questions.text: A 60-year-old intubated male on vasopressin and norepinephrine infusions, with a Foley catheter, develops persistent high-grade fevers on postoperative day 6. His WBC count is 21,700/mm³. Blood cultures from the central line on postoperative day 9 show coagulase-negative cocci in clusters, and subsequent cultures from the peripheral IV line on postoperative day 11 show the same organism. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Central line-associated bloodstream infection

 

  • The presence of coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis) in blood cultures from both the central line and peripheral line strongly suggests a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). 
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci are a common cause of bloodstream infections associated with intravascular devices, particularly in critically ill, intubated patients. 
  • The timeline, fever, and leukocytosis further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: This could cause fever and leukocytosis in an intubated patient, but the findings of positive blood cultures are more specific to a bloodstream infection.

 

Option C. Catheter-associated urinary tract infection: While a Foley catheter could cause a UTI, there are no specific urinary symptoms or findings in this patient to suggest this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Bowel ischemia: This is less likely in the absence of abdominal symptoms or other imaging/laboratory findings consistent with bowel ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI) are a common and serious complication in critically ill patients with central lines. 
  • They often present with fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures, particularly with organisms like coagulase-negative staphylococci.

questions.text:
Threshold retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is characterized by which of the following criteria?

 

  1. 8 total, or 5 confluent, clock hours of extra-retinal neovascularization
  2. Plus disease
  3. Zone I or II disease
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3
