  • Threshold retinopathy of prematurity refers to the stage of ROP that is associated with a high risk of progression to retinal detachment, making it a critical stage for intervention, often requiring laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections. The criteria for threshold ROP include:
    1. 8 total, or 5 confluent, clock hours of extra-retinal neovascularization: This refers to the extent of neovascularization (abnormal new blood vessels) around the retina, which is a defining feature of threshold ROP. Neovascularization occurring in 8 or more clock hours of the retina, or 5 or more clock hours in a contiguous (confluent) area, is considered threshold ROP.
    2. Plus disease: This term describes the dilation and tortuosity of the retinal blood vessels, particularly in the posterior pole, which is an indication of severe disease and a sign that ROP is worsening. Plus disease is an essential characteristic of threshold ROP and requires immediate intervention.
    3. Zone I or II disease: The classification of ROP involves dividing the retina into three zones. Zone I represents the area around the optic nerve, and Zone II extends to the periphery of the retina. Threshold ROP is typically present in Zone I or II, where the neovascularization and plus disease are most severe.
  • All three criteria—extra-retinal neovascularization, plus disease, and involvement of Zones I or II—are necessary to diagnose threshold ROP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Threshold retinopathy of prematurity is characterized by 8 total or 5 confluent clock hours of extra-retinal neovascularization, the presence of plus disease, and involvement of Zone I or II disease. 
  • This stage requires prompt intervention to prevent further complications, such as retinal detachment.

choices.text: Inhibits the formation of intracellular viral forms of orthopoxviruses.
Targets the viral p37 protein, preventing viral envelopment and systemic spread.
Suppresses the replication of the variola virus within the host cell.
Inhibits viral entry into host cells by blocking the viral fusion protein.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with monkeypox and is started on tecovirimat for treatment. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of tecovirimat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Targets the viral p37 protein, preventing viral envelopment and systemic spread.

 

  • Tecovirimat is an antiviral medication that targets the orthopoxvirus p37 protein, which is necessary for the virus's envelopment. 
  • By inhibiting this protein, tecovirimat prevents the formation of extracellular viral particles, which are responsible for the systemic spread of the infection. 
  • It does not affect the intracellular forms of the virus, which are responsible for replication inside the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits the formation of intracellular viral forms of orthopoxviruses: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not affect the intracellular forms of the virus but targets the viral p37 protein involved in the formation of extracellular forms.

 

Option C. Suppresses the replication of the variola virus within the host cell: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not directly inhibit viral replication; instead, it prevents the production of extracellular viral particles by targeting the p37 protein.

 

Option D. Inhibits viral entry into host cells by blocking the viral fusion protein: This is incorrect. Tecovirimat does not block viral entry. It works by preventing the envelopment of the virus, thus halting the release of infectious viral particles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tecovirimat targets the orthopoxvirus p37 protein, inhibiting the envelopment of the virus and preventing the release of extracellular viral particles responsible for the systemic spread of the infection.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female with oily skin presents with severe, nodulocystic acne, characterized by large inflamed nodules and cystic lesions on the face, as shown in the image. The acne has been persistent and unresponsive to topical treatments. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral isotretinoin

 

  • Oral isotretinoin is the first-line treatment for severe, nodulocystic acne, characterized by deep, inflamed nodules and cysts, as seen in this patient. 
  • It addresses all major causes of acne by reducing sebaceous gland size and sebum production, normalizing keratinization, decreasing inflammation, and inhibiting Propionibacterium acnes. 
  • Given the severity of the acne and the risk of permanent scarring, isotretinoin is the most appropriate and effective treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Topical clindamycin: Topical clindamycin is used for mild to moderate inflammatory acne. It is insufficient as monotherapy for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Option C. Oral steroids: Oral steroids may help in acute, severe inflammatory conditions (e.g., acne fulminans), but they are not appropriate for routine treatment of nodulocystic acne. Steroids can exacerbate acne when used chronically.

 

Option D. Topical retinoids: Topical retinoids are effective for mild to moderate acne by preventing comedone formation. However, they are not potent enough for severe, deep nodulocystic acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral isotretinoin is the first-line treatment for severe, nodulocystic acne. It works by reducing sebum production, normalizing keratinization, decreasing inflammation, and inhibiting Propionibacterium acnes.

choices.text: 4–10 times broader than the medulla
Thin in comparison to the medulla

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the typical relationship between the cortex and the medulla in human hair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4–10 times broader than the medulla

 

  • In human hair, the cortex is significantly broader than the medulla, usually by a factor of 4–10 times. 
  • The cortex contains the bulk of the hair's pigment (melanin) and contributes to the hair’s strength and flexibility. 
  • The medulla, on the other hand, is the central, often hollow core of the hair, and is either absent or much thinner in finer hair types.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human and animal hair

choices.text: Decreased serum potassium levels due to increased renal potassium excretion
Increased risk of hyperglycemic ketoacidosis in non-diabetic individuals
Enhanced renal sodium reabsorption leading to increased blood pressure
Decreased risk of cardiovascular events in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes is prescribed dapagliflozin. Which of the following additional effects of dapagliflozin is most likely to occur due to its pharmacologic action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased risk of cardiovascular events in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

 

  • Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, primarily used for managing type 2 diabetes by promoting glucosuria and inhibiting glucose reabsorption in the kidneys. 
  • In addition to its glucose-lowering effects, it has been shown to offer significant cardiovascular benefits, especially in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). 
  • Recent clinical trials, such as the DAPA-HF trial, have demonstrated that dapagliflozin significantly reduces the risk of hospitalization for heart failure and cardiovascular death in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased serum potassium levels due to increased renal potassium excretion: Dapagliflozin does not typically cause significant potassium loss. While diuretics (especially loop diuretics or thiazides) can lead to hypokalemia, dapagliflozin does not have a direct diuretic effect strong enough to reduce potassium levels significantly.

 

Option B. Increased risk of hyperglycemic ketoacidosis in non-diabetic individuals: Although SGLT2 inhibitors can increase the risk of euglycemic ketoacidosis in patients with type 1 diabetes, this risk is not commonly associated with non-diabetic individuals. The occurrence of ketoacidosis in non-diabetic patients using SGLT2 inhibitors is rare and does not present as a typical adverse effect.

 

Option C. Enhanced renal sodium reabsorption leading to increased blood pressure: Dapagliflozin actually decreases renal sodium reabsorption, leading to a mild diuretic effect and a reduction in blood pressure. This mechanism contributes to its beneficial effects on patients with heart failure and diabetes, rather than increasing blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dapagliflozin not only lowers blood glucose in type 2 diabetes but also reduces cardiovascular events and hospitalizations for heart failure in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

questions.text:
Match the Nobel Laureates with their respective discoveries. 

 

List I


a. Sir Ronald Ross
b. Sir Godfrey N. Hounsfield
c. F.G. Banting & J.J.R. McLeod
d. Har Gobind Khorana

 

List II


I. Insulin
II. CT scan
III. Life cycle of Plasmodium
IV. Interpretation of genetic code
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a-III, b-II, c-I, d-IV

 

  • a. Sir Ronald Ross is credited with discovering the III. life cycle of Plasmodium, which is responsible for malaria.
  • b. Sir Godfrey N. Hounsfield developed the II. CT scan, a breakthrough in medical imaging.
  • c. F.G. Banting & J.J.R. McLeod are known for their discovery of I. insulin, a hormone vital for regulating blood sugar.
  • d. Har Gobind Khorana is famous for his work on the IV. interpretation of the genetic code, contributing significantly to molecular biology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sir Ronald Ross discovered the life cycle of Plasmodium
  • Sir Godfrey N. Hounsfield developed the CT scan
  • F.G. Banting & J.J.R. McLeod discovered insulin
  • Har Gobind Khorana interpreted the genetic code.

choices.text: Increased likelihood of diagnosing PE in the early stage
Increased negative predictive value (NPV) for PE

questions.text:
A 60-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents with chest pain and dyspnea. The physician is concerned about a pulmonary embolism (PE) and orders two diagnostic tests:

 

  1. D-dimer test
  2. CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA)

 

The tests are ordered in parallel to confirm the diagnosis of PE. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of performing both tests together?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased negative predictive value (NPV) for PE

 

  • When parallel testing is performed, the NPV is typically increased. This is because if both tests are negative (i.e., negative D-dimer and negative CTPA), the likelihood of the patient truly being free of the disease (in this case, pulmonary embolism) is very high. 
  • The negative result from either test rules out the disease with greater confidence.
  • Negative predictive value (NPV) refers to the probability that a patient who tests negative actually does not have the disease. In this scenario, if both the D-dimer test and the CTPA are negative, the NPV for ruling out PE increases, and the physician can be more confident that the patient does not have PE.
  • Parallel testing is often used when ruling out a serious condition, like PE, as it increases the accuracy of identifying patients who are disease-free.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased likelihood of diagnosing PE in the early stage: This is incorrect. Parallel testing increases the ability to rule out disease (i.e., increases NPV), but it does not specifically increase the likelihood of diagnosing disease in the early stage. This would be more related to sensitivity or early-stage testing.

 

Option B. Decreased sensitivity for detecting PE: This is incorrect. Sensitivity would generally increase with parallel testing, as either test can detect disease. A negative result from both tests significantly reduces the likelihood of PE, but sensitivity is about detecting true positives, not ruling out disease.

 

Option D. Increased specificity for PE diagnosis: This is incorrect. While specificity can be improved in certain diagnostic strategies, parallel testing does not inherently increase specificity. It may decrease specificity because a false positive from one test could lead to a false positive result overall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In parallel testing, the negative predictive value (NPV) is increased when two tests are used together to rule out a disease. 
  • This is particularly useful for conditions like pulmonary embolism, where negative results from both tests provide a high level of confidence in excluding the disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of fever, headache, and malaise. On physical examination, his temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), and he has a slow heart rate of 58 beats per minute. The rest of his physical examination is notable for a faint maculopapular rash over his torso and no obvious source of infection. A diagnosis of yellow fever is suspected based on the clinical presentation, and laboratory tests confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following clinical findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Faget’s sign

 

  • Faget's sign is characterized by fever with bradycardia (a slow heart rate) and is most commonly associated with yellow fever, a viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the yellow fever virus (YFV), transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • The hallmark of Faget's sign is the paradoxical combination of a high fever and a relatively slow heart rate (bradycardia), which contrasts with the expected tachycardia that typically accompanies fever from most other infectious causes.
  • Faget’s sign is not specific to yellow fever, but it is most commonly seen in this condition and can help differentiate it from other febrile illnesses. 
  • This finding is thought to be due to the viral effects on the autonomic nervous system, particularly the vagal tone, resulting in a lower heart rate despite the elevated body temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brudzinski’s sign: Brudzinski’s sign is a physical finding that is associated with meningeal irritation, commonly seen in meningitis. It is positive when a patient involuntarily flexes their knees when the neck is flexed. This sign is unrelated to yellow fever and would not be present in this patient.

 

Option C. Romberg sign: The Romberg test is used to assess proprioception and balance, primarily in patients with neurological issues such as vestibular or cerebellar disorders. It is not related to fever or yellow fever, and thus would not be relevant in this case.

 

Option D. Kernig’s sign: Kernig’s sign is another sign of meningeal irritation, commonly seen in bacterial meningitis. It is positive when a patient experiences pain and resistance when trying to straighten the leg while the hip is flexed. Like Brudzinski’s sign, this is unrelated to yellow fever and would not be expected in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Faget’s sign (fever with bradycardia) is a clinical finding most commonly associated with yellow fever. It helps to distinguish yellow fever from other febrile illnesses, where tachycardia is typically present with fever.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid
Conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following reactions represents an anaplerotic process?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate

 

  • An anaplerotic reaction is a metabolic process that replenishes intermediates of the TCA cycle. 
  • The conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, catalyzed by the enzyme pyruvate carboxylase, is a key anaplerotic reaction. 
  • Oxaloacetate is a crucial intermediate in the TCA cycle, ensuring its continuation during periods of high energy demand or depletion of cycle intermediates.
  • This reaction requires biotin as a coenzyme and ATP. It is vital in conditions where oxaloacetate levels are reduced, such as during gluconeogenesis or prolonged fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion of pyruvate to acetaldehyde: This reaction occurs during anaerobic fermentation in certain microorganisms, such as yeast, but it is not relevant in humans and does not replenish TCA cycle intermediates.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid: This reaction, catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase, occurs during anaerobic metabolism to regenerate NAD+ for glycolysis. However, it does not produce TCA cycle intermediates and is not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA: This reaction, catalyzed by pyruvate dehydrogenase, produces acetyl CoA, which enters the TCA cycle. However, acetyl CoA is a substrate for the cycle and not an intermediate, so this reaction is not considered an anaplerotic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An anaplerotic reaction replenishes intermediates of the TCA cycle. The conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase, is a key anaplerotic reaction critical for maintaining the TCA cycle's functionality during energy demand.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric neurology clinic with a history of recurrent seizures since early childhood. The seizures are characterized by abrupt loss of consciousness followed by periods of confusion. The child's developmental milestones are significantly delayed, and recent imaging studies reveal atrophy of the left cerebral hemisphere. The neurologist aims to determine the most likely epileptic syndrome associated with these clinical and radiological findings. Which epileptic syndrome is most likely associated with left hemispheric atrophy in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dyke-Davidson-Masson syndrome

 

  • Dyke-Davidson-Masson syndrome is characterized by cerebral hemiatrophy or hypoplasia, typically resulting from an insult to the central nervous system during the fetal period or early childhood. 
  • This condition is associated with compensatory ipsilateral calvarial hypertrophy. 
  • Children with this syndrome often present with seizures, developmental delays, and hemiparesis. 
  • The presence of left hemispheric atrophy on imaging strongly points toward Dyke-Davidson-Masson syndrome as the underlying epileptic syndrome in this clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet syndrome: Dravet syndrome is a severe form of epilepsy that begins in infancy, often triggered by fever. It is associated with generalized seizures, developmental delays, and a high risk of status epilepticus. Unlike Dyke-Davidson-Masson syndrome, Dravet does not typically involve cerebral hemiatrophy.

 

Option B. West syndrome: West syndrome, also known as infantile spasms, presents in early infancy with a specific type of seizure (spasms), developmental regression, and a characteristic EEG pattern called hypsarrhythmia. It is not specifically associated with unilateral cerebral atrophy.

 

Option C. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a childhood-onset epileptic encephalopathy characterized by multiple seizure types, cognitive impairment, and a specific EEG pattern. While it involves severe epilepsy and developmental delays, it does not specifically involve hemispheric atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing Dyke-Davidson-Masson syndrome is essential when evaluating a child with refractory epilepsy and unilateral cerebral atrophy on imaging. 
  • Understanding the distinct clinical and radiological features of this syndrome aids in accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of the associated epileptic conditions.

questions.text: In the context of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, which of the following factors does not affect the genetic equilibrium of a population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Random mating

 

  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium assumes that certain conditions are met for a population to maintain genetic stability. 
  • These conditions include no mutations, no migration, a large population size, random mating, and no natural selection. 
  • Random mating does not disrupt equilibrium; in fact, it is one of the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg model. 
  • However, factors such as small population size (leading to genetic drift), mutations, and gene outflow (migration) can disrupt the equilibrium and change allele frequencies in a population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small population: A small population violates the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium by increasing the effects of genetic drift, which can cause random changes in allele frequencies, leading to a departure from equilibrium.

 

Option C. Mutations: Mutations introduce new genetic variations and can alter allele frequencies, thus disrupting Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Option D. Gene outflow: Gene outflow, or migration (the movement of individuals or their genetic material into or out of a population), alters allele frequencies by introducing or removing genes, disrupting equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Random mating is a condition required for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, and does not affect genetic equilibrium, unlike factors such as small population size, mutations, and gene outflow.

choices.text: Done in primary survey of trauma
Reliably excludes injury in penetrating trauma
Cannot reliably detect 80 ml of free blood

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the utility of eFAST in trauma patients:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reliably excludes injury in penetrating trauma

 

  • In the context of trauma care, the extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST) is a valuable diagnostic tool with certain limitations. Here's an assessment of the given statements:
  • This statement is incorrect. eFAST is useful for detecting free fluid that may indicate bleeding, but it cannot reliably exclude injury, especially in cases of penetrating trauma where small or complex injuries may not be associated with significant fluid collections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Done in primary survey of trauma: This statement is correct. eFAST is non-invasive, can be quickly performed at the bedside, and does not interfere with resuscitative efforts.

 

Option C. Cannot reliably detect 80 ml of free blood: This statement is correct. eFAST has a limit in sensitivity and may not detect small amounts of free blood, typically below 100 ml.

 

Option D. Unreliable for assessment of retroperitoneum: This statement is correct. eFAST is limited in its ability to assess the retroperitoneal space due to overlying structures and the depth of the area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the utility and limitations of eFAST in trauma care. 
  • eFAST is a rapid, non-invasive imaging technique that is useful during resuscitation for detecting free fluid indicative of bleeding. 
  • However, it cannot reliably exclude injury, especially in penetrating trauma, does not detect small volumes of fluid well, is not reliable for retroperitoneal assessments, and is operator-dependent.

choices.text: Immunity lasts for 1 year and requires annual boosters
Immunity lasts for life after a single dose, with protection starting from 7 days
Immunity lasts for 35 years, after which a booster is required
Immunity is temporary, requiring a booster dose every 5 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the immunological profile of individuals after a single dose of the Yellow Fever vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunity lasts for life after a single dose, with protection starting from 7 days

 

  • The Yellow Fever vaccine provides lifetime immunity after a single dose, with protection beginning within 7 days of vaccination. 
  • This long-lasting immunity does not require boosters, except in cases of significant outbreaks or travel to endemic regions where immunity verification is needed. 
  • The vaccine certificate is considered valid for life after the first dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

YF vaccination:

 

  • Immunity lasts: From 7 days of Vaccination till 35 years 
  • WHO recommended validity of Vaccination Certificate for International travel: from 10 days to lifelong
  • YF vaccine is the only Live vaccine that can be administered in Pregnancy (if there is risk of exposure)
  • Yellow Fever Vaccine and Cholera Vaccine cannot be given together: Maintain a gap of 3 weeks or more between them

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of persistent hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and weight loss is diagnosed with advanced cancer. As part of his treatment, he undergoes a surgical procedure. Following surgery, he is fitted with the device shown in the image. What is the most likely surgical procedure he underwent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngectomy

 

  • The patient underwent a total laryngectomy, which involves removing the larynx and creating a permanent tracheostoma by bringing the trachea directly to the skin surface. 
  • This procedure is typically performed for advanced laryngeal cancer.

 

Key points:

 

  • After laryngectomy, the patient's ability to speak is compromised because the vocal cords are removed along with the larynx.
  • The device shown in the image is a tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP).
  • This device is used for voice rehabilitation. 
  • It is inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to allow airflow into the esophagus, enabling the patient to produce speech.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: A tracheostomy involves creating a temporary or permanent opening in the trachea but does not include removal of the larynx. It is typically used for airway management, not for advanced laryngeal cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Cricothyroidotomy: Cricothyroidotomy is an emergency airway procedure involving a temporary opening in the cricothyroid membrane. It is not a permanent solution or associated with voice rehabilitation.

 

Option D. Thyroidectomy: Thyroidectomy involves removal of the thyroid gland, commonly for thyroid cancer or goiter. It does not involve creating a tracheal opening or affect the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laryngectomy involves removal of the larynx and creation of a permanent tracheostoma. 
  • Post-operatively, a tracheoesophageal prosthesis can be used for voice rehabilitation to enable speech.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a history of intermittent fever for the past 4 years and is diagnosed with chronic brucellosis. Which of the following serological tests would be least helpful in diagnosing brucellosis at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard Agglutination Test

 

  • The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) is primarily used to detect IgM antibodies in the acute phase of brucellosis, which appear 7–10 days after infection. 
  • In chronic brucellosis, the IgM antibodies gradually decline and are replaced by IgG antibodies, which persist. 
  • Therefore, SAT is least helpful in the chronic phase, as it is not sensitive enough to detect the predominance of IgG antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2 Mercaptoethanol Test: This test is used to differentiate IgM from IgG antibodies in chronic brucellosis. It helps in neutralizing IgM antibodies, leaving IgG antibodies detectable, which is useful in chronic cases where IgG persists.

 

Option C. Complement Fixation Test: This test detects both IgG and IgM antibodies and is useful in diagnosing brucellosis in both acute and chronic phases. It is sensitive to IgG, making it effective in detecting chronic infections where IgG is the dominant antibody.

 

Option D. Coomb's Test: The Coomb’s test is used to detect autoimmune hemolytic anemia and is not relevant for diagnosing brucellosis. It does not detect Brucella antibodies and is used for identifying antibodies against red blood cells, not infectious agents like Brucella.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In chronic brucellosis, IgG antibodies persist, while IgM antibodies decrease. 
  • The Standard Agglutination Test, which detects IgM, is therefore not helpful for diagnosing chronic infection. 
  • Instead, tests like the 2 Mercaptoethanol Test and Complement Fixation Test are more appropriate for detecting IgG antibodies in chronic cases.

questions.text: Which of the following interferons is produced predominantly by fibroblasts and is classified as a Type I interferon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IFN-β

 

  • IFN-β (Interferon-beta) is produced primarily by fibroblasts and is classified as a Type I interferon, similar to IFN-α. 
  • It is induced by viral infections and serves key functions in the antiviral immune response, including stimulating MHC-I expression and antiproliferative effects. 
  • Though IFN-α and IFN-β share many similarities, they differ in the types of cells they are produced by, with IFN-β being more fibroblast-derived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-α: IFN-α is produced by macrophages and many other cell types in response to viral infections, but IFN-β is primarily produced by fibroblasts, not macrophages.

 

Option C. IFN-ϒ: IFN-ϒ is a Type II interferon produced mainly by Th1 cells, CD8 T cells, and NK cells, and is involved in immune regulation rather than antiviral immunity.

 

Option D. IFN-λ: IFN-λ is produced in response to infections and is important in mucosal immunity but is not primarily produced by fibroblasts and is not classified under Type I interferons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interferons is host-derived proteins that play a crucial role in the immune response to viral infection. Type & properties of IFN -

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent ear and sinus infections, easy bruising, and a persistent rash. On examination, the child has an eczematous rash and petechiae. Laboratory investigations reveal thrombocytopenia with small platelets. His family history reveals a maternal uncle who also had recurrent infections and died at a young age. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

 

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS gene on chromosome Xp11. 
  • It is characterized by the classic triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (small platelets), and immunodeficiency leading to recurrent infections. 
  • The immunodeficiency is due to defective T-cell function and impaired antibody production. 
  • The family history of male relatives with similar symptoms suggests an X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID): Incorrect. SCID presents with profound immunodeficiency and severe infections early in life, but it does not feature thrombocytopenia or an eczematous rash.

 

Option B. Job syndrome: Incorrect. Job syndrome (hyper-IgE syndrome) presents with recurrent infections, particularly abscesses, eczema, and elevated IgE levels, but thrombocytopenia is not a feature.

 

Option C. Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia: Incorrect. Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia) involves recurrent infections due to defective B-cell maturation and absent immunoglobulins. However, it does not involve thrombocytopenia or eczema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome as a condition characterized by the triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia with small platelets, and immunodeficiency. 
  • Understanding its X-linked inheritance and differentiation from other immunodeficiency disorders is critical for diagnosis and management.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old infant presents with excessive tearing and mucus discharge from the eye, which has been persistent since birth. On examination, a nasolacrimal duct obstruction is suspected. What is the most common site of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction?

 

  1. Upper canaliculus
  2. Lower canaliculus
  3. Common canaliculus
  4. Valve of Hasner
  5. Middle turbinate near the canthus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 Only

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) is one of the most common causes of excessive tearing in infants. 
  • The most frequent site of obstruction is at the Valve of Hasner, located at the junction of the nasolacrimal duct and the inferior meatus of the nose. 
  • This anatomical site can remain closed or fail to open after birth, causing tears to accumulate in the eye and leading to symptoms such as excessive tearing (epiphora) and mucus discharge. 
  • The obstruction often resolves on its own by 6-12 months of age, although interventions such as lacrimal duct probing may be required if symptoms persist.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Upper canaliculus: The upper canaliculus typically does not play a primary role in congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. Obstruction here would more likely be secondary to other factors such as eyelid abnormalities or infection.

 

2. Lower canaliculus: Although the lower canaliculus can be involved in more complex cases of nasolacrimal duct obstruction, it is not the most common site of congenital obstruction.

 

3. Common canaliculus: The common canaliculus, where the upper and lower canaliculi join before draining into the nasolacrimal duct, is typically not the site of congenital obstruction. The obstruction is more commonly at the distal end of the nasolacrimal duct, at the Valve of Hasner.

 

5. Middle turbinate near the canthus: The middle turbinate is not a common site of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. Obstruction at the Valve of Hasner is much more frequent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Valve of Hasner is the most common site of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with dietary concerns, seeking advice on which type of fat contains the highest proportion of saturated fatty acids. He is particularly interested in fats used in cooking. Based on the available options, which of the following fats has the highest content of saturated fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coconut oil

 

  • Coconut oil is known for having the highest content of saturated fatty acids among the listed options. 
  • It consists of approximately 90% saturated fat, which is predominantly in the form of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs). 
  • These saturated fats can have different health implications compared to long-chain fatty acids found in other sources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palm oil: Palm oil has a moderate level of saturated fat (about 50%) but not as high as coconut oil. It also contains monounsaturated fats, which make it less saturated overall.

 

Option B. Butter: Butter contains about 63% saturated fat, which is less than coconut oil but still a significant proportion compared to other fats.

 

Option D. Margarine: Margarine, especially the trans-fat-free versions, tends to contain unsaturated fats and may have some saturated fat depending on the processing, but it does not have the high percentage of saturated fatty acids seen in coconut oil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coconut oil contains the highest proportion of saturated fatty acids compared to other commonly used fats like palm oil, butter, and margarine.

choices.text: CMV-specific IgG avidity by enzyme immunoassay
Amniotic fluid for CMV nucleic acid amplification testing

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 22 weeks of gestation presents for evaluation after a routine ultrasound reveals signs suggestive of congenital infection. What is the gold standard test for confirming this fetal CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amniotic fluid for CMV nucleic acid amplification testing

 

  • The gold standard for diagnosing fetal infection with CMV is amniotic fluid for CMV nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), typically using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 
  • This test detects CMV DNA in the amniotic fluid, which indicates direct evidence of fetal infection. 
  • Testing the amniotic fluid is most reliable after 21 weeks of gestation and at least six weeks after maternal primary infection to allow the virus to cross the placenta and accumulate in the amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV-specific IgG avidity by enzyme immunoassay: CMV IgG avidity testing is used to distinguish recent from past maternal CMV infections. Low avidity suggests recent infection, while high avidity indicates an older infection. However, this test does not confirm fetal infection.

 

Option C. Amniotic fluid for viral culture: Viral culture of amniotic fluid is less sensitive and takes longer than nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). Thus, it is not the gold standard for diagnosing fetal CMV infection.

 

Option D. IgG CMV: The presence of IgG CMV indicates maternal immunity to CMV but does not confirm whether the fetus is infected. IgG can cross the placenta and does not differentiate between maternal and fetal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for diagnosing fetal cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of amniotic fluid, which directly detects CMV DNA and confirms fetal infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is being treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate. She has shown poor response to clomiphene alone. Which medication can be added to improve her response to clomiphene?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metformin

 

  • Metformin improves clomiphene response in women with PCOS by addressing insulin resistance, a common underlying factor in PCOS. 
  • Insulin resistance exacerbates hyperandrogenism and disrupts ovulation. 
  • By reducing insulin levels and improving ovarian sensitivity to gonadotropins, metformin enhances the likelihood of ovulation when combined with clomiphene citrate. 
  • This combination is particularly effective in women with obesity or metabolic abnormalities associated with PCOS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA): DHEA is an androgen precursor used in cases of diminished ovarian reserve to improve egg quality. It does not address insulin resistance or ovulatory dysfunction in PCOS and is not appropriate for enhancing clomiphene response.

 

Option C. Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is often used as a first-line ovulation induction agent for PCOS. However, it is not typically combined with clomiphene for poor responders. Metformin is more effective in addressing the underlying insulin resistance that limits clomiphene efficacy.

 

Option D. Insulin: Administering exogenous insulin would exacerbate the hyperinsulinemia already present in PCOS, worsening hyperandrogenism and ovulatory dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metformin is an effective adjunct to clomiphene citrate in treating infertility in women with PCOS. 
  • It improves ovulation rates by addressing insulin resistance, a key pathophysiological feature of PCOS, thereby enhancing the response to ovulation induction therapies.

questions.text: In a sewage treatment plant, the most important factor to focus on for effective treatment is the primary component that needs to be removed or controlled for ensuring the water's safety and cleanliness. What is the most critical factor in the sewage treatment process?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Solids

 

  • The most important factor in sewage treatment is the removal of solids. Solids, including suspended solids and organic matter, need to be effectively removed during the primary and secondary stages of sewage treatment. 
  • This is essential for ensuring that the treated water is safe for discharge or further use, as untreated solids can contain harmful pathogens and contribute to water pollution. 
  • While bacterial count, nitrite, and phosphorus are also important, solids are typically the primary target in sewage treatment processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial count: Incorrect. Although bacterial load is an important consideration, sewage treatment primarily focuses on removing solids to reduce the organic load. Bacterial treatment is part of the secondary treatment phase but not the primary factor.

 

Option C. Nitrite and phosphorus: Incorrect. Nitrite and phosphorus removal is part of advanced treatment processes to prevent eutrophication, but solids removal is the first and most critical step in sewage treatment.

 

Option D. Water content: Incorrect. Water content refers to the liquid phase, which is not typically the focus of sewage treatment. The focus is on removing contaminants like solids and pathogens from the water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most important factor in sewage treatment is the removal of solids, including suspended solids and organic matter, to ensure the water is safe for discharge or reuse.

choices.text: Streak culture by using loop with intermittent heating
Stroke culture (zigzag fashion by straight wire)

questions.text: A microbiologist is setting up a culture for antimicrobial susceptibility testing and bacteriophage typing. Which of the following culture methods would be the most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawn or carpet culture

 

  • Lawn or carpet culture is the appropriate method for performing antimicrobial susceptibility testing using the disk diffusion method, bacteriophage typing, and for producing large amounts of bacterial growth needed for preparation of bacterial antigens and vaccines. 
  • This method involves spreading a bacterial culture evenly over the surface of an agar plate, allowing for uniform bacterial growth across the entire plate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streak culture by using loop with intermittent heating: Incorrect. This is a standard method for obtaining isolated colonies, but it is not ideal for susceptibility testing or bacteriophage typing.

 

Option C. Stroke culture (zigzag fashion by straight wire): Incorrect. Stroke culture is mainly used for tests like citrate, urease, and triple sugar iron (TSI) tests, not for antimicrobial testing or bacteriophage typing.

 

Option D. Stab culture: Incorrect. This method is mainly used for maintaining stock cultures, and for tests like the OF test, mannitol motility medium, and TSI. It is not used for antimicrobial testing or bacteriophage typing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lawn or carpet culture is used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing, bacteriophage typing, and growing large quantities of bacteria for antigens or vaccine preparation.

questions.text: Match the following defense mechanisms with their most appropriate clinical examples:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

  1. Reaction formation (c) Homophobic individual with same-sex attraction: This is correct. Reaction formation occurs when a person expresses the opposite of their true feelings to protect themselves from anxiety or distress. A homophobic individual who is actually attracted to the same sex may react with extreme homophobia to suppress or deny their attraction.
  2. Intellectualization (a) Doctor with cancer discussing pathophysiology without emotion: This is correct. Intellectualization involves focusing on the intellectual or abstract aspects of a situation to avoid dealing with its emotional content. The doctor discussing the pathophysiology of cancer in a detached, unemotional manner exemplifies this defense mechanism.
  3. Displacement (d) Resident scolding intern after being criticized by consultant: This is correct. Displacement involves redirecting emotions or reactions from the original source of stress to a less threatening target. In this case, the resident redirects their frustration from the consultant (the actual source of stress) to the intern, which is a typical example of displacement.
  4. Regression (b) Medical student playing with toys before exam: This is correct. Regression occurs when an individual reverts to childlike behaviors or earlier developmental stages as a way to cope with stress. Playing with toys before an exam represents a regressive response to the anxiety of the upcoming test.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Match the items in List I with the appropriate nutrients from List D. Select the correct answer using the given codes. 

 

List I


a. Papaya fruit
b. Soya beans
c. Ragi
d. Amla fruit

 

 

List D


I. Calcium
II. Vitamin C
III. Protein
IV. Vitamin A
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-IV, b-III, c-I, d-II

 

  • Papaya fruit (a): Papaya is a rich source of Vitamin A (IV). Vitamin A is essential for vision, immune function, and skin health, and papaya contains significant amounts of this vitamin.
  • Soya beans (b): Soya beans are an excellent source of Protein (III). They provide a complete plant-based protein, making them important for vegetarians and vegans.
  • Ragi (c): Ragi is particularly high in Calcium (I), which is essential for bone health. It is a good source of calcium, especially for individuals who may not consume dairy products.
  • Amla fruit (d): Amla, also known as Indian gooseberry, is packed with Vitamin C (II). It is famous for its high vitamin C content, which boosts immune function and overall health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papaya is rich in vitamin A, soya beans are an excellent source of protein, ragi provides calcium, and amla is a high source of vitamin C.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with 8 weeks of amenorrhea presents to the emergency department complaining of vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a gestational sac without visible fetal parts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anembryonic pregnancy

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy, also known as a blighted ovum, is a common cause of early pregnancy loss. It occurs when a fertilized ovum implants into the uterine wall, but the embryo fails to develop. 
  • The ultrasound findings of a gestational sac without fetal parts or a fetal pole confirm this diagnosis. 

 

Common clinical presentations include:

 

  1. Vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain due to the non-viable pregnancy.
  2. A history of amenorrhea, indicating pregnancy, and subsequent findings of pregnancy failure.

 

Ultrasound findings in anembryonic pregnancy are characteristic:

 

  1. A gestational sac within the uterus.
  2. Absence of a fetal pole or visible embryonic parts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Threatened abortion: Threatened abortion refers to vaginal bleeding during early pregnancy without pregnancy loss. In these cases, the gestational sac contains visible fetal parts, and fetal cardiac activity is often observed. The absence of fetal pole in this case rules out threatened abortion.

 

Option B. Hydatidiform mole: Hydatidiform mole, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease, presents with an abnormal gestational sac. On ultrasound, it demonstrates a "snowstorm" pattern due to trophoblastic overgrowth and hydropic villi. This ultrasound finding is absent in the current case, ruling out molar pregnancy.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy occurs when implantation happens outside the uterine cavity, often in the fallopian tube. Ultrasound typically shows no gestational sac in the uterus. The presence of a gestational sac within the uterus excludes ectopic pregnancy in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy (blighted ovum) is a type of early pregnancy failure characterized by the absence of embryonic development within a gestational sac. 
  • Transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac without a fetal pole or visible embryonic parts. 
  • It commonly presents with vaginal bleeding, lower abdominal pain, and amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of burning retrosternal chest pain after meals. The pain improves with antacids. He denies symptoms of nausea, vomiting, palpitations, or syncope. The patient is obese. Upper endoscopy reveals proximal dislocation of the gastroesophageal junction 3 cm above the diaphragmatic indentation of the esophagus and erosive changes in the lower esophagus. This patient is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal adenocarcinoma

 

  • The findings of a sliding hiatal hernia, erosive esophagitis, and chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) put the patient at high risk of Barrett's esophagus, a condition in which the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced with metaplastic columnar epithelium. 
  • Barrett's esophagus is a known precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia: This is characterized by impaired esophageal motility and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation or imaging findings.

 

Option C. Gastric adenocarcinoma: This is not related to GERD or hiatal hernia and more commonly arises from chronic Helicobacter pylori infection or other gastric mucosal pathology.

 

Option D. Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma: MALT lymphoma is associated with chronic H. pylori infection and involves the stomach more often than the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with chronic GERD and a hiatal hernia are at increased risk for Barrett’s esophagus, which significantly raises the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma.

choices.text: Chronic kidney disease causing metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of fatigue, dry eyes, and dry mouth. She also reports intermittent muscle weakness and occasional episodes of numbness in her hands. Laboratory tests reveal:

 

  • Serum potassium: 2.8 mEq/L (normal: 3.5–5.0 mEq/L)
  • Serum bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L (normal: 22–28 mEq/L)
  • Serum anion gap: 8 mEq/L (normal: 8–12 mEq/L)
  • Urine pH: 7.0

 

Further evaluation reveals anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA)

 

  • Sjögren’s syndrome is an autoimmune disorder associated with distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) due to impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubules. This results in:
    • A non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
    • Hypokalemia due to increased renal potassium excretion.
    • Inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5) despite systemic acidosis.
  • Anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies are commonly seen in Sjögren’s syndrome and confirm the underlying autoimmune condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 diabetes mellitus causing ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis causes an anion gap metabolic acidosis, not a non-anion gap acidosis.

 

Option C. Primary hyperaldosteronism causing hypokalemia: This would not explain the metabolic acidosis, as primary hyperaldosteronism is associated with metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease causing metabolic acidosis: CKD typically causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis in advanced stages, not a non-anion gap acidosis with a high urine pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) is a known complication of Sjögren’s syndrome, characterized by hypokalemia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, and a high urine pH. 
  • Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old hiker presents with a 2-week history of fever, headache, fatigue, and a spreading red rash on his thigh. He reports hiking in a wooded area in New England a month ago. During his examination, there was a rash, which is shown below.

 

 

Laboratory findings show:

 

  • WBC: 10,500/mm³
  • ESR: Elevated
  • ELISA for Borrelia burgdorferi IgM: Positive

 

Which of the following complications is most likely to develop if this condition remains untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bell’s palsy

 

  • The patient’s presentation, including the "bull’s-eye" rash (erythema migrans), exposure to a wooded area, and positive serology for Borrelia burgdorferi, is consistent with early Lyme disease. 
  • If untreated, Lyme disease can progress to disseminated disease, which may involve cranial neuropathies (e.g., Bell's palsy), carditis, and arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glomerulonephritis: This is more characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis or lupus nephritis, not Lyme disease.

 

Option C. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): While severe sepsis can lead to DIC, it is not a complication of Lyme disease.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis: This is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis, not Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Lyme disease, caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, can progress to complications such as Bell’s palsy, myocarditis, or arthritis if left untreated. 
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline) can prevent these complications.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of severe ear pain following a routine surgical procedure to remove an inflamed adenoid. The otoscopic examination is normal, but the pain persists, radiating from the throat to the ear on the same side. The physician explains that the symptom is due to referred otalgia. Which anatomical structure is primarily responsible for this symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for the referred ear pain after procedures like tonsillectomy or adenoidectomy. 
  • This nerve provides sensory innervation to the tonsillar mucosa, the peritonsillar area, and the middle ear mucosa (via Jacobson's nerve). 
  • During surgery, irritation or inflammation of the glossopharyngeal nerve in the throat can lead to referred pain perceived in the ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vestibulocochlear nerve: Incorrect. This nerve is responsible for hearing and balance, not pain perception or referred otalgia.

 

Option B. Facial nerve: Incorrect. The facial nerve primarily innervates muscles of facial expression and has limited sensory functions, not significant in referred ear pain.

 

Option D. Trigeminal nerve: Incorrect. The trigeminal nerve provides sensation to the face and oral cavity but does not innervate the tonsillar region or middle ear.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Referred otalgia following procedures like tonsillectomy or adenoidectomy occurs due to irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve, which shares sensory innervation between the tonsillar region and the middle ear mucosa via Jacobson's nerve. 
  • Recognizing this referred pain pattern is essential for accurate diagnosis and reassurance in post-surgical care.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in active labor presents at term. Clinical pelvimetry reveals an oval-shaped pelvic inlet, where the anteroposterior diameter is greater than the transverse diameter. On abdominal examination, sub-umbilical flattening is noted, and the fetal heart is auscultated on the flanks. What is the most likely type of pelvis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthropoid pelvis

 

  • An anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an oval-shaped pelvic inlet where the anteroposterior diameter is greater than the transverse diameter. 
  • This type of pelvis often results in a fetal position where the head is transverse or oblique, leading to sub-umbilical flattening and flank auscultation of the fetal heart tones, as described in this case. 
  • It is less common than the gynecoid pelvis but can still allow vaginal delivery in many cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platypelloid pelvis: A platypelloid pelvis has a flattened shape with a wide transverse diameter and a reduced anteroposterior diameter. It is associated with transverse lie or obstructed labor, but the clinical presentation in this question aligns more closely with an anthropoid pelvis.

 

Option C. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the most common type of pelvis and has a rounded inlet with equal transverse and anteroposterior diameters. It is typically associated with optimal conditions for vaginal delivery and does not match the oval-shaped inlet described here.

 

Option D. Android pelvis: The android pelvis has a heart-shaped inlet with a narrow anteroposterior diameter, leading to increased risk of arrest of labor. It does not fit the oval-shaped inlet or the clinical findings described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An anthropoid pelvis is defined by an oval-shaped inlet where the anteroposterior diameter is greater than the transverse diameter. 
  • It can lead to specific clinical findings, such as sub-umbilical flattening and flank auscultation of fetal heart tones.

questions.text: A parasagittal section of the abdomen reveals the structure marked A. What is the superior border of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Caudate lobe of liver

 

  • Epiploic foramen is the marked structure indicated in the provided image.
  • The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is the opening that connects the greater sac and the lesser sac (omental bursa) in the abdominal cavity. 
  • It is bounded by specific anatomical structures:
    • Superior border: Caudate lobe of the liver
    • Inferior border: First part of the duodenum
    • Anterior border: Hepatoduodenal ligament (part of the lesser omentum), which contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, bile duct).
    • Posterior border: Inferior vena cava (IVC)
  • In the given image, the superior border of the marked structure (epiploic foramen) is the caudate lobe of the liver.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum forms the anterior border of the epiploic foramen, specifically through the hepatoduodenal ligament. It is not the superior border.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The first part of the duodenum forms the inferior border of the epiploic foramen, not the superior border.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava lies posterior to the epiploic foramen and forms its posterior border, not the superior border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The epiploic foramen (of Winslow) is bordered superiorly by the caudate lobe of the liver, anteriorly by the lesser omentum, inferiorly by the first part of the duodenum, and posteriorly by the inferior vena cava. 
  • It serves as the communication between the greater and lesser sacs in the abdominal cavity.

choices.text: Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and Vital Capacity (VC)
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and FEV1/FVC ratio

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with chronic cough, progressive shortness of breath, and wheezing. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are performed, and the results indicate obstructive lung disease consistent with COPD. Which of the following lung volumes or capacities increase in COPD?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

 

  • In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), air trapping due to airway obstruction and loss of elastic recoil leads to an increase in lung volumes such as:
    1. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. In COPD, air trapping and hyperinflation cause increased FRC.
    2. Total Lung Capacity (TLC): TLC is the maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. Hyperinflation caused by the loss of alveolar elastic recoil increases the TLC in COPD.

 

In contrast:

 

  • Vital Capacity (VC) is reduced or remains normal in COPD because trapped air limits the total volume that can be forcefully exhaled.
  • FEV1/FVC ratio decreases in obstructive lung disease due to a disproportionate decrease in FEV1 compared to FVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and Vital Capacity (VC): While FRC increases in COPD, VC decreases or remains normal due to air trapping limiting maximal expiratory airflow.

 

Option C. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) only: While FRC increases, TLC also increases due to hyperinflation of the lungs. Both FRC and TLC are elevated in COPD.

 

Option D. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and FEV1/FVC ratio: FRC increases, but the FEV1/FVC ratio decreases in COPD due to the obstructive nature of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In COPD, Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and Total Lung Capacity (TLC) both increase due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs. 
  • The FEV1/FVC ratio decreases, and Vital Capacity (VC) is reduced or normal.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with fatigue, malaise, and jaundice for the past few weeks. Laboratory tests show elevated ALT, AST, and hyperbilirubinemia. Serology is positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies. A liver biopsy reveals piecemeal necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic active hepatitis

 

  • Piecemeal necrosis (also known as interface hepatitis) refers to hepatocyte necrosis at the interface of portal tracts and the surrounding liver parenchyma. 
  • It is a histological hallmark of chronic active hepatitis, particularly in autoimmune hepatitis.
    • Chronic active hepatitis often presents with fatigue, jaundice, and laboratory findings of elevated liver enzymes.
    • Autoimmune hepatitis, a common cause of chronic active hepatitis, is associated with positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies and is more common in women.
    • Liver biopsy shows piecemeal necrosis, inflammatory infiltrates, and bridging necrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral hepatitis: Viral hepatitis (especially acute) shows lobular inflammation and hepatocyte ballooning. Chronic viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B or C) may show piecemeal necrosis but typically lacks anti-smooth muscle antibodies, which are more specific for autoimmune hepatitis.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hepatitis: Alcoholic hepatitis presents with Mallory bodies, neutrophilic infiltration, and ballooning degeneration in the liver. It does not typically involve interface hepatitis.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Malignancies (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma) are characterized by abnormal tumor growth and atypical cells, not piecemeal necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Piecemeal necrosis (interface hepatitis) is a key histological feature of chronic active hepatitis, often seen in autoimmune hepatitis. 
  • It involves hepatocyte necrosis at the portal-parenchymal interface.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete presents with hip pain after overstretching their leg backward while sprinting. On examination, there is tenderness around the anterior hip joint, and the physician identifies excessive hyperextension of the thigh. Injury to which ligament is most likely responsible for this instability?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iliofemoral ligament

 

  • The iliofemoral ligament, also known as the Y-ligament of Bigelow, is the strongest ligament in the human body and plays a critical role in stabilizing the hip joint. 
  • It originates from the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) and attaches to the intertrochanteric line of the femur. 
  • The iliofemoral ligament tightens during hip extension, preventing hyperextension of the thigh. 
  • This is particularly important during activities like standing upright or walking, as it stabilizes the hip without requiring significant muscular effort.
  • In this scenario, the athlete's hyperextension of the thigh suggests dysfunction or injury to the iliofemoral ligament, which is primarily responsible for limiting such movement.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pubofemoral ligament: The pubofemoral ligament reinforces the inferior part of the hip joint capsule and prevents excessive abduction and some external rotation, not hyperextension.

 

Option C. Ischiofemoral ligament: The ischiofemoral ligament is located posteriorly and primarily limits internal rotation and posterior displacement of the femoral head. It is not the main structure that prevents hyperextension.

 

Option D. Pectofemoral ligament: The pectofemoral ligament (part of the pubofemoral complex) limits abduction and external rotation of the hip. It does not prevent hyperextension of the thigh.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The iliofemoral ligament is the primary ligament that prevents hyperextension of the thigh at the hip joint. 
  • It stabilizes the hip joint by tightening during extension and allows for upright posture with minimal muscular effort.

choices.text: Barodontalgia due to air trapped under teeth
The bends caused by nitrogen effervescence
Barosinusitis from air trapped in sinuses

questions.text: A commercial diver experiences sudden pain in the joints and stiffness after ascending rapidly to the surface. The diver also complains of a dull, aching sensation in the arms and legs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms, and what is the primary mechanism behind this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The bends caused by nitrogen effervescence

 

  • The bends (also known as decompression sickness) is caused by the formation of nitrogen bubbles in the joints and tissues when a diver ascends too rapidly after exposure to high-pressure environments. 
  • As the pressure decreases, nitrogen dissolved in the bloodstream comes out of solution and forms bubbles, leading to the characteristic aching and pain in the joints. 
  • This condition is one of the most common manifestations of decompression sickness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barodontalgia due to air trapped under teeth: Incorrect. Barodontalgia refers to pain from air trapped beneath dental work, typically caused by pressure changes during ascent or descent. This is not the primary symptom in this scenario.

 

Option C. Barosinusitis from air trapped in sinuses: Incorrect. Barosinusitis occurs when air is trapped in the sinuses, causing pain and discomfort, particularly in the facial area, but it does not typically cause the joint pain seen in the bends.

 

Option D. Emphysema leading to cerebral embolism: Incorrect. While emphysema can lead to serious complications such as cerebral embolism, it is not the primary cause of joint pain in this scenario. The bends is the most likely explanation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The bends, caused by nitrogen effervescence, lead to joint pain and stiffness in divers who ascend too rapidly, and it is a key manifestation of decompression sickness.

questions.text: A patient undergoes an MRCP scan due to abdominal pain and jaundice. The scan is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Choledocholithiasis

 

  • The MRCP scan shows biliary tree dilation with a filling defect in the common bile duct (CBD), which is characteristic of choledocholithiasis (common bile duct stones). 
  • Choledocholithiasis occurs when stones obstruct bile flow, leading to proximal biliary dilation. 
  • Patients typically present with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and elevated liver enzymes, such as alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin. 
  • MRCP is the imaging modality of choice to detect bile duct obstructions, including stones, due to its high sensitivity and ability to visualize the biliary tree.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) causes irregular strictures and a "beaded" appearance of the bile ducts rather than a discrete filling defect. PSC is more common in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Option B. Cholecystitis: Cholecystitis involves inflammation of the gallbladder, usually due to cystic duct obstruction. It does not typically cause a filling defect or significant biliary tree dilation as seen in choledocholithiasis.

 

Option D. Biliary atresia: Biliary atresia is a congenital condition characterized by absence or obliteration of the biliary ducts in infants. It presents with persistent neonatal jaundice and does not apply to this adult case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choledocholithiasis occurs when stones obstruct the common bile duct, causing biliary dilation and a filling defect on imaging. 
  • MRCP is the preferred diagnostic test for identifying bile duct stones and other biliary abnormalities.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent ear discharge and progressive hearing loss in her right ear. She reports intermittent foul-smelling discharge for the past year. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida with debris accumulation and signs of chronic otitis media. Which of the following anatomical areas is most likely involved in the formation of a cholesteatoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prussak space

 

  • A cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear, typically arising from retraction pockets in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. 
  • The Prussak space, located between the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus, is the most common site for the initiation of cholesteatomas. 
  • Retraction pockets in the pars flaccida extend into the Prussak space, allowing for accumulation of keratin debris and subsequent infection, leading to the formation of a cholesteatoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promontory: The promontory is part of the medial wall of the middle ear and houses the cochlear basal turn. While it is an important anatomical landmark, it is not involved in the formation of cholesteatomas.

 

Option B. Oval window: The oval window is an opening in the medial wall of the middle ear that connects to the stapes footplate and the inner ear. It plays a role in sound conduction but is not involved in the early formation of cholesteatomas.

 

Option D. Facial recess: The facial recess is a surgical landmark located lateral to the facial nerve and medial to the chorda tympani in the posterior tympanum. It is not related to cholesteatoma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prussak space is the primary site involved in the formation of cholesteatomas, particularly those arising from retraction pockets in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 40-year-old immunocompetent woman presents with progressive nasal obstruction, facial pressure, and thick, yellow-green nasal discharge for the past two months. She also reports anosmia but denies fever or systemic symptoms. Nasal endoscopy reveals bilateral nasal polyps and thick eosinophilic mucin in the nasal cavity. No signs of tissue invasion are observed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

  • The clinical presentation and findings are characteristic of Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS), a condition seen in immunocompetent individuals. The hallmarks include:
    • Nasal polyposis.
    • Eosinophilic mucin without evidence of tissue invasion.
    • Thick nasal discharge and nasal obstruction.
    • Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common fungal organism responsible for AFRS. It induces an allergic reaction rather than direct invasion, leading to mucosal inflammation and polyposis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Candida is more commonly associated with oral thrush or systemic fungal infections in immunocompromised individuals. It does not cause allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Cryptococcus is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in association with cryptococcal meningitis or systemic cryptococcosis. It is not a cause of AFRS.

 

Option D. Mucor species: Mucor species are responsible for mucormycosis, a highly invasive fungal infection that occurs in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with diabetes or on immunosuppressive therapy). Mucormycosis involves tissue invasion, which is absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common organism causing allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS), a condition seen in immunocompetent individuals characterized by nasal polyposis and eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease is undergoing evaluation for her lipid profile. Testing reveals impaired cholesterol esterification in high-density lipoprotein (HDL) particles. Which of the following apolipoproteins is primarily responsible for activating lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), the enzyme involved in this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apo A-I

 

  • Apo A-I is the primary activator of lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), an enzyme crucial for the esterification of free cholesterol in HDL particles. 
  • This esterification is vital for the maturation of HDL and the process of reverse cholesterol transport, where cholesterol is removed from peripheral tissues and returned to the liver. 
  • Apo A-I, a structural and functional component of HDL, directly interacts with LCAT to enhance its enzymatic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apo A-II: Although associated with HDL, Apo A-II primarily stabilizes HDL structure and has a minor role in lipid metabolism. It does not significantly activate LCAT.

 

Option C. Apo B-100: Found in LDL and VLDL, Apo B-100 is critical for LDL receptor binding and the delivery of cholesterol to peripheral tissues. It is not involved in LCAT activation or HDL metabolism.

 

Option D. Apo B-48: Apo B-48 is a structural protein found in chylomicrons and plays a role in triglyceride-rich lipoprotein transport. It does not activate LCAT or participate in cholesterol esterification in HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Apo A-I is the primary activator of LCAT, which is essential for HDL maturation and reverse cholesterol transport, playing a key role in cholesterol metabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a traumatic brain injury and is being monitored for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The physician is calculating cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) to ensure adequate blood flow to the brain. How is this cerebral perfusion pressure calculated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - Intracranial pressure

 

  • Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) represents the pressure gradient driving blood flow to the brain. It is calculated as:

    CPP=Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)−Intracranial Pressure (ICP)

    • Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): Represents the average blood pressure in the arterial system and is the driving force for cerebral blood flow.
    • Intracranial Pressure (ICP): Reflects the pressure inside the skull, which opposes cerebral blood flow.
  • A decrease in CPP can occur due to low MAP (e.g., hypotension) or high ICP (e.g., cerebral edema, hemorrhage). Maintaining CPP within normal ranges (typically 60–80 mmHg) is essential to prevent cerebral ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as:

               CPP=Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)−Intracranial Pressure (ICP)

  • This ensures adequate cerebral blood flow and prevents ischemia, especially in conditions of elevated ICP or hypotension.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, an erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull reveals multiple lytic lesions, and a skin biopsy finding is shown in the image. Immunohistochemistry is positive for S100 and CD1a. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is caused by the proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are abnormal dendritic cells. This case presents the classic features of LCH:
    1. Lytic bone lesions: Common in LCH, especially in the skull, leading to bone pain.
    2. Skin biopsy findings: Cells with prominent nuclear grooves (reniform nuclei) and infiltration by eosinophils are highly characteristic.
    3. Immunohistochemistry: The Langerhans cells are positive for S100 and CD1a, which are diagnostic markers for LCH.
  • Children with LCH often present with systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and bone pain, correlating well with this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma: A benign histiocytic disorder seen in infants and young children. It presents as yellowish skin nodules but does not cause lytic bone lesions or show CD1a positivity on immunohistochemistry.

 

Option C. Multicentric Castleman disease: This lymphoproliferative disorder presents with lymphadenopathy, systemic inflammation, and organomegaly. It is not associated with lytic bone lesions, prominent nuclear grooves, or CD1a positivity.

 

Option D. Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH): HLH is characterized by uncontrolled immune activation, leading to fever, hepatosplenomegaly, cytopenias, and hemophagocytosis. It does not produce lytic bone lesions or show the histological findings of LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by lytic bone lesions, prominent nuclear grooves, eosinophilic infiltration, and immunohistochemical positivity for S100 and CD1a.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of a red, scaly rash on sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, and hands. The rash primarily appears in spring. He also reports intermittent irritability, confusion, and difficulty with coordination. His diet includes adequate protein and vitamins. Laboratory investigations reveal increased excretion of neutral amino acids in the urine, while serotonin and its metabolites, including 5-HIAA, are within normal limits. Urine tests for indole compounds are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartnup disease

 

  • Hartnup disease is characterized by increased excretion of neutral amino acids, including tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency despite adequate dietary intake. 
  • This results in pellagra-like symptoms such as a red, scaly rash on sun-exposed areas (face, neck, hands) and neurological symptoms like irritability, confusion, and coordination difficulties. 
  • The normal levels of serotonin, 5-HIAA, and negative indole compounds in the urine further support this diagnosis by indicating disrupted tryptophan transport rather than its metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid syndrome: Carcinoid syndrome results from excessive serotonin production by neuroendocrine tumors. It typically presents with flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps. Elevated levels of serotonin and its metabolites (e.g., 5-HIAA) in the urine are diagnostic. The absence of these findings and the negative indole tests rule out carcinoid syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency: Vitamin B6 deficiency is associated with symptoms like irritability, depression, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not cause aminoaciduria or a pellagra-like rash.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is caused by a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated levels of phenylalanine.
