Clinical features include intellectual disability, musty body odor, and eczema but do not include aminoaciduria of neutral amino acids or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hartnup disease presents with pellagra-like dermatitis, neurological symptoms, and increased urinary excretion of neutral amino acids despite adequate protein and vitamin intake.

choices.text: End-diastolic volume (EDV) and pressure curve shifts to the left without change in slope
Slope changes in the end-systolic volume (ESV) pressure curve
End-systolic volume (ESV) and pressure curve shifts to the left without change in slope
Slope changes in the end-diastolic volume (EDV) and pressure curve

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of heart failure presents with fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Echocardiography shows reduced contractility of the heart. How will this condition affect the relationship between end-systolic volume (ESV), end-diastolic volume (EDV), and their pressure-volume curves?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in the end-systolic volume (ESV) pressure curve

 

  • The end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR) curve is primarily affected by changes in contractility. 
  • A decrease in contractility leads to a reduced slope of the ESPVR curve. 
  • This occurs because the heart generates less pressure for a given end-systolic volume, reflecting impaired systolic function. As contractility decreases, the heart is unable to eject as much blood, resulting in an increased end-systolic volume (ESV) and reduced stroke volume.
  • The slope of the ESPVR curve is an indicator of myocardial contractility, and a reduction in this slope is characteristic of conditions such as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. End-diastolic volume (EDV) and pressure curve shifts to the left without change in slope: The EDV pressure-volume relationship primarily reflects ventricular compliance and preload, not contractility. A shift in EDV is unrelated to the ESPVR slope caused by decreased contractility.

 

Option C. End-systolic volume (ESV) and pressure curve shifts to the left without change in slope: Decreased contractility causes the ESPVR curve to shift downward and rightward due to reduced pressure generation, not to the left. The slope also decreases rather than remaining unchanged.

 

Option D. Slope changes in the end-diastolic volume (EDV) and pressure curve: The EDV pressure curve reflects ventricular filling (preload), which is influenced by compliance and volume but not contractility. Changes in contractility specifically affect the ESPVR slope, not the EDV curve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decreased contractility of the heart causes a reduction in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR) curve. 
  • This reflects the heart’s inability to generate sufficient pressure for a given end-systolic volume, a hallmark of impaired systolic function.

questions.text: A researcher is testing a new drug’s efficacy and sets the significance level (alpha) at 0.05. After performing the hypothesis test, the p-value obtained is 0.02, leading the researcher to reject the null hypothesis. However, it is later revealed that the drug has no real effect. What type of error did the researcher commit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 error

 

  • A Type 1 error occurs when the researcher rejects the null hypothesis despite it being true.
  • In this case, the p-value of 0.02 is less than the significance level of 0.05, leading the researcher to reject the null hypothesis. 
  • However, the drug actually has no real effect, meaning the null hypothesis was true, and rejecting it was an error. 
  • This is also known as a false positive, where the researcher incorrectly concludes that the drug has an effect when it does not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 2 error: A Type 2 error occurs when the null hypothesis is not rejected when it is actually false. This would happen if the researcher failed to detect the drug's real effect, even though it existed.

 

Option C. Type 3 error: This term is not widely recognized in standard statistical texts but can refer to errors made in addressing the wrong research question, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Power error: This is not a recognized statistical term. Power refers to the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false, and an error related to power is typically a Type 2 error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Type 1 error occurs when a true null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected, leading to a false positive conclusion.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide is experiencing hemorrhagic cystitis as a result of the drug’s urotoxic effects. Which of the following drugs can be administered to treat this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroid

 

  • Steroids, particularly corticosteroids, are used to treat established hemorrhagic cystitis caused by cyclophosphamide. 
  • The condition involves inflammation and damage to the bladder mucosa due to toxic metabolites like acrolein. 
  • Steroids reduce inflammation, edema, and immune-mediated damage, which helps manage the symptoms and promotes healing of the bladder lining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesna: Mesna is a preventive agent that binds to acrolein in the bladder, neutralizing its toxic effects. However, it is not effective for treating hemorrhagic cystitis once it has already developed.

 

Option C. Epoetin-alpha: Epoetin-alpha is used to treat chemotherapy-induced anemia but does not have any role in managing hemorrhagic cystitis.

 

Option D. Palifermin: Palifermin is used to reduce the severity of chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis. It does not address bladder toxicity or inflammation caused by cyclophosphamide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of established hemorrhagic cystitis, steroids are used to manage inflammation and tissue damage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman delivered a baby with normal expulsion of an intact placenta. Thirty minutes later, she developed vaginal bleeding, hypotension, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound revealed retained placental tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Placenta succenturiata

 

  • Placenta succenturiata is characterized by the presence of one or more accessory lobes in addition to the main placental mass. 
  • These accessory lobes are connected to the main placenta by blood vessels but can sometimes remain in the uterus after delivery, leading to retained placental tissue. 
  • This can result in postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), as described in this patient. The retained lobe prevents the uterus from contracting effectively, contributing to ongoing bleeding and the boggy uterus palpated on examination.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumvallate placenta: Circumvallate placenta is a morphological abnormality where the edges of the placenta are rolled inward due to excessive fibrin deposition. It is associated with complications such as preterm labor and placental abruption but does not cause accessory lobe retention or postpartum hemorrhage due to retained tissue.

 

Option B. Placenta membranacea: Placenta membranacea is a rare condition where the placenta develops as a thin, membranous structure that covers the uterine cavity. It is associated with antenatal complications such as previa and bleeding but is not a common cause of retained tissue after delivery.

 

Option D. Circummarginate placenta: Circummarginate placenta is a variant of normal placental development characterized by a flat margin of fibrin deposition. It does not typically result in retained placental tissue or postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta succenturiata refers to the presence of accessory placental lobes that may remain in the uterus after delivery, causing postpartum hemorrhage and uterine atony. 
  • Retained tissue should be suspected in cases of PPH with a boggy uterus and confirmed by ultrasound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of seasonal allergic rhinitis presents with complaints of itching, runny nose, and watery eyes after exposure to pollen. Which of the following cytokines is most likely to trigger the activation of basophils in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-5

 

  • IL-5 is a cytokine primarily responsible for the activation, proliferation, and recruitment of basophils and eosinophils, especially during allergic responses and type I hypersensitivity reactions.
  • IL-5 is produced by Th2 cells and mast cells, and it plays a critical role in:
    1. Activation of basophils: IL-5 primes basophils for degranulation and cytokine release.
    2. Eosinophil recruitment and activation: IL-5 is the major cytokine for eosinophil differentiation and survival.
  • In patients with allergic rhinitis, IL-5 contributes to the pathogenesis by activating basophils, which release histamine and other mediators, resulting in itching, swelling, and other allergic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TNF-alpha: TNF-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in systemic inflammation and is mainly produced by macrophages. While TNF-alpha can influence allergic responses, it does not directly activate basophils.

 

Option C. IL-2: IL-2 stimulates T cell proliferation and enhances natural killer (NK) cell activity. It is not involved in basophil activation or allergic responses.

 

Option D. INF-gamma: INF-gamma is a cytokine produced by Th1 cells and NK cells to activate macrophages and promote cell-mediated immunity. It does not play a role in basophil activation or allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IL-5 is a cytokine produced by Th2 cells that activates and recruits basophils and eosinophils, playing a central role in allergic reactions and type I hypersensitivity.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male after falling from a motorcycle is brought is to the emergency with a head injury. Imaging was done as shown. Identify the incorrect statement (s) about the given condition.

 

 

  1. Alternate periods of unconsciousness with a normal spell may be seen
  2. Associated with cerebral contusion
  3. Associated with fracture of temporal bone
  4. Ipsilateral hemiparesis may occur
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 only 

 

  • Given image shows concavo-convex hyperdense lesion suggestive of Extradural hematoma (EDH). 

 

Explanation of each option:

 

  1. Lucid interval is seen in EDH
  2. Since severity of trauma is moderate in EDH, cerebral contusion is unlikely. It is seen in Subdural hemorrhage.
  3. Fracture of temporal bone is commonly seen
  4. Ipsilateral hemiparesis may occur due to “Kernohan notch” effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • EDH may show a lucid interval, is associated with facture of temporal bone and sometimes shows ipsilateral hemiparesis which is a false localising sign.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the ER with acute dystonia, including muscle rigidity and abnormal posturing, following the administration of metoclopramide for nausea and vomiting. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

  • Acute dystonic reactions, such as those described in this patient, are a well-known side effect of dopamine receptor antagonists like metoclopramide. 
  • These drugs block dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, which leads to an imbalance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system. 
  • This imbalance results in extrapyramidal symptoms, including muscle rigidity, tremors, and abnormal posturing.
  • The initial treatment for acute dystonia involves using antihistamines with anticholinergic properties to restore the balance of acetylcholine and dopamine. 
  • Promethazine, a first-generation antihistamine, is the drug of choice due to its potent central anticholinergic activity. 
  • It also has good penetration of the blood-brain barrier, making it effective in treating the central nervous system effects of acute dystonia.
  • In addition, promethazine is an antihistamine with strong anticholinergic effects, which can help to relieve the muscle rigidity and other extrapyramidal symptoms caused by dopamine blockade in the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pheniramine: Pheniramine is another antihistamine, but it has relatively weaker anticholinergic effects compared to promethazine. While it may have some mild benefit in treating acute dystonia, it is not the drug of choice. Promethazine is more effective due to its stronger anticholinergic and central nervous system activity.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that works by blocking dopamine receptors. However, it is not used to treat acute dystonia caused by other dopamine antagonists. In fact, using dopamine blockers like chlorpromazine can exacerbate dystonic reactions rather than treat them. Therefore, it is not appropriate in this case.

 

Option D. Prochlorperazine: Prochlorperazine is another dopamine antagonist with antiemetic properties, similar to metoclopramide. It can worsen dystonic reactions because it further blocks dopamine receptors, which can lead to increased extrapyramidal symptoms. Like chlorpromazine, it is contraindicated for treating metoclopramide-induced dystonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The initial treatment for acute dystonic reactions induced by dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) is the administration of an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, such as promethazine, which helps to restore the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

questions.text: What represents the marked area in the given histology of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mantle zone

 

  • The mantle zone is the darker-staining region that surrounds the germinal center within a secondary lymphoid follicle. 
  • It is composed of small, resting naive B-cells that form a ring-like structure around the pale-staining germinal center. 
  • The mantle zone serves as a boundary between the germinal center and the outer lymphoid tissue, ensuring separation between actively proliferating B-cells (germinal center) and resting B-cells.

 

Key points about the mantle zone:

  • It forms a dark-staining ring around the germinal center.
  • Contains small, tightly packed resting B-lymphocytes.
  • It is distinct from the lighter germinal center, where active B-cell proliferation occurs.

 

In the provided image, the marked dark peripheral area encircling the pale center is consistent with the mantle zone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marginal zone: The marginal zone lies outside the mantle zone and is typically prominent in the spleen. It contains memory B-cells and is not as clearly defined in lymph nodes.

 

Option B. Paracortical zone: The paracortical zone is located outside the follicles and primarily contains T-cells. It does not surround the germinal center.

 

Option C. Germinal center: The germinal center is the pale-staining central region where active B-cell proliferation occurs. The marked area in this image corresponds to the darker peripheral region, which is the mantle zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mantle zone is the darker-staining ring of resting naive B-cells that surrounds the germinal center in a secondary lymphoid follicle. 
  • It acts as a boundary between the actively proliferating B-cells in the germinal center and the surrounding lymphoid tissue.

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia, and elevated urine malonic acid. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12

 

  • Malonyl aciduria is a rare metabolic disorder that results from a deficiency in vitamin B12. 
  • This condition is related to the impaired function of enzymes involved in methylmalonic acid metabolism. 
  • Vitamin B12 is required as a cofactor for the methylmalonyl-CoA mutase enzyme, which is critical for the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. 
  • A deficiency in vitamin B12 leads to the accumulation of methylmalonic acid and other intermediates such as malonyl acid. 
  • These intermediates are then excreted in the urine, leading to the characteristic findings in malonyl aciduria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Riboflavin deficiency leads to ariboflavinosis with symptoms like sore throat, cracks around the mouth, and glossitis, but it is not related to malonyl aciduria.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency typically causes seizures and peripheral neuropathy. It is not associated with malonyl aciduria.

 

Option D. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects but does not cause malonyl aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malonyl aciduria is most commonly associated with vitamin B12 deficiency due to impaired methylmalonyl-CoA metabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with weakness in his right hand and difficulty extending his fingers and wrist. Physical examination reveals intact sensation but significant weakness in wrist and finger extension. The patient reports a recent fall causing a forearm injury. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected in this condition, and which nerve is responsible for its innervation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor Digitorum

 

  • The extensor digitorum muscle is primarily responsible for extension of the fingers and the wrist. 
  • It is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the radial nerve).
  • In this case, the patient’s wrist drop (inability to extend the wrist and fingers) with intact sensation is classic for a radial nerve injury at the level of the forearm.
  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a motor branch of the radial nerve and supplies the muscles of the posterior compartment of the forearm, including the extensor digitorum. 
  • Sensory function remains intact because the posterior interosseous nerve has no sensory component.
  • The clinical presentation of a forearm injury with weakness in wrist and finger extension but preserved sensation strongly suggests injury to the posterior interosseous nerve and dysfunction of the extensor digitorum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pronator Quadratus: The pronator quadratus muscle is responsible for pronation of the forearm and is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve). It does not contribute to wrist or finger extension.

 

Option B. Flexor Digitorum Superficialis: This muscle flexes the proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers and is innervated by the median nerve. It is unrelated to wrist or finger extension.

 

Option D. Brachioradialis: Brachioradialis is a forearm flexor, innervated by the radial nerve. While it shares innervation with the extensor muscles, it does not participate in wrist or finger extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The extensor digitorum muscle is responsible for finger and wrist extension and is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve, a motor branch of the radial nerve. 
  • Injury to this nerve causes weakness in extension without sensory loss, as seen in this case.

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project to regulate blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS)

 

  • The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), located in the medulla oblongata, is the primary site where afferent fibers from baroreceptors terminate. 
  • Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch relay signals via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and vagus nerve (CN X), respectively. 
  • The NTS integrates this sensory input and regulates autonomic centers to maintain blood pressure. 
  • It stimulates parasympathetic activity through the nucleus ambiguus and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus, reducing heart rate, and inhibits sympathetic output by modulating the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) through the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM), causing vasodilation and lowering blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM): The RVLM is responsible for sympathetic tone and blood vessel constriction. It does not receive the direct input from baroreceptors; instead, it is modulated by the NTS.

 

Option B. Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus: The dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus is involved in parasympathetic control of visceral organs, including the heart, but it is downstream of the NTS. It does not directly receive afferent baroreceptor input.

 

Option D. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM): The CVLM provides inhibitory input to the RVLM to reduce sympathetic outflow. It is part of the baroreceptor reflex pathway but is not the initial site of baroreceptor afferent termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Afferent fibers from baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch project to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. 
  • The NTS integrates this input and coordinates autonomic responses to maintain blood pressure homeostasis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old nulliparous woman in active labor has been pushing for the past two hours without progress and feels extremely fatigued. The CTG remains normal. On examination, the fetal head is 1 cm above the ischial spines and in the occipitoanterior position. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emergency cesarean section

 

  • In this case, the patient is experiencing a prolonged second stage of labor with no progress despite pushing for two hours. 
  • Although the CTG is reassuring and the fetal head is in the occipitoanterior position, the head remains high (1 cm above the ischial spines). 
  • This indicates that operative vaginal delivery (e.g., forceps or vacuum) is not safe due to the high station of the fetal head, which increases the risk of maternal and fetal trauma. 
  • Therefore, an emergency cesarean section is the most appropriate option to safely deliver the baby and avoid complications for both mother and fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observe for spontaneous progress: Observation is inappropriate as the second stage of labor has already been prolonged, and the patient is fatigued. Further delay increases the risks of maternal exhaustion, uterine rupture, or fetal distress.

 

Option B. Trial of forceps in theater: Operative vaginal delivery is not indicated here because the fetal head is still high (1 cm above the ischial spines), making forceps or vacuum delivery unsafe and prone to complications like excessive traction, maternal trauma, or fetal injury.

 

Option D. Perform fetal blood sampling: Fetal blood sampling is unnecessary in this scenario as the CTG is normal, indicating no immediate concerns about fetal wellbeing. This option does not address the lack of progress in labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For prolonged second-stage labor with no descent of the fetal head and maternal exhaustion, emergency cesarean section is indicated, especially when the fetal station remains high, as operative vaginal delivery in such cases carries significant risks.

choices.text: The catheter is maintained for at least 8 weeks
The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter
The fistula is associated with pelvic radiation
The fistula is larger than 2 cm in diameter

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with a genitourinary fistula following a complicated vaginal delivery. The patient is managed with continuous bladder drainage via Foley catheter. Which characteristic of the fistula increases the likelihood of spontaneous healing with this approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter

 

  • The likelihood of spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula depends on its size and associated factors. 
  • Fistulas measuring 2 to 3 mm in diameter are small enough to have a good chance of closing spontaneously when managed with continuous bladder drainage, as this reduces pressure on the fistula and allows natural tissue healing. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The catheter is maintained for at least 8 weeks: While prolonged bladder drainage may aid in healing, catheterization typically lasts 2–4 weeks for small fistulas. Extended catheterization does not increase the likelihood of spontaneous healing if the fistula size or underlying factors are unfavorable.

 

Option C. The fistula is associated with pelvic radiation: Fistulas caused by pelvic radiation damage are less likely to heal spontaneously because of poor vascularization and tissue quality. These usually require surgical repair.

 

Option D. The fistula is larger than 2 cm in diameter: Larger fistulas (>2 cm) are unlikely to close with conservative management alone due to the extent of the defect. Surgical repair is typically necessary for fistulas of this size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula is most likely when the fistula is small (2–3 mm in diameter) and managed with continuous bladder drainage to reduce pressure and promote tissue healing. 
  • Larger fistulas or those associated with complicating factors usually require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive back pain and bilateral lower limb weakness. A detailed radiological investigation is performed after injecting contrast into the spinal canal, revealing clear visualization of the spinal cord and nerve roots. Which of the following investigations was performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myelography

 

  • Myelography is a specialized radiographic technique that uses contrast injected into the subarachnoid space to visualize the spinal cord, nerve roots, and spinal canal. 
  • It is often used to detect structural abnormalities such as spinal stenosis, herniated discs, or nerve root compression, especially when MRI is contraindicated. 
  • The description of contrast-based imaging focusing on the spinal cord aligns with myelography.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluoroscopy: Fluoroscopy provides real-time imaging for procedures but does not create detailed images of the spinal cord or nerve roots.

 

Option C. Neurography: Neurography uses advanced MRI techniques to visualize peripheral nerves, not the spinal canal or spinal cord.

 

Option D. Angiography: Angiography visualizes blood vessels after injecting contrast, primarily for detecting vascular abnormalities, not spinal cord pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myelography is a contrast-enhanced radiographic study used to visualize the spinal cord, nerve roots, and spinal canal, often to assess structural spinal pathology when MRI is unavailable or contraindicated.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with intermittent dizziness, palpitations, and shortness of breath that worsen when lying flat and improve when sitting up. On examination, a diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals a mass in the left atrium, which is surgically removed. The gross pathology image shows a gelatinous mass attached to the atrial septum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left atrial myxoma

 

  • Left atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults, typically originating from the atrial septum. 
  • It presents with positional symptoms like dyspnea and dizziness due to intermittent obstruction of the mitral valve, mimicking mitral stenosis. 
  • A diastolic murmur and a "tumor plop" sound may be heard on examination. 
  • Echocardiography reveals a mobile atrial mass, and gross pathology shows a gelatinous, pedunculated tumor. 
  • Unlike rheumatic mitral stenosis, infective endocarditis, or cardiac sarcoma, myxomas do not involve calcified valves, vegetations, or aggressive invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatic mitral stenosis: Rheumatic mitral stenosis also causes a diastolic murmur at the apex but results from thickened, calcified mitral leaflets rather than a mass in the atrium. Echocardiography would show valvular narrowing instead of a mass.

 

Option C. Cardiac sarcoma: Cardiac sarcomas are rare, malignant tumors that can arise in the heart. They are more aggressive than myxomas and often invade surrounding cardiac tissue. The gross appearance is not gelatinous, and symptoms include rapid clinical deterioration.

 

Option D. Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis causes valvular vegetations, leading to regurgitant murmurs and systemic emboli. It does not cause a mobile atrial mass resembling a tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Left atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. It presents with positional symptoms (worsened when lying flat), a diastolic murmur, and obstructive findings mimicking mitral stenosis. 
  • Gross pathology reveals a gelatinous, pedunculated mass often attached to the atrial septum.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with primary open-angle glaucoma is started on a new medication to help manage intraocular pressure. The drug is known to increase the trabecular outflow of aqueous humor through its effect on the Rho kinase pathway. Which of the following is the most likely side effect associated with the use of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cornea verticillata

 

  • Cornea verticillata, also known as vortex keratopathy, is a potential side effect of medications affecting the Rho kinase pathway, such as netarsudil, a Rho kinase inhibitor. 

  • This condition is characterized by the deposition of drug metabolites in the corneal epithelium, leading to a whorl-like pattern. While the finding is typically asymptomatic and reversible, it is a notable side effect associated with this class of drugs.

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinal vein thrombosis: Retinal vein thrombosis is not a known side effect of Rho kinase inhibitors. It is more commonly associated with systemic conditions like hypercoagulability or hypertension.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances such as halos: Visual disturbances like halos are often caused by increased intraocular pressure or corneal edema, but they are not commonly reported with Rho kinase inhibitors.

 

Option D. Periorbital edema: Periorbital edema is typically seen with prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost, bimatoprost) and is not associated with Rho kinase inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rho kinase inhibitors, such as netarsudil, lower intraocular pressure by increasing trabecular outflow. 
  • A characteristic side effect of these medications is cornea verticillata, which manifests as asymptomatic deposits in the corneal epithelium. 
  • Understanding this unique side effect is important in the management of glaucoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being exposed to a toxic substance while handling a pesticide at his workplace. He complains of excessive tearing, which is accompanied by a reddish discoloration of his tears. Upon examination, he appears to be experiencing drooling and has difficulty breathing. Which of the following pesticides is most likely responsible for the chromolacryorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paraoxon

 

  • Chromolacryorrhea (reddish or blood-tinged tears) is most commonly associated with Paraoxon, an organophosphate compound. 
  • Paraoxon is the toxic metabolite of Parathion, a pesticide that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to cholinergic toxicity. 
  • In severe cases, the accumulation of acetylcholine can cause symptoms such as excessive salivation, lacrimation (tear production), and chromolacryorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DDT: DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is an insecticide known for its neurotoxic effects, but it does not cause chromolacryorrhea.

 

Option C. Pyrethrin: Pyrethrins are insecticides derived from chrysanthemum flowers and cause neurotoxic symptoms by interfering with nerve signal transmission, but they are not associated with chromolacryorrhea.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is a naturally occurring insecticide that affects cellular respiration but does not typically cause chromolacryorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paraoxon, an organophosphate, is most likely to cause chromolacryorrhea due to its cholinergic toxicity affecting the eyes and other tissues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 6 x 4 cm right breast lump in the upper medial quadrant. The lump is fixed to the pectoralis major. Examination reveals no axillary nodes but left left-sided supraclavicular node. Her TNM stage is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T3N0M1

 

  1. T3 (Tumor size):
    • A 6 × 4 cm tumor qualifies as T3 (tumor size >5 cm).
    • Fixation to the pectoralis major muscle does not upgrade the T stage unless there is involvement of the chest wall or skin, which would be T4.
  2. N0 (Nodal stage):
    • No ipsilateral axillary lymph node involvement is noted on examination, making it N0.
    • Regional lymph node involvement includes ipsilateral axillary, infraclavicular, and internal mammary nodes.
  3. M1 (Metastasis stage):
    • The presence of a contralateral supraclavicular node is classified as distant metastasis (M1).
    • Any nodal metastasis on the contralateral side or distant locations is considered M1 disease, irrespective of the nodal involvement on the ipsilateral side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T3N3M0: Incorrect because there is no ipsilateral nodal involvement, and the contralateral node involvement classifies it as M1.

 

Option B. T4N3M0: Incorrect because fixation to the pectoralis muscle alone does not qualify as T4. T4 requires chest wall fixation (beyond pectoralis) or skin involvement.

 

Option D. T4N3M1: Incorrect due to the incorrect T and N stage. There is no evidence of T4 involvement or N3 ipsilateral nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the TNM staging of breast cancer:

 

  • T3 refers to tumors >5 cm in size. Fixation to the pectoralis major does not automatically upgrade to T4.
  • N0 indicates no ipsilateral nodal involvement.
  • M1 indicates distant metastasis, including contralateral supraclavicular node involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a contraindication for thrombolytic therapy with streptokinase?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraventricular tachycardia

 

  • Streptokinase is a thrombolytic agent used in the management of acute myocardial infarction, but its use is contraindicated in several clinical situations, including active bleeding, recent surgery, trauma, or a history of cerebral hemorrhage. 
  • However, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is not a contraindication for streptokinase therapy. 
  • SVT is a type of arrhythmia that does not pose a risk of worsening bleeding or contraindicate the fibrinolytic action of streptokinase. 
  • Therefore, a patient with SVT can receive thrombolytic therapy with streptokinase as long as no other contraindications are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Recent trauma: Recent trauma, particularly major trauma involving significant blood loss, is a contraindication for thrombolytic therapy. Streptokinase can exacerbate bleeding by promoting fibrinolysis, so it should not be used in patients with recent trauma or any condition where there is a high risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Recent cerebral bleeding: A history of recent cerebral hemorrhage is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy, including streptokinase. The risk of worsening intracranial hemorrhage outweighs any potential benefit in these patients. Thrombolytic agents are contraindicated due to the risk of causing fatal bleeding.

 

Option D. Recent surgery: Thrombolytic therapy is contraindicated in patients who have recently undergone surgery. Surgery often involves tissue trauma and may be associated with increased bleeding risk. Administering thrombolytic therapy can exacerbate postoperative bleeding, making it unsafe in this context.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Streptokinase is contraindicated in patients with recent trauma, cerebral bleeding, or recent surgery, but not in those with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of autoimmune thyroiditis presents with worsening symptoms of fatigue and joint pain. He has elevated autoantibodies against thyroid antigens. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Central tolerance

 

  • The patient’s history of autoimmune thyroiditis and elevated autoantibodies suggests that there is a breakdown of tolerance to self-antigens, resulting in an immune response against the thyroid gland. 
  • The central tolerance mechanism ensures that self-reactive T-cells are deleted during their maturation in the thymus. 
  • A failure in this process could lead to the escape of self-reactive T-cells into the periphery, which can then cause autoimmune diseases.
  • In this case, the patient’s immune system is not effectively preventing the activation of self-reactive T-cells against thyroid antigens. 
  • This could be due to a defect in the central tolerance process, which allows self-reactive T-cells to escape from the thymus and mount an immune attack on the thyroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoptosis of self-reactive T-cells: Incorrect. Apoptosis (AICD) is a peripheral tolerance mechanism, and while it plays a role in eliminating self-reactive T-cells in the periphery, a defect in this process would typically lead to autoimmune disease by preventing the death of self-reactive cells. The defect in this patient is likely related to central tolerance.

 

Option C. Sequestration of self-antigens: Incorrect. Sequestration of self-antigens occurs in immunologically privileged sites like the brain or eye and helps prevent immune responses to self. This mechanism is not directly related to the failure of tolerance to thyroid antigens.

 

Option D. Ignorance of self-reactive T-cells: Incorrect. Ignorance refers to a situation where self-reactive T-cells never encounter their target antigen, but in autoimmune thyroiditis, the immune system has actively targeted thyroid antigens, making this mechanism unlikely to explain the disease process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A failure of central tolerance leads to the escape of self-reactive T-cells, which can contribute to the development of autoimmune diseases like autoimmune thyroiditis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female presents with fever, arthralgia, rash, and fatigue that began 10 days after completing a course of ceftriaxone for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination reveals a diffuse maculopapular rash, tender lymphadenopathy, and mild joint swelling. Laboratory results show:

 

  • Elevated ESR and CRP
  • Decreased C3 and C4 complement levels
  • Mild proteinuria and hematuria
  • No peripheral eosinophilia

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum sickness

 

  • The patient's symptoms of fever, rash, arthralgia, and fatigue, along with low complement levels (C3 and C4) and recent ceftriaxone use, strongly suggest serum sickness, a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. 
  • Immune complexes formed in response to the drug deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation and complement activation. 
  • The absence of eosinophilia supports this diagnosis, as it differentiates serum sickness from IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (Type I).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This presents with renal involvement and low complement levels but typically follows a streptococcal infection and lacks systemic features like rash and arthralgia.

 

Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): While SLE can present with similar symptoms, it typically shows autoantibodies such as ANA or anti-dsDNA, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lupus: Drug-induced lupus can present with fever, rash, and arthralgia, but it is more commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies and does not typically involve complement consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum sickness is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition and complement activation, often triggered by drugs like ceftriaxone, leading to systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and arthralgia.

questions.text: Which zona pellucida protein is primarily responsible for zona hardening after sperm penetration, preventing polyspermy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ZP2

 

  • The ZP2 protein plays a critical role in zona hardening, a biochemical change in the zona pellucida that occurs after sperm penetration. 
  • This process, known as the cortical reaction, prevents additional sperm from binding and penetrating the oocyte, ensuring monospermy. 
  • ZP2 undergoes proteolytic cleavage after fertilization, modifying the zona structure and preventing further sperm interaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ZP3: ZP3 is primarily responsible for binding sperm to the zona pellucida and initiating the acrosome reaction, allowing the sperm to penetrate the zona. However, it does not play a role in zona hardening after sperm entry.

 

Option B. ZP1: ZP1 contributes to the structural integrity of the zona pellucida but is not directly involved in zona hardening or the prevention of polyspermy.

 

Option C. ZP4: ZP4 is another zona pellucida protein involved in sperm binding but does not play a role in zona hardening or preventing polyspermy after sperm penetration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ZP2 is the zona pellucida protein primarily responsible for zona hardening, a process that prevents polyspermy by blocking additional sperm from binding and penetrating the oocyte after fertilization. 
  • This ensures successful monospermic fertilization.

choices.text: Stop leprosy drugs and add steroids
Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman diagnosed with leprosy presents with a type 2 Lepra reaction. What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

 

  • In type 2 Lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum or ENL), inflammation is typically a response to the underlying leprosy infection. The primary management involves:
    1. Continuing anti-leprosy drugs to treat the underlying infection. Stopping or altering the anti-leprosy regimen can lead to a worsening of the disease.
    2. Adding steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction. Steroids, such as prednisolone, are the first-line treatment for type 2 Lepra reaction. They help reduce the inflammation and prevent further complications.
  • Steroids are usually started at a high dose and tapered gradually. This treatment strategy is particularly important in pregnant women as controlling the reaction without disrupting the anti-leprosy treatment is critical for both maternal and fetal health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop leprosy drugs and add steroids: This approach is incorrect as stopping anti-leprosy drugs can lead to a flare-up of the disease and worsen the patient’s condition. The anti-leprosy drugs must be continued, and only steroids are added to manage the type 2 Lepra reaction.

 

Option B. Thalidomide: While thalidomide is effective in treating ENL, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenicity. Thalidomide can cause serious birth defects, so it should not be used in pregnant patients. Therefore, this is not a suitable option.

 

Option C. Thalidomide + steroids: Although this combination is an effective treatment for type 2 Lepra reaction in non-pregnant individuals, thalidomide is not safe during pregnancy. Therefore, this option is not recommended in a pregnant woman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In type 2 Lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum), continuing anti-leprosy drugs and adding steroids is the preferred treatment strategy, especially in pregnant women, to manage the inflammatory reaction without disrupting the treatment of leprosy. 
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, progressive vision loss, and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Further evaluation reveals optic atrophy, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, and diabetes insipidus. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of DIDMOAD syndrome. Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WFS1

 

  • DIDMOAD syndrome (also known as Wolfram Syndrome) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by Diabetes Insipidus, Diabetes Mellitus, Optic Atrophy, and Deafness. 
  • It is most commonly caused by mutations in the WFS1 gene, which encodes wolframin, a protein involved in endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis. 
  • The syndrome typically presents in childhood or adolescence with diabetes mellitus and progressive optic atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FOXP3: Mutations in FOXP3 are associated with IPEX syndrome, not DIDMOAD.

 

Option C. HNF1A: Mutations in HNF1A are associated with MODY (Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young).

 

Option D. PDX1: Mutations in PDX1 are linked to pancreatic development defects and some forms of neonatal diabetes but not DIDMOAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WFS1 gene mutations are responsible for DIDMOAD syndrome (Wolfram Syndrome), which presents with a combination of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, optic atrophy, and deafness.

questions.text: A patient was being examined for suspected Peripheral Arterial Disease. On history, he had complaints of claudication in his right calf. On examination, his right-sided femoral pulse was present but all pulses distal to that were absent. The left side was normal on examination. What is the most likely site of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Femoropopliteal obstruction 

 

The patient's symptoms and examination findings, with the absence of pulses distal to the right femoral pulse, suggest a femoropopliteal obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortoiliac obstruction: Incorrect. Aortoiliac obstruction would typically affect pulses more proximally, including the femoral pulse, and lead to bilateral gluteal claudication

 

Option C. Iliac obstruction: Incorrect. Iliac obstruction alone wouldn't explain the absence of pulses distal to the right femoral pulse. It would lead to thigh claudication.

 

Option D. Posterior tibial obstruction: Incorrect. Posterior tibial obstruction would lead to claudication in the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sites of obstruction and their respective clinical findings-

choices.text: Infants born with physical deformities due to maternal cocaine use
Infants exposed to crack cocaine in utero during the 1980s-1990s epidemic
Children born with neonatal withdrawal symptoms after maternal crack use
Newborns who are exposed to cocaine after birth via breastfeeding

questions.text: The term ‘crack baby’ refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infants exposed to crack cocaine in utero during the 1980s-1990s epidemic

 

  • The term ‘crack baby’ was used to describe children who were exposed to crack cocaine while in the womb during the 1980s-1990s crack cocaine epidemic in the United States. 
  • These children were often affected by a variety of developmental and behavioral issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infants born with physical deformities due to maternal cocaine use: Cocaine use during pregnancy is not typically associated with major physical deformities. However, it may increase the risk of low birth weight, placental abruption, and preterm labor, but physical deformities are not a hallmark of "crack baby" syndrome.

 

Option C. Children born with neonatal withdrawal symptoms after maternal crack use: Neonatal withdrawal symptoms, also known as Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS), are primarily seen in infants exposed to opioids, not cocaine. Cocaine does not cause a withdrawal syndrome in neonates.

 

Option D. Newborns who are exposed to cocaine after birth via breastfeeding: While cocaine can be transmitted through breast milk, this is not the context in which the term "crack baby" was coined. The term specifically refers to prenatal exposure to crack cocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The term ‘crack baby’ refers to infants exposed to crack cocaine in utero during the 1980s-1990s crack cocaine epidemic.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with progressive macrocephaly, irritability, and vomiting over the last several weeks. Imaging reveals obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow at the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius. Which of the following ventricles will most likely enlarge due to this obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both lateral and third ventricles

 

  • The aqueduct of Sylvius (cerebral aqueduct) connects the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle, allowing CSF to flow between them. When there is obstruction at the aqueduct of Sylvius:
    • CSF cannot flow distally from the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle.
    • This causes enlargement of the third ventricle as well as the lateral ventricles, which drain into the third ventricle via the foramen of Monro.
    • The fourth ventricle remains unaffected because it is distal to the obstruction.
  • This results in non-communicating (obstructive) hydrocephalus, which is characterized by dilation of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both third and fourth ventricles: The obstruction occurs above the fourth ventricle at the aqueduct of Sylvius, so CSF cannot reach the fourth ventricle. Therefore, only the third and lateral ventricles enlarge.

 

Option C. Only third ventricle: The third ventricle enlarges, but so do the lateral ventricles because CSF flow is blocked downstream, and CSF accumulates in both areas.

 

Option D. Only lateral ventricles: The lateral ventricles enlarge, but the third ventricle also enlarges because the obstruction occurs distal to it at the aqueduct of Sylvius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An obstruction at the aqueduct of Sylvius causes non-communicating hydrocephalus, leading to enlargement of the lateral and third ventricles, while the fourth ventricle remains unaffected.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of blurred vision. After conducting a refractive error test, you find that the patient has a lens with a power of 0.25 diopters. Based on this finding, what is the focal length of the lens in meters?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 meters

 

The power (P) of a lens is related to its focal length (f) by the formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • P is the power of the lens in diopters (D)
  • f is the focal length in meters.

 

For a lens with a power of 0.25 D, the formula can be rearranged to solve for focal length:

 

 

Thus, the focal length of the lens is 4 meters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The power of a lens is the reciprocal of its focal length.

choices.text: Activation of a stimulatory G protein
Activation of an inhibitory G protein

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, and muscle cramps after consuming contaminated seafood during a family trip. Stool analysis reveals the presence of Vibrio cholerae. The molecular mechanism responsible for this patient's symptoms involves which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Activation of a stimulatory G protein

 

  • Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes activation of the stimulatory G protein (Gs). 
  • This leads to continuous activation of adenylyl cyclase, resulting in increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. 
  • Elevated cAMP stimulates chloride secretion through CFTR channels, followed by sodium and water, leading to massive watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibition of protein synthesis: Seen in diphtheria and Shiga toxins, which block elongation factor-2, halting protein synthesis. This does not occur in cholera.

 

Option C. Activation of an inhibitory G protein: Cholera toxin activates Gs, not Gi. Activation of Gi would inhibit adenylyl cyclase and reduce cAMP, which is inconsistent with cholera.

 

Option D. Increased intracellular calcium release: This occurs in toxins from Clostridium difficile and Clostridium perfringens. Cholera works via cAMP, not calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholera toxin activates the stimulatory G protein (Gs), increasing cAMP and causing severe watery diarrhea through excessive chloride and water secretion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presents to the pain clinic for a procedure involving local anesthetic infiltration for pain management. The physician wants to ensure that the patient receives adequate anesthesia with minimal systemic absorption issues. What is the correct order of routes for the absorption of local anesthetics from fastest to slowest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostal, Brachial, Epidural, Caudal

 

  • The rate of absorption of local anesthetics is largely determined by the vascularity of the injection site. 
  • Intercostal injections are absorbed the fastest due to the rich vascular supply of the intercostal spaces. 
  • This is followed by brachial plexus blocks, which are also highly vascularized. Epidural and caudal blocks are absorbed more slowly because of the comparatively lower vascularity of these spaces.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • When administering local anesthetics, it's crucial to consider the rate of systemic absorption to avoid toxicity. 
  • The intercostal route has the fastest absorption, followed by the brachial, with the epidural and caudal routes having slower absorption rates.

choices.text: It causes severe effects on kidney
It is structural analogue of isoflurane
It has very high blood gas partition coefficient

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient is scheduled for a routine orthopedic surgery under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist opts to use desflurane as the primary inhaled anesthetic agent. While discussing its properties with a trainee, the anesthesiologist reviews several characteristics of desflurane. Which one of the following statements regarding desflurane is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a structural analogue of isoflurane

 

  • Correct. Desflurane closely resembles isoflurane in structure but has quicker recovery times due to its lower solubility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It causes severe effects on kidney: Incorrect because desflurane is known for having least effects on kidney compared to other anesthetic agents.

 

Option C. It has very high blood gas partition coefficient: Incorrect because desflurane actually has a low blood–gas partition coefficient, which allows for rapid induction and recovery from anesthesia.

 

Option D. It is metabolically unstable: Incorrect. Desflurane is relatively stable metabolically with minimal metabolism in the body.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Desflurane is closely related to isoflurane in its chemical structure but is characterized by its low solubility in blood, allowing for quick adjustments in anesthesia depth and faster recovery times post-surgery.

questions.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in which type of collagen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen 1

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

Osteogenesis Imperfecta/Brittle Bone Disease is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation. 

 

So, there is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen 3: Collagen type III is a fibrillar collagen found in tissues such as skin, lungs, and blood vessels. It is involved in providing structural support and integrity to these tissues.

 

Option B. Collagen 2: Collagen type II is a fibrillar collagen that is a major component of cartilage. It provides structural support and tensile strength to cartilage, which is essential for its function in joints.

 

Option C. Collagen 4: Collagen type IV is a non-fibrillar collagen found in basement membranes, a specialized form of extracellular matrix. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and structure of basement membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in type 1 collagen. 

 

It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation. 

 

So, there is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth.
